Even at easy sail and under constant vigil, your ship is running the risk in these waters, for slumbering ice giants lurk in the darkness in all directions. "Dead ahead!" comes the cry, but it's too late. A low growl shakes the boat, as a wave dumps it atop an iceberg, which is shaped like an upturned molar. The ship is undamaged, but beached — if only it could be returned to the water...
801626: Nothing in nature can prevail against human endeavour, it would seem. The crew watch with trepidation as the fuses burn down to the stick, before an ear-splitting series of detonations ring across the vastness, sundering the icy claws that had held your ship hostage. A small blizzard of debris blankets the deck, to the hilarity of all on board, for they are free once more!
801627: Ice crumbles all around courtesy of some impressive firepower. Any cannon that can be swiveled at the target is put to use, chipping away at the icy dungeon in which the ship has become wedged until the way is clear. Then, like a cheerful sea lion, the fair vessel slips down an escarpment and plops back into the water. The crew cheer.
801628: The iceberg fights back. Though the way is almost clear, the relentless cannon fire seems to have woken the ogre below — and to the horror of the crew, the vast berg rolls slightly to one side. Great shards of ice detach and bounce over the deck, injuring your men. Quick action is needed.
801629: Get out and push the ship free
801631: Your men live for such challenges, and scarcely need telling what to do. Leaping down from the boat, they get behind her, knotting guy ropes as fast as they can. As they work, the berg rumbles suggestively, but it is your quick-thinking crew who prevail. Once clear of the ice field, the crew will be able to treat their wounds.
801632: It's an uphill struggle. The pitching of the unstable berg does not help one jot, as the men tumble and slide to find grip. Such is the effort required to pull the ship successfully down from the iceberg into the sea, that no-one notices one of the teams is missing. It appears they have fallen through a thin part of the ice to their deaths...
801630: Let the rolling iceberg toss you into the sea
801633: Your ship performs a rather messy dismount. After that initial roll, the iceberg halts long enough to suggest it wants to stay in its new position — but then everything happens all at once. The berg spins violently, and the ship goes with it! The ship strikes the water at such an angle that very serious damage is done to much of the lee-side. Fortunately, the crew emerge unharmed.
801624: Build something to help you escape
801634: The crew assemble a dozen hardy levers to free the ship. Flexible hickory planking is cut and reshaped into wedges, before being inserted into the ice at intervals of five paces, until they surround the stern. On a count of three the men lift, and to their surprise, so does the hull! Once it starts moving, there's no stopping it, and it clatters through the icy obstructions to the sea. Your sailors embrace in the wake of their success — they have been very resourceful.
801635: The crew choose the wrong wood for the task. They select a decorative mahogany veneer, stripped from the captain's cabin. "Whatever it takes," the captain says with laudable magnanimity, but the whole business is futile. Despite the wedges being placed in great number at the stern of the ship, no amount of pressure from the crew can encourage the ship to move, since the levers lack the requisite spring. They'll need to find another way off this iceberg.
801636: The crew realise they are blessed! "If God has seen fit to place us here, we should trust in him," says the ship's holy man, thoughtfully, "I would not discount the idea that this very iceberg has sentience! I know of at least one explorer whose expeditions ride bergs by design!" Indeed, the navigators observe that the iceberg is itself moving, and at fair speed, in a desirable direction. This shall make a fine home for a time.
801637: The days melt into weeks that melt into months. Even the probable agnostics among the crew take to prayer, for each passing day there is some fresh cause for optimism, some sign that someone is listening. As spring approaches, some of the berg thaws. One day, a migratory bird is spotted. At long, long last, a vast chunk of the iceberg separates, leaving the ship mere metres from open water. A day of heaving has it afloat again, though your men have lost all notion of time.
801638: There is no-one out there. After a week perched atop the pink-white berg, with supplies diminishing, the crew cannot bear to wait in the gnawing cold any longer. Any help will have to come from within.
802095: A ship in need of rescue! The vast floating tapestries of algae in these windless waters have long been thought impassable. Just when you thought your own vessel had managed to avoid the yellow-orange plants, you see another ship stuck fast! They must also have seen you, as their alarm begins to sound. With no proper rescue equipment aboard, your own ship risks becoming entangled if you get too close. Should you try to help?
802096: A steamship should have nothing to fear here
802099: Your steamer glides effortlessly through. The crew lean from the rails to peer at the sargassum colony, which is thick with sealife like crabs and tropical fish. The algae parts easily before your ship. The absence of wind presents no difficulty as it would for a sailboat, and indeed, as you tug them into open water, the crew of the ship in distress explain it was not the algae, but the calm that had stalled them. They are delighted to have been discovered, and several of them offer to join your expedition.
802097: Harpoon them and tug them away
802100: A good shot, but there is too little wind to tug them clear. Having signalled your intention, the gunner sends the harpoon crunching into the other ship's hull. A fine shot, considering it was at the limit of the harpoon's range. However, the calm prohibits them pulling the ship out of the brown mass of algae, so the crew consider their next steps.
802104: The breeches buoy guarantees a safe rescue. The crew transform a lifebuoy into a harness, and attach it to runners which allow it to zip between the two ships once the harpoon rope is drawn taut. The stranded sailors take it in turns to enjoy this rather daring form of escape. Having been lifted from the doldrums, they are keen to assist however they may for the remainder of the expedition.
802105: The breeches buoy shears off into the water just as the first sailor climbs onto the contraption, leaving it dangling perilously from the rope between the two ships. Desperate for rescue, the crew of the stranded boat decide to swim for it instead. After thrashing the distance, the mariners eventually slop aboard, their bodies jaundiced with algae. "Five years we've been stuck here," one stammers angrily. They're going to be quite a burden on your expedition.
802103: Inspire them to traverse the rope
802106: A surge of belief animates the stranded sailors. "You are saved!" cries your lookout, "your ordeal is over!" Under the encouragement of your lieutenants, the other crew grab the rope, and with the desperate strength of hope, they cross the distance to reach your ship. Your crew's goodwill has shone through, and the grateful survivors join your expedition without a second thought.
802107: They take no strength from your crew's silent prayer. If only someone had offered a few more words of encouragement — anything positive at all. First to cross is an old man so thin, you could fold him up and tuck him in a drawer. Clutching the fibrous rope is challenge enough for his frail wrists, and after a brief struggle, he drops off. His crewmates jump in with him, and commence a desperate thrash through the brown sargassum. The few that make it to your ship will only be a burden on your expedition.
802101: Panicked sailors toss themselves into the algae, as your stray harpoon crashes wildly through the lower deck, and seawater rushes in through the breach. She's going down! "We brought them to this," yells one of your officers, "we have a responsibility to do something!"
802108: Send your best swimmers to the rescue
802110: Your swimmers are strong and fit enough, but the malnourished crew of the sinking ship need all the help they can get. The algae weighs like a lion's mane on your heroes, as they relay the castaways on-by-one. Once all are accounted for, they lie on the burning deck, panting. This whole episode has been exhausting.
802111: The rescue is a tragedy. Your men paddle like puppies in the densely-packed sargassum — it's hard to understand quite how sailors could be so lacking in practice. Gasping, they reach desperately towards the castaways they should be rescuing, as if for support, only for the undertow of the sinking ship to pull them under. This was all your fault.
802112: "We did what we could..." the lieutenant trails off, "...and we couldn't do much!" answers your steersman darkly. There is so little wind here, it takes an eternity to pass the sinking boat by. Hands reach desperately towards you, but the pull of their sinking ship soon drags them under the surface. It will take an awful lot to lift your crew out of the doldrums.
802113: "Don't leave! We've been here for ten years!" Reads the message in semaphore. There's so little wind here, it takes an eternity to pass the stranded boat by. A drift of shame. Your crew, as yellow-bellied as this sea of sargassum, will need a lot to lift them out of the doldrums.
802746: Pirates! The torn black flag bearing a skull and crossbones is a shock to those on your expedition who thought they were a dying breed. The weather-worn ship emerges from the mist with prepared to plunder. Astride her bow stands her colourful captain, axe raised; along her rails, the spectral silhouette of her starving crew, hungry to feed.
802749: You swivel on a sixpence, ready to blow them away! Quickly setting sails to curb momentum, your ship turns in the shallowest possible arc for a vessel this size — a manoeuvre only a tactician well-accustomed to risk would attempt. Meanwhile, some of the crew have improvised a few grenades, should you want to make use of them...
802753: The pirates are sunk before they have chance to do any damage at all! Your ship's guns target the most mould-ridden flank of the corsairs' ship, smashing it through. The antique vessel collapses in on itself, and your sailors enjoy the resulting plunder almost as if they themselves had been the pesky picaroons.
802754: It's a disappointing salvo. Despite being in a strong position, your cannons are miscalibrated, and end up firing short. The pirates know they cannot win this with their outmoded gunnery, and between shots they draw in close, latching onto your ship with their boarding hooks.
802757: Today is not the day you are vanquished by pirates. The rowdy band charge aboard only to find your resolute crew arranged in a classical shield wall, with percussion cap pistols poking out of what few gaps remain. Although your crew sustain fairly gruesome injuries from pirate axes, all but one survive. That young lad is given a funeral, unlike the poor dead pirates.
802758: You're lucky they don't leave with your ship! Some of your sailors are equipped with old flintlocks, whose inaccuracy permits the enemy to engage at close quarters. The swordplay proceeds so terribly on your side that a section of pirates are able to reach the lower deck, and pilfer all they find. Satisfied, their captain bays "fall back!" and the scourge are gone, leaving your crew to count the dead.
802759: "Take all you want, but please, don't hurt us!" your officer pleads. The pirate captain grins, revealing a jumbled set of shark teeth, before proceeding to strip the chap of his ear. "Sounds fair," he says, still smiling. Your ship is then relieved of its supplies without further violence; the pirates no doubt bound by some arcane code to honour your surrender. You wonder if your expedition can survive on what the little they leave behind.
802760: The pirates weren't expecting such a crafty attack. "I was saving these for a special occasion," your weaponsmith burps. The 'special brew' he's concocted consists of a bottle filled with powder, a hemp fuse, and a nail surprise. There's a shimmering sound as they explode, and when the smoke clears, your crew frisk the punctured bodies littering the deck, singing "Rollicking band of pirates, we!"
802761: Ineffective to say the least. The improvised grenades are duff fireworks, and when landing on the pirate deck, they fail to discharge. There is no time to apportion blame, for the tide of battle has swung again in favour of the pirates, who have hooked the two ships together for boarding.
802750: The turn is not sharp enough. There was nothing wrong with the idea, but whatever tactical advantage your ship may have had is lost with the rather cautious turning circle it plots, out of which the ship emerges a slow-moving target.
802764: You make the best of a poor position. At the last moment, your maverick navigators cut inside the approaching pirates, who had been hoping to board you. Your crew have the breathing space now to act!
802768: After a long exchange, the pirates are sunk! Damage is done to both ships, before finally your men "cross the T" by releasing a full broadside into their prow. Immediately, the enemy ship is guzzling water. Any plunder floating above the wreck can serve as compensation for the minor damage you've received.
802769: It is a damaging encounter. The rotted exterior of the pirate vessel invites cannon fire, but their movements are too clever, never exposing their flanks to a broadside. Keen to corner them, your officers overcommit, and in doing so, leave themselves open to a devastating barrage. The pirates take the chance to flee — which is fortunate, because your ship is almost dead in the water.
802770: Your crew go beserk for the fight. Most of the ramshackle pirate crew fall in the first bloodthirsty charge, while your raiders suffer only one or two casualties. While the pirates bleed out, your men deprive them of any ill-gotten plunder they have. You then scupper the barque, and watch as it disappears, black flags and all, to meet Davy Jones.
802771: Your crew don't seem too keen. Perhaps they know they won't stand a chance going hand-to-hand with seasoned pirates. As the two ships adjoin, it's the pirates who make the charge. Almost immediately, a pirate swings an axe and lops off a head. Horrified, your steersman hurriedly spins your ship away, with fighters on both sides falling into the resulting chasm. Your depleted crew flees at full speed.
802765: The navigators fail to recover from the initial setback. Your helmsman has no tricks left up his sleeves, and cannot pick up speed to outrun the approaching pirates. They intend to board you!
802774: It is a saddening scene. To see this many brave fighters put to the sword is regrettable. Fortunately, the losses are largely on the other side; the pirates' antique weaponry ever more a disadvantage in the modern age. When the last scrawny dog is dead, you set their ship alight like a funeral barque. Your own sailors, still twitching from the skirmish, pour themselves long jars of rum, and remember the fallen.
802775: You are no match for the pirates. The attackers pour in like beetles from all sides, a many-legged brood washing over your forces like some unstoppable plague, crushing all resistance. "I know it's a good'un, but we ain't taking the ship..." the pirate captain is heard to utter by a few survivors, who were cowering behind a locked door, "...just everything on it!" When the sound of looting and cheering has died away, the survivors emerge to find the expedition ship stripped of pretty well everything it had.
802776: Should have waved the white flag sooner. Your weapons drop and the pirate captain saunters aboard. She is tall and surprisingly aged, dressed in the dashing clothes of a bygone era, "For our trouble, we'll have some of yer crew for slaves," she growls, "all of 'em left of this line." She swishes her cutlass and portions off several of your crew as her playthings. After that, she turns more amicable, as her horde loot your ship. As they leave, she drops a feathered glove to show her gratitude.
802777: "Take all you want, but please, don't hurt us!" your officer pleads. The pirate captain grins, revealing a jumbled set of shark teeth, and proceeds to strip the chap of his ear. "Sounds fair," he says, still smiling. Your ship is then relieved of its supplies without further violence; the pirates no doubt bound by some arcane code to honour your surrender. You wonder if your expedition can survive on what the little they leave behind.
802748: Have an officer make a rousing speech
802778: Your men are resolute following the speech. Your acting lieutenant points his sabre to the sky, defying the heavens themselves. "If I, born with gas lighting, heated water, and a silver spoon in mouth..." with each fresh admission a cheer goes up, "If I can enjoy chopping through these mangy pirates, then you lot will bloody well be in heaven!" There is a raucous cheer as the men prepare for their orders.
802782: It is indeed a heroic charge. Led by the acting lieutenant, your sailors hurtle down the boarding bridges and storm the pirate ship, leaving a mangled trail in their wake. The black flag is ripped from the mast, and the pirate's booty is plundered. Unexpectedly, however, your lieutenant then impishly permits the survivors to go free — "Come now, be humble in thy victory! For how dull would the world be without these old pirate salts!"
802783: Pirates are always ready for a skirmish! Having delayed boarding until they were properly armed and ready, your men fail to make use of their conviction. On seeing the pirate planks fall first, your lieutenant backtracks, urging caution in the face of the oncoming horde!
802784: Stay put and pick them off
802786: You only take a few losses between reloads, when wild pirates set upon the soldiery with cutlasses and handaxes. Suddenly there is a cry from the pirate ship. The pirate captain has been hit! Clutching her chest, she is borne away below deck on the shoulders of her shipmates. The pirates immediately withdraw so that they may attend to their queen.
802787: The first round of rifle fire misses, and there is no time to prepare a second before the horde are on top of your crew, binding the strongest first, and maiming those who resist. When the hurly-burly's over, the pirates prop your bound survivors against each other as they trawl the ship for goodies, before they wish you "fair winds" and depart, cackling with glee.
802788: Your men don't hesitate having come this far. There is a din as the two packs collide, like rugby players, over the divide between the boats. Blood surges over the wooden boards, as men fall on both sides. Finally, the pirates are driven back, at which point they retract their boarding planks and raise their sails to the breeze, spinning away to prey on victims less chewy.
802789: Your men hesitate a second too long, and the pirates have made up the distance between the ships. Now they've been allowed on board, they have the upper hand, and are soon on top of your crew, binding them and maiming those who resist. When the hurly-burly's done, the pirates prop your bound survivors against each other as they trawl the ship for goodies, before wishing you "fair winds" and departing, cackling with glee.
802790: The pirates are sunk before they have a chance to do any damage at all! Your ship's guns target the most mould-ridden flank of the corsairs' ship, smashing it through. The antique vessel collapses in on itself, and your sailors enjoy the resulting plunder almost as if they themselves had been the pesky picaroons.
802792: It's a disappointing salvo. Despite being in a strong position, your cannons are miscalibrated, and end up firing short. The pirates know they cannot win this with their outmoded gunnery, and between shots they draw in close, latching onto your ship with their boarding hooks.
802796: Today is not the day you are vanquished by pirates. The rowdy band charge aboard only to find your resolute crew arranged in a classical shield wall, with percussion cap pistols poking out of what few gaps remain. Although your crew sustain fairly gruesome injuries from pirate axes, all but one survive. That young lad is given a funeral, unlike the dead pirates.
802797: You're lucky they don't leave with your ship! Some of your sailors are equipped with old flintlocks, whose inaccuracy permits the enemy to engage at close quarters. The swordplay proceeds so terribly on your side that a section of pirates are able to reach the lower deck, and pilfer all they find. Satisfied, their captain bays "fall back!" and the scourge are gone, leaving your crew to count the dead.
802795: "Take all you want, but please, don't hurt us!" your officer pleads. The pirate captain grins, revealing a jumbled set of shark teeth, and proceeds to strip the chap of his ear. "Sounds fair," he says, still smiling. Your ship is then relieved of its supplies without further violence; the pirates no doubt bound by some arcane code to honour your surrender. You wonder if your expedition can survive on what the little they leave behind.
802779: There's neither spirit nor courage to be roused. Your crew instead seem transfixed by the approaching spectre of doom. Even as the horde board, the defenders' minds seem elsewhere, hypnotised perhaps by the tall and angular captain with greying hair and a wizened visage, who stalks the deck juicing your sailors. Once the pirates have taken everything they desire, they leave just as mysteriously as they appeared.
803042: Unfair imprisonment! While enjoying some well-deserved shore leave, a local militia seizes a dozen members of your expedition without explanation. They are taken to a fortress that's been hollowed into the sandstone cliffs that dominate the harbour. The charges against your crew prove spurious to say the least, and when a hefty sum is demanded in exchange for their release, the militia's intentions become all too plain.
803037: The fine is duly paid. Of course, your crew boil as the militia counts the payment and divides it up between them, all while flapping without remorse about the noble old art of bribery. Yet your sailors take comfort that they have been allowed to leave safe and sound, and mark the harbour on the map with the noble intention of forewarning other seafarers of the ruse.
803038: No fine, no prisoners. The militia make it clear: your crew members will not be freed unless their ludicrous demands are met.
803032: Try to break the prisoners out
803039: You secure an early release! Your men return to the ship and wait for nightfall. At the sight of a signal flare, the prisoners anticipate your course of action and place a lit candle by the bars of each window. After careful calibration of the cannons, a second flare goes up signalling the imminent blast. The candles extinguish in acknowledgement before the ship's guns sound. The cliff wall of the fortress crumbles away! Taking their chances, the prisoners launch themselves into the water below, just as your ship passes by. Tales of the daring rescue will be going around for years.
803040: You make a mess of the fortress — and the poor people inside. The cannon fire impacts the cliff, but your artillerymen have not taken enough care in their calculations. The fortress walls crumble easily enough, but the occupants of the cells are either killed in the blast, or plunge to their deaths on the rocks below. As your expedition makes a hasty exit, the crew try to come to terms with what they have done.
803041: "I think that's the last we shall ever see of them," lament the sailors that night, as the anchor is raised and the westerly breeze tears them away from the unforgiving fortress. As they depart, candles appear at the bars of each cell, signifying — in the imagination of your crew at least — a unanimous verdict of reproach.
800254: After weeks of hot weather, supplies of drinking water have become dangerously low. It therefore seems a minor miracle when a fellow ship appears on the horizon, for surely they have water to share? But as it draws near, the crew are aghast, for there is no sign of life aboard. 'It is a ghost ship, we must flee before it is too late!' they cry.
800255: Send a diver to check it out
800258: The diver does remarkably to spot the fiends furled in sails, or waiting under barrels to ambush, should your men have boarded. Your ship draws alongside the vessel as if to pass, but then unleashes enough cannon-fire to drown it. The crew are elated, believing they have done the oceans a great service.
800259: Heavens shine upon you, for whatever caused the crew to vacate this ship seems no longer a concern. Better yet, the lord has seen fit to provide the water you seek.
800260: The ship's hold contains an unholy mound of corpses. 'God hath forsaken these men', says the doctor, 'but how?'
800262: Have the doctor investigate what happened
800264: 'We are lucky indeed, for malaria cannot reach us now.' says the doctor confidently. This swift diagnosis confirms the crew are pleased to load up the drinking water they have been gasping for.
800265: 'Touch nothing! Get off the ship,' frets the doctor, who believes a dreadful plague has taken the crew of this ill-fated vessel. Perhaps drinking water is itself the cause. The crew are miserable time has been wasted, and that their thirst is still not slaked.
800266: The doctor is inconsolable, 'it is plague. I lanced a bubo, and it ruptured suddenly upon my person!' That the water be contaminated is misery enough, but to have to abandon the good doctor is a disaster! Your expedition drifts glumly on.
800267: No relief at escaping the grotesque mound of corpses, can compensate the terrible thirst of your crew. There are murmurings that no such expedition can succeed if 'gift horses always be looked in the mouth.'
800261: The crew are so faithless, that every creaking plank aboard the ghostly ship raises a whimper. So when a banshee howl erupts from below deck, every sailor runs for their life. One poor soul trips in a coil of rigging and cracks their head upon an iron capstan. The death exposes all the more the crew's foolishness.
800257: Leave and hope to find an island with drinking water soon
800268: No relief at escaping the disturbingly empty ship, can compensate the terrible thirst of your crew. There are murmurings that no such expedition can succeed if 'gift horses always be looked in the mouth.'
800269: Terrifyingly, the ship takes after yours in pursuit. Who knows what dread hands operate its multifarious controls!
800270: Try to outrun the awful vessel!
800272: Your ship manages to escape the ghoulish clutches of that unwholesome adversary, but have no drinking water, or anything else, to show for the ordeal.
800273: Your ship is not agile enough. Men pour into the waves from where enemy cannons punch holes. Seemingly contented with this sacrifice, the dread sentience commanding the vessel calls off its dreadful pursuit.
800271: Turn and face it, whatever it is!
800274: Pirates! But trickery cannot match the power of a modern seaship! Summarily demolished, a few of them are left clinging to wreckage. They beg to join your cause - unpaid. Such are the dwindling prospects of piracy in this day! The crew will jibe at them, but secretly all must be elated to have acquired such sea-wisdom for free.
800275: A pirate nuisance! Though their scurvy deception gives them advantage, they are like many of their creed, rather jaded. By the time their ship is sunk, it has cost you a few good men. Yet the recovery of precious drinking water in among the flotsam, assuages the grief of your crew.
800276: Bloody pirates! A terrible menace even in this day and age! Your crew are outmanoeuvred, outsmarted, and your ship is reeled-in for boarding. Many are killed in valiant defence of the company, but to no avail. Your vessel is duly ransacked for supplies, before the villains are again on their way.
800538: An undesirable visitor haunts the ship. Fleeting silhouettes, knocking and screeching sounds. Each morning the ship appears in utter disarray. 'A night fiend,' gulps the hardiest of old crewmen, as he sweeps debris from the deck. As night draws in again, you realise something must be done.
800543: Every right to a little joke. 'These claw marks!' the naturalist feigns horror. 'Is it something terrible?!' asks a fearful sailor. But the naturalist can bite tongue no longer, and succumbs to laughter; 'No! Good heavens. We have a mother and kittens aboard!' The cat family is found in a barrel, which, it is agreed, shall serve as their home for the duration. The crew dote on the little rascals, their presence a great comfort.
800544: Each sailor strides with inner conviction, as they form a procession of candles behind the smug-looking priest, flooding holy light into every heathen crevice. The priest's ritual is unfaltering, and not only are the crew rid of the night-time menace, but now believe it is god's plan the expedition will succeed.
800545: The crew has its sceptics, even though the exorcism seems at first to have worked. Two days later a sailor cries, 'It had glowing yellow eyes!' upon having sighted the demon near the hold. The unholy thing must be caught.
800547: It is nothing so savage. All are concealed around the strip of meat, expecting the worst. But what descends from the rafters of the hold, silent and gentle winged, is a luminous white owl. It is an ambiguous omen, according to those that know, but the sailors are content to keep it aboard.
800548: Whatever it is, it is far too clever. It avoids the bait, but continues its night raids. Rumour this is an offended Klabautermann are substantiated by several separate accounts. Little voices overheard, brief sightings, even the discovery of a miniature table and chair. Some can live with the impish nuisance, but many will jump ship at the next port..
800549: Build a trap to catch the thing
800550: The cage-trap is well-made, and daybreak reveals an unlikely specimen encaged. 'A sort of badger?' is the first analysis, which in actuality, is fairly far from the mark. The compendium of animalia in the ship's library reveals it a 'northern raccoon', also remarking that is 'quite edible.'
800551: The snapping trap is weak and flimsy. The crew are excited by a sharp sound, but rush to the scene, only to find the bait gone, and the trap in disrepair. A piece of bright red felt caught in the spring explains all. 'Klabautermann!' they despair, for it is a terrible omen to offend a sea goblin as they have done.
800552: The crew don't have much belief, and the priest makes a hash of the exorcism. If anything, his fragmented delivery only agitates the creature. The next night, a sailor is adamant he has sighted something 'irrefutably demonic.'
800557: Rather excessive. The soldiery tense as strange noises draw near. Fingers itch upon triggers. The moment demon wings flap into view, the night is lit up with powder. Finally the smoke subsides, and the mangled thing is revealed to be nothing more than a bat. Troops thunder heavily about the ship, before discovering the rest of the hog-nosed critters in the hold. Everyone is left feeling utterly stupid.
800558: Your lily-livered cowards quiver like jelly! Fear chokes them as they spin wildly about looking for something to shoot that they can't see. Two are so panicked they bump together, causing the other to suddenly fire. Shot hits an angelic young sailor, killing instantly. The night terror is gone, but has taken for payment the most undeserving of souls.
800555: Sate the demon with a sacrificial offering
800559: A man's finger for a stowaway weasel! In good faith, a pious sailor volunteers the pinkie of his right hand as a votive offering. But at the smell of blood, it is a slinky little mustelid that appears. With the weasel caught and caged, the night terror is over, but the sailors will not forgive or forget the loss of a good man's finger.
800560: Sacrilege! A prohibited tome is consulted, the vile solicitations of its pages consuming the crew! Unspeakable acts are performed upon a man, so that the demon can be assuaged. Yet still the menace remains, and worse, the crew's sacrificial victim bleeds out from his injuries.
800561: The practical joke is ruined. The bored sailors bemoan the pathetic response to their little entertainment. That the senior officers have been duped by an obvious ruse, makes all severely doubt their fitness to lead.
800553: The faithless crew never take any part of the exorcism seriously. 'What's the point of hocus-pocus when its but greedy sailors stealing?!' yells one man. Accusations fly between conspiracy theorists, until a violent brawl breaks out. At the next mooring, the injured parties desert your godless expedition.
800563: Your sharp-nosed hunters pick up a scent. Pungent droppings demarcate a perimeter, in the centre of which is a crate with a hole. A sailor reaches his arm bravely in. There is a brief struggle, and a whine like the ones at night, before the troublemaker is pulled out. It is a common garden fox. The cunning little creature becomes the crew's talisman for the remainder of the expedition.
800564: Hunters find tracks, but can't say what made them. The marks are indeed strange - disturbing almost. Claw marks that go deep in the decking, as if the unspeakable thing that made them was in some frenzy.
800569: Reassuringly human coughing comes from within. It turns out you have a stowaway - a young girl wishing to escape a life of hardship. She is spirited., and the crew take to her quickly. She is given work to do, and food to eat. All believe she shall prove their good luck charm.
800567: Build a trap to catch whatever it is
800570: Knowing its habits helps. The box is made to measure, and along with its clever latch, is placed where the fiend seems most often to be. The box is found in the morning, with a gigantic rat inside it. The trap appears to have killed it, and that is the end of the matter.
800571: The ramshackle trap box is in bits the next morning. While to some they appear benign, the claw marks appear more frequently. Once a man wakes with his cheeks gouged. Some are so perturbed by the night demon, that they slink off the ship at the next available harbour.
800572: A feeling of calm descends upon the crew. The prayer seems to fill the spiritual void in the sailor's breasts. Approaching the world with a new perspective means even if the unexplained episodes at night persist, they pay it no mind.
800573: The communal prayer is broken by more wild shrieking. It matters not that, apart from vanishing supplies, the mischievous spirit seems fairly harmless. The crew are deeply troubled, and worry their souls are lost.
800565: The hunters stumble guilelessly into its trap. The night is unfeasibly pitch, and the hunters' lamps extinguish. Who knows why, without a breath of wind? A scratching draws near. Then a commotion... and screaming, followed by silence. Just like that, the fiend has gone forever, returning to the air whence it came. Three men lie dead in their own blood. Their livers have been removed.
800574: The menace is very persistent. Restless nights, devoured food, and stolen supplies shall go unexplained and unresolved for the remainder of the expedition. The crew are at their wit's end.
800973: Everything points towards the fiery gate. It appears like a hallucination, an ancient stone doorway suffused with blue flame set into the rock face. Perhaps a long lost people constructed it, as a shortcut through the high ridge dividing the region. Your men consider it an auspicious sign, and would like to enter it, but perhaps it would be safer to take the long way through the dense jungle.
800974: Have the scientist inspect the gate
800975: Have faith and leap through the flames
800976: Wrap up in something before leaping through
800978: The scientist banishes the illusion. "The fire that you perceive around the gate is simply an agglomeration of azure glow-worms." Laughter becomes delight, as the party take the pulsing creatures in hand. Indeed, they are of great help in navigating the dark tunnel to the far side of the ridge, saving you days of trekking.
800979: If anything the flames are cool, like bundles of ribbons brushing the skin. This gate is, without question, an earthly manifestation of the divine, for not far along the tunnel, the light breaks in once more, and your party arrive on the far side of the ridge, spiritually tranquil, and having saved days of trekking.
800980: Some of the crew remain doubtful. Drawing a little closer to the gate, they are surprised to feel no heat coming from the fire. One leap of faith and they would be through! Still, they hesitate, for a perfect human skeleton lies just the other side of the threshold.
800981: Alas! Fire and brimstone! Some of the crew seem entranced by the glowing entrance. The temperatures are volcanic, but the diabolic procession of fanatics are numb to the pain. The others watch horrified, as fabric, skin and flesh renders before their eyes. It makes the long way round seem a miracle of mercy.
800982: Try to determine how the person died
800984: The doctor forms a decent hypothesis, and the crew are convinced. "Even from afar, I can see the bones are in poor condition; not burned, but malnourished." Anxious not to end up the same way, the crew take a gamble, and are astonished to discover that leaping through the gate does them no harm. They follow the tunnel to the other side of the ridge. "I wonder if it was those frogs we licked..." the doctor mumbles.
800985: A little knowledge is a dangerous thing. Your doctor makes several sweeping assumptions, finally concluding, "exhaustion, I'm quite certain. That they died at this particular place is only a coincidence." As the first volunteer crosses the threshold, flames grasp his ankles, then shoot rapidly up and over his body. He drops upon the stone floor, taking his place beside the last poor fool. Horrified, your expedition must go the long way round.
800986: "Ouch!" The men yelp, rolling in the stone passageway beyond, until they are sure they are no longer aflame. With the strange gate behind them, your brave soldiers compare their ugly burns as they march through the tunnel to the far side of the ridge.
800987: "Cowards!" Your men lack the discipline to follow a simple order! You will have to find another way.
800988: They make it. Rolled-up like carpets, they skip over the strange and fiery threshold. As they wend their way through the passage to the other side of the ridge, their worst complaint is the overwhelmingly sweet pong of sweat that is sure to follow them for the rest of the journey. Still, all remain curious as to what that gate really was.
800989: "That he died like a sausage?! What else can I tell his family!?" Either way, your volunteer leapt through the fire and paid with his life. Who knows — perhaps dousing his mantlecoat in a protective layer of paraffin was a mistake! Your expedition will have to trudge the miserable way round.
800990: The crew have no regrets in plotting what they perceive to be a safer, more rational course. Sweaty jungles are the devil they know, snakes and spiders notwithstanding. They make good time, and soon find a shallow incline that leads them up and over to the far side of the ridge. Still, many are curious to know what sorcery was governing the gate they saw.
800991: The jungle thins out to a precipice, which seems to form part of the ridge you are trying to cross. A long and shoddy-looking bridge stretches to the other side, if you want to risk it, or else you could attempt to take an even larger detour.
800992: There is no way through, thanks to your shambolic map reading, as the jungle grows thicker and danker. The group tire, having many disagreements, and separate into factions. The sensible ones stick together, and decide the only realistic option is to backtrack for several weeks. The rest will die among the roots and ferns.
800995: Inspection shows it to be in passable condition. There are a few nerve-wracking moments during the crossing, as the wind whips up and the rickety bridge begins to sway. In any case, all are rather pleased to reach the other side, from which they succeed in reaching the far side of the ridge.
800996: Only a fool would ever set foot on it! Of course, it's nothing if not dramatic as the bridge cables twang, and one after the other, your men pile into the gorge. The craftsmen who had been so very confident in the deathtrap structure's safety choose hang back in shame, as the expedition sorrowfully wends the long way round the ridge.
800997: It is a long trek, yet one that could have been so much longer were it not for some sound map reading and compass work. The vegetation is thick and stubborn. Your expedition hacks their way through with irritation, marking yet another hiccup for the expedition log book.
800998: Imbecile orienteers! There's no way to cross this river valley for a hundred miles! You've covered half that distance before you realise, but having wasted a lot of time and provisions, your men may as well see this major boo-boo through. It takes almost three weeks of struggle before your expedition is back on track.
802270: The lookout is sure of himself: he has sighted a mermaid. In the hot noon sun, sailors suspend their duties and rush to inspect the mirrory waters for a sign of the creature. Lo! There is something — a glimmer of silver tail, and a sweet yet melancholy melody that follows behind it. Surely it's a mermaid's song!
802274: "Something just as rare, and no less magical!" chuckles your zoologist, who proceeds to dive after the creature, resurfacing a short while later. "Poor little soul seems to have been separated from its mother," your zoologist splutters, clutching a juvenile specimen of an obscure sea-dwelling species. "Would you chaps kindly run her a bath? I think we'd better take her with us." From now on, whenever your crew feel sad, they can stop by the creature's tub and enjoy its special warblings.
802275: Answer the mermaid's call with a sailor's chant
802276: Not one, but a dozen strange sea creatures answer the spirited shanty, swimming and leaping joyfully alongside your vessel. Since they seem like no creature you've ever seen, it might be an opportunity to catch a specimen for the benefit of natural science...
802278: A fine catch! Taking care not to hurt the beautiful creature, your fishermen haul the great net from the water, and let her slop into a tub they've prepared in the hold. The crew take to calling her "Mermaid". Though she has been separated from her pod, she seems to enjoy being doted upon, and will certainly be kept well fed.
802279: The men aren't used to catching fish alive. They trap one of the creatures alright, but hoist the net so roughly it provokes the creature to struggle. It contorts desperately, striping its flippers a glistening red, before finally wrenching itself free. Reunited, the 'mermaids' flee to the depths, and your sailors are left songless but for the howl of the winds.
802281: An otherworldly duet. The creatures dance over the waves, as your sailors' song reprises, "I dreamed a dream the other night/Lowlands, lowlands away, my John/My love she came all dressed in white/My lowlands away". There is no greater source of pride for a sailor than having made peace with the ocean.
802282: The mermaid vanishes. The sailors drawl a patriotic war ballad they are fond of, but it has a threatening air, and the siren does not deign to answer. Blue in the face from trying, the sailors mourn the ill omen of the mermaid's disappearance, permitting themselves no more thoughts of she and her sisters, or their undersea kingdom.
802283: When the mermaid disappears, a sailor dives in after her! Your irreverent sailors pick a lewd shanty to sing. Angry this moment of innocence is being spoiled, the impassioned young man tosses himself into sea to pursue the fleeting creature. He is not much of a swimmer.
802285: He's coughed up a lot of water, but he'll live. The navigators scream for someone to jump in after him, to give them time to bring the ship about. The boy is already sinking by the time his comrade catches up with him, but he's hauled to the surface where the ship is now waiting. When he finally comes to, the boy describes how beautiful the mermaid was, and how invitingly her tail swished. The sailors are so jealous of the boy, they instantly regret having bothered to save him.
802286: Pursuing in the ship is a mistake. You lose sight of the boy, until someone realises he must have slipped underneath the keel. Divers emerge with the pale dead boy in their arms. The stories of mermaids are true — but that's not the only hard lesson your crew have learned this day.
802287: Let the fool go if that's what he wants
802288: The smitten boy drowns. He paddles himself to exhaustion, driven on by the hope of something better. Whatever that noble feeling was, you're fairly certain it won't be the emotion written on his face as he asphyxiates. His letters later show a preexisting disillusionment with life aboard the ship, describing a "culture of bullying most uncivil."
802289: Convince the sailors to ignore the creature
802290: Duty trumps distraction. Awoken by the earnest plea of the presiding officer, the sailors return immediately to their posts. The officer makes the case that it "can be a great source of pride to have not given in to temptation," and that "this is our way of life at sea." Plugging their ears with wax like the heroes of an ancient tale, the men now seem more concentrated than ever on overcoming the far greater challenges ahead.
802291: Curiosity gets the better of your crew. If the fable is true, it would be against all superstition to ignore it. The men ignore the squawked orders of their superiors and begin muttering among themselves about how best to catch the mermaid's attention. When one grabs hold of the wheel to change course, it is clear things have got out of hand. The bo'sun, finding this challenge to authority thoroughly unacceptable, brandishes the whip.
802294: The sailors grumble back to their posts. Resorting to such primitive naval discipline has left a bit of a bad atmosphere, but you doubt it will last forever. Besides, the bos'un only gave them a very gentle bruising — anything more than that is frowned upon these days. At least those silly thoughts of mermaids have been well and truly banished.
802295: What you have done is illegal, and the crew have no difficulty making their displeasure known. After the bo'sun has beaten a man's back to a pulp, the crew gather on the top deck, where the cries of the mermaid can still be heard, although it sounds like weeping now. "That act was outlawed a half century ago. We hereby notify you of our forthcoming testimony against the bo'sun in a court of law — that is, if we ever manage to return." Morale aboard stoops to a new low.
802296: Drop the issue and let them be
802297: Discipline aboard this ship is lax. Convinced that their misconduct will go unpunished, the sailors take to negotiating, and even outright ignoring the tedious instructions of the officers. The use of "mermaid" as a keyword becomes synonymous with this rebellious undercurrent, which is sure to blight the rest of the voyage.
802382: Can it be the voice of a child this deep in the jungle? The expedition has taken a several-day sojourn inland, looking for citrus to save them from scurvy. Taking shelter during a particularly heavy cloudburst, they are sure they can hear children's voices through the pitter-patter of rain. Your men strain to see where it may be coming from. "It is Lucifer, of cloven hoof, leading us astray!" whispers the priest, "Pay him no heed!"
802386: "Hush you insufferable fool, it is a marvellous species of talking bird!" exclaims the zoologist. Following a trail of excrement on the rainforest floor, the zoologist soon finds a colourful feather. "Raaawwwk!" splutters something in the trees above. The expedition crane up their necks to find the most colourful avian peering sidelong down at them. The specimen is duly captured for the benefit of the natural sciences.
802387: The sailors close their minds to the voices. With the stubbornness of true believers, your crew convince themselves it is devil speak, repeating "I renounce him, his demons and his works!" Their faith is affirmed when the rain stops, and the voices desist. Later that day, they stumble across Eden; a thicket of Camucamu fruit trees. "Very tart fruits indeed," says the doctor, "precisely what we've been wanting."
802388: The voices are too persistent for them to ignore. "I must know what they are!" one man cries, and the priest cannot seem to dissuade him or others from venturing from the shelter to seek them out. The further they go from the camp, the clearer the child-like chatter becomes. It feels inevitable something terrible is going to happen.
802389: At least let the priest go ahead
802391: The priest's incantations subdue the Devil. The priest swats his flickering torch in front of the party, bellowing incessantly "God is my salvation, the Lord be my sword and shield!", his mouth brimming with rainwater, until someone shakes him by the shoulder. He startles, but his comrade reassures him. "The voices have ceased! You have saved us — saved us from temptation!"
802392: The devil noise drowns out the priest's prayer. As he anoints each sailor hastily with holy water, a voice identical to his screeches "Get away devil!", and raucous laughter erupts from the forest all around. Men and women run for dear life, only for the jungle to swallow them up. The ship feels very empty on the onward journey. "Led to the underworld," the captain prods the disgraced priest in the chest, "by the agents of Lucifer!"
802393: The voices are gone, but the scurvy is terrible. Scarpering from the jungle, the crew leave all their supplies behind. In addition, the expedition has not found the vitamin-rich fruit it so badly needed. It will be several weeks before new land is sighted, and the crew's teeth and hair are already falling out.
802394: It's not children they've heard, but birds! The hunters among the crew know it right away, signalling to the others to be quiet as they scan the trees for the cacophonous culprits. Before too long, one of the brightly-coloured beauties makes itself known. The hunters manage to capture it, and bring the little marvel back on board for the benefit of the natural sciences.
802395: Fear incites a rash decision. The majority tremble in silence, as the eerie voice draws ever nearer, except for one cocksure officer who jabs his pistol every which way, looking for something to shoot. Seeing movement among the trees he fires, only to see his bullet graze the shoulder of an indigenous girl, perhaps five or six years old. It is likely she has never come across the white devil before, and she disappears into the trees wailing. She will survive. The officer, however, is clutching his chest — he has had a heart attack, and he dies.
802398: An old man claims to know the location of a great treasure. You've stopped over at a sandswept port. A gaggle of officers are enjoying sweet cardamom-infused coffee in the morning sun, when one of the patrons approaches. He is old and blind; his clothes dirty. "I have need of adventurers like yourselves, for the treasure of the pirate Hassan Ben Sahid is here! It is just waiting to be found!"
802399: Believe the old man and follow him
802401: He trusts you, and proffers a crinkled map of the town. It is annotated with an unusual script. "Take it! I cannot read it," he says, swatting flies from his milky and crusted eyes, "but then, I never could solve it, even when I had my sight!" It turns out the only thing he is absolutely sure of is that the treasure is hidden nearby.
802405:
One of the officers makes the map talk. She is an educated woman — a graduate of a fine old university, who snuck into the navy by shaving her head. "Arabic," she says, "but here it's written from left to right, like a mirror image." It reads:
"Hassan Ben Sahid breathes his last,
Upon you these spoils fairly won,
As I enter that lavish garden,
may your own thirst be quenched."
802407: Read it spiritually, go to the cemetery
802409: The treasure of Hassan Ben Sahid! The cemetery is modest; just unmarked funeral stones jutting up from the dust. Each is pointing in the same direction. "We need not disturb the dead," your officer says, pointing to a lush grove of date palm, "for our thirst has been quenched!" There, in its centre, is a working noria that might have been running for centuries. "Lower me down," she says. At the bottom of the well is the most extraordinary golden hoard! You go to thank the old blind man, but he has vanished...
802410: Your officers rigidly uphold their beliefs. The old blind man leads you to the modest cemetery — a square of unmarked funeral stones jutting up from the dust. Each is pointing in the same direction. "We should not disturb the dead," the officers agree. There are simply too many stones to know where to start — and no way of guessing which belonged to Ben Sahid. The crew return to the ship, believing that at least they tried.
802408: Read it literally and seek out a garden
802411: The treasure of Hassan Ben Sahid! "The map smells sickly sweet with something," says one keen-nosed officer, "dates, perhaps!" After hunting around, the officers come across a lush grove of date palm. "Our thirst is quenched!" they cry, for there in its centre is a working noria, which might have been running for centuries. One of them is lowered down to the bottom of the well, where they find the most extraordinary golden hoard! You go to thank the old blind man, but he has vanished...
802412: Though pleasant, the search is fruitless. There are many gardens between the arched babs of the old town, and none any less sweet-scented or busy-with-bees than the last. The crew give up their efforts to find the spot where Ben Sahid's treasure lies buried, instead preferring the less tangible rewards of exploring a new and unfamiliar place.
802406: No-one can work out what the message says. "Looks a bit like Arabic?" offers one of the confused officers. The old blind man sighs a bitter sigh, snatches back his map, and departs. As the ship leaves port, rumours spread of the gold, sapphires and rubies that have been passed up. The crew can't help but feel disappointed.
802413: A treasure cache! Matching the landmarks of the city to the crude objects depicted on the faded map, one thing in particular sticks out. "An old fort!" a smart young officer exclaims. The blind man follows the eager beagles in amusement, as they set off at a giddy clip. He knows the fort cannot be where Ben Sahid's treasure is buried, since it belonged to a great enemy of his who came from the far north. Nevertheless, it is full of unclaimed riches!
802414: The map appears worthless without the annotations. "We could have just remained in that wonderful old square under that marvellous arched gate, and sipped our coffee on this beautiful sunny day. Instead, we've sweat our braces off on this childish treasure hunt! We've seen the whole city, and yet we've seen absolutely nothing at all!" So much for relaxing shore leave...
802402: The old man leads you into a trap! He chatters amiably all the way to a hammam — a steam bath — where he insists a descendant of Ben Sahid now works. Before they can realise how misplaced their trust in him was, your officers, naked and relieved of their weapons, are surrounded by a gang asking for payment.
802417: It's a bit of a wrestling match. "How do you like that eh, sirrah!" blares your punchiest officer, emerging from the fight the victor, his adversary left gasping and bloody-nosed on the marble floor. "What do you think you're doing!" rages the proprietor of these fabulously frescoed baths, "this is a place of peace you have defiled!" So much for relaxing shore leave...
802418: An officer drowns in a sweat-filled bath. Punches are thrown in every direction, and no-one sees him hit his head. The thugs hold up their hands, "we never thought it would come to this," they say, when it's discovered he is dead. There is a sombre mood as he's carried back aboard ship, and the others have to explain how he came to such a bizarre end.
802419: They watch as your embarrassed crew empty their pockets
802422: You trade various goods in return for safe passage. Not so much a trade as blackmail, your sailors feel the shame of ridicule as their clothes are returned. What kind of rational being believes in the existence of Ben Sahid's treasure, and permits a blind man to lead them to it!?
802423: Your men offer far too little, so the bathhouse thugs help themselves to it all anyway. Their ringleader, the old man who led your treasure-seeking officers here, turns out not to be blind at all. He gives your officers something rather less pleasant than a massage until they agree to write a note ordering supplies be released from the ship's hold. Once the exchange has been made, your shame-faced officers are finally allowed to go free.
802424: Fantasies of pirate treasure belong to another century. Your crew ignores the blind man, who becomes rather angry and beats the backs of the officers with his fists. The officers pity him, and do not try to retaliate. Eventually he hobbles off, muttering to himself. As the ship leaves port, rumours spread of the gold, sapphires and rubies that have been passed up. The crew can't help but feel disappointed.
802427: A delicious-looking banquet, with no-one around to eat it! Rising smoke encourages the crew to put to shore, but upon their arrival, they find the hamlet of conical stone huts to be deserted. Nevertheless, after months on jerky and biscuits, the sight of the fresh fish, cassava, and bananas wrapped in banana leaves that have been left out has the crew salivating! "It's too good to be true!" a sage old sailor warns.
802431: The expedition have absolute faith in his words. "We may yet be allowed to eat, if we appease the spirit of this fair glen," the old sailor croons, gesturing towards a stone marked with white chalk that appears to have fallen on its side. The crew have absolute faith in his words. "That's what mother always told me about fairy circles, and I never knew her to be wrong..."
802434: Study the chalk spirit on the stone
802437: Your crew study the chalk symbol with due reverence. It has three points like an arrowhead, and the smiling face of a deity at its centre. The crew interpret the slight angle of this triangle as a sign, since it points roughly towards a distant and cloud-wreathed peak.
802439: Let your anthropologist piece the clues together
802442: Your men are soon enjoying every hospitality. "It is a three-pointed zemi," the anthropologist says excitedly. "The inhabitants of this village have departed to the mountain yonder, to thank the spirit for a plentiful harvest." Your men put away their weapons, and sit cross-legged by the stone awaiting their return. The locals are surprised and afraid to have foreign visitors, but sensing only good intentions, they invite you to their hearty feast. The chief enjoys your company greatly, and insists you take an amulet and some bananas as a parting gift.
802440: Follow the arrow towards the mountain
802443: Your men are soon enjoying every hospitality. You're following the trail when your sharp-eyed scout remarks "The villagers are returning from the mountain! They're armed with nothing but palm leaves!". You await them in the open, making sure to keep any weapons out of sight. The locals are surprised, and afraid to have visitors, but as this is an auspicious day, they invite you to a hearty feast. The chief enjoys the company of your knowledgeable woodsmen greatly, and insists you take an amulet and some bananas as a parting gift.
802444: Your crew find some bananas at least. You're following the trail when your scout says in agitation, "The villagers return from the mountain! They're carrying fearsome weapons!". Heeding the scout's worries, the crew detour through a banana grove, where they stock up on fruit and return to the ship. Later, upon hearing the scout's description of the weapons, some crew members begin to wonder if they might not just have been the branches of a royal palm...
802445: The expedition party are content to gather their own food. Leaving the strange village and its untouched banquet behind, the crew soon encounter a banana grove. "A fitting reward for our having left the spirits of that village undisturbed," the old sailor says with a satisfied air, evidently in favour of the rather pious restraint your people have shown in this place.
802438: "It's just a child's drawing," is the cynical analysis offered by the ship's quartermaster, which no-one else has sufficient conviction to debate. "And what's it got to do with whether we eat that food or not?" Spiritual nourishment seems to be the last thing on the minds of your crew...
802435: Lift the ritual stone back up
802446: Back in its correct position, the chalk symbol looks like an arrow pointing towards a distant mountain. Showing their fine physical condition, your men lift the stone on a count of three. It must weigh a ton, but they still make short work of it. The symbol is a three-pointed star, with a face in its midst, which seems to the trackers to suggest the direction in which the villagers must have departed.
802447: The statue won't budge. As many men whose hands can fit around the slab attempt to lift it, but to no avail. "And what's it got to do with whether we eat that food or not?" pipes up one of your scrawny soldiers. Spiritual nourishment seems to be the last thing on the minds of your crew...
802451: The expedition party are content to gather their own food. Leaving the strange village and its untouched banquet behind, the crew soon encounter a banana grove. "A fitting reward for our having left the spirits of that village undisturbed," the old sailor says with a satisfied air, evidently in favour of the rather pious restraint your people have shown in this place.
802432: They should have had more faith in the old sailor. Taking his words with a pinch of salt, your men swarm the miraculous banquet, turning the food over in their hands, as if to divine if it is real or not. Before anyone can take a bite however, the villagers reappear looking rather cheesed off.
802454: A greedy, but profitable raid. Neither side wants to die for a picnic, so they come at each other with whatever they can find; palm branches, rocks, even handfuls of dirt. Needless to say, the scuffle is a very odd spectacle indeed, but eventually results in the villagers fleeing into the forest. The feast, meanwhile, has been almost entirely trampled and smeared into the raffia matting on which it had been laid out — but the crew do manage to pillage a few handfuls of bananas that they found in a store hut.
802455: Too awful to be true. As the villagers rush forwards, your men fire wildly, only to realise the tribe are unarmed, and intent only on recovering their food. One of them is hit — a woman. There is nothing your medics can do for her. The sense of shame is only compounded upon returning to the ship, when a group of your men are found to have stolen supplies belonging to the villagers, in spite of everything. Your expedition can barely look one another in the eye.
802456: Your people are very diplomatic. Immediately stepping away from the feast, they raise their hands above their heads and offer a few reassuring words that no harm was meant. The villagers lower their weapons. Though they seem disgruntled at your invasion of their home and ritual, their chief offers you a generous quantity of bananas to wish you peacefully on your way.
802457: Your expedition leaves safe, but hungry. The villagers stare, silent and disapproving, as your men raise their hands slowly and back away. As the expedition boards the ship, the captain raises a spyglass to the village, high up in the lush green valley. He can see the villagers still watching, waiting, until they are sure the thieves are gone.
802458: Your expedition leaves both hungry, and several men lighter. Not only have your men desecrated the feast in honour of the spirit of cassava, but they remain unapologetic, poking and prodding the different dishes as if the villagers weren't even there. When one man takes a carved ritual spoon and starts digging in, smiling as he does so, he seems surprised when a villager shoots him. A brief exchange of gunfire follows, before your men flee to avoid taking further losses.
802433: Your band of fools mock the old sailor. "Old wives' tales!" they guffaw, savaging the feast like locusts, stuffing their mouths with a fervour that would be unthinkable back home. But when one of them suddenly turns pale, the realisation dawns on the others — the food has been poisoned! Who did this? And why!? Your crew survive, but the poisoning is very serious, and requires weeks of recuperation before they are ready to depart this cursed place.
802461: A watchful lookout spots the enemy before they attack. It seems the indigenous people who built these huts were dispossessed of them long ago, and that they now serve as a refuge for pirates and brigands. Forewarned is forearmed, and the crew stage a small ambush of their own. You bait the curs out before overpowering them, taking all the food and supplies they have.
802462: The command to go ahead and eat is given in error. The lookout has barely given the all clear when she spots the inhabitants of the village rushing in from all sides.
802463: The savage bandits find the expedition before it can find them. It seems the indigenous people who built these huts were dispossessed of them long ago, and that they now serve as a refuge for scoundrels. They whoop and holler from the trees and descend upon a few valiant defenders, as the rest of the expedition turns to flee for the ship.
802468: It's a trap, of course. As soon as one of the sailors touches the cassava, a hooting resonates around the village. It seems the indigenous people who built these huts were dispossessed of them long ago, and that they now serve as a refuge for pirates and brigands. As soon as there is gunfire, your sailors scatter in a panic and flee to the ship, empty-handed and badly wounded.
802547: The crew need some common ground. It is a fact that your crew were recruited regardless of their origins or beliefs, and your officers now wonder if this was a mistake. After weeks of lasting rainstorms, the more devout sailors raise their voice: this constant punishment is testimony to His obvious displeasure at the heresy aboard. Something is needed to bring the believers and apostates together, before things get out of hand.
802556:
The Old Norse has much wisdom to share.
“Men brave and generous live the best lives, seldom will they sorrow; then there are fools, afraid of everything, who grumble instead of giving.”
The Sæmundar Edda serves as a gentle reminder to your sailors that their grievances are shallow and foolish. Having heard the captain quote it the previous evening, the crew awake with open hearts and minds. And what's more, the sun is shining again.
802557:
The Odyssey's wisdom seeps into your sailors' souls.
"For a friend with an understanding heart is worth no less than a brother."
The sailors can't help but compare this tale of camaraderie with their own quest, adventures and misadventures. Having heard the captain quote it the previous evening, the crew awake with open hearts and minds. And what's more, the sun is shining again.
802558:
The Iliad's wisdom seeps into your sailors' souls.
"Come then, let us give each other glorious presents, so that any of the Achaians or Trojans may say of us: 'These two fought each other in heart-consuming hate, then joined with each other in close friendship.'"
Hector's speech reminds your sailors of the things they do have in common, rather than those they don't. Having heard the captain quote it the previous evening, the crew awake with open hearts and minds. And what's more, the sun is shining again.
802559:
The epic poem puts your crew's petty bickering into perspective.
"The battle continued from day to day; and all they who fell, and all the swords that lay on the field of battle, and all the shields, became stone."
The crew themselves are petrified as they hang on the captain's every word. It's a bit of a saga, but they emerge the next morning to blue skies and fair winds.
802560:
Your sailors bond over the bizarre love story.
“There was never any yet that wholly could escape love, and never shall there be any, never so long as beauty shall be, never so long as eyes can see."
The captain closes, leaving the crew to ponder the fate of Daphnis and Chloe, and all the goats. Even the zealots crack a few bawdy jokes, and all emerge the next morning to blue skies and fair winds.
802561:
All are enchanted by the Book of the Dead.
A speculative translation of the Ptolemaic illustrations leaves the whole crew weighing their own hearts. Regardless of their beliefs, your crew share dreams of Anubis and his scales, and the mysterious spells that may transport one to the underworld Duat, to meet Osiris. All emerge next morning — to blue skies and fair winds.
802554: Encourage the apostates to have faith
802562:
A message of forgiveness relieves the tension.
"For the Lord your God is gracious and compassionate. He will never abandon you, even if you have abandoned him."
The priest speaks to a common morality — the universal lessons of kindness to your fellows, love conquering all, et cetera. The anger of those with other beliefs, or none at all, softens enough so that everyone can get on with the expedition.
802563:
The priest further inflames those in opposition.
"If your friend who is as your own soul entices you secretly, saying, 'Let us go and serve other gods,' your hand shall be first against him to put him to death!"
Needless to say, the tensions that a few kind words might so easily have relieved, now threaten to sabotage your expedition.
802555: Convince the zealots to be more tolerant
802564:
Your representative chooses her words carefully.
"We must believe so that we may triumph. God is a circle whose center is everywhere and circumference nowhere,"
quotes the former barrister, setting aside her own particular beliefs for the greater good. The crew listen intently, and agree that the expedition will not benefit from scepticism, towards matters of faith, or indeed anything else.
802565:
The diplomat makes things worse.
"When it is a question of money, everyone is of the same religion!"
A line of argument both insulting, and untrue, since the clergymen aboard only stand to receive a small church stipend for their efforts. "Faithless lot! We do not do this for greed as you so plainly do!" Needless to say, the tensions that a few careful words might so easily have relieved, now threaten to sabotage your expedition.
803275: "A-Anyone home...?" Seeking refuge from a thunderstorm, your people dash for the tumbledown castle. A flash of lightning illuminates its stark towers, barred windows and the solemn stone gryphons either side of the gate. As the last of your party crosses the threshold, an iron portcullis drops and clangs shut behind them! Despite their best efforts, your men cannot seem to lift it. The castle and its courtyard appear empty, but there is a sense that someone — or something — has been expecting you.
803276: Cry out that you come in peace
803277: The officer refuses to give in to his fear, but calls out steadily "We mean no harm! We only seek refuge from the storm!" As if by magic, the castle's great door creaks open. Your men accept the invitation to shelter, but with palpably less enthusiasm than would be customary on a night such as this. Inside, a once-opulent dining hall greets them, its few flickering candles burned down to a nub. But the attention of the crew is frozen upon the head of the long table, where a vaporous woman appears to be hovering several feet in the air!
803278: Refuse to believe it is real
803301: "It must be a trick, for it most certainly is not real!" says a young woman, who rushes forward, hand raised towards the figure. Just as she is about to touch it, it vanishes. "There's a pane of glass here... a mirror!" she exclaims. "Impressive, isn't it!" A diminutive and smartly-dressed man emerges from the shadows, hands aloft, "I'm Jean-Eugène Poivre, and this is my latest invention!" Relief turns to wonder as they marvel at the life-like mannequin he's created for the illusion. "Permit me to make it up to you!" he beams, flipping a switch which fills the hall with electric light. "Geoffery," he calls up to the rafters, "inform the cooks we have guests tonight!"
803302: "Disbelieve your eyes...!" The unconvincing advice only serves to startle the crew even further. The moment one of the crew plucks up the courage to take a step forward, the apparition abruptly vanishes. "What manner of horror is this that we have just witnessed? I will not stay here a moment longer!" he says. Finding the portcullis in the courtyard has mysteriously returned to the raised position, your crew take the chance to make a run for it.
803303: "It-it cannot be...!" An officer's hand quavers towards the apparition, but the faceless woman mirrors him, pointing her claw-like finger as if to single him out. At this sinister omen, everybody dashes for the entrance, screaming, trampling and shoving one another in their haste to flee. Finding the portcullis in the courtyard has mysteriously returned to the raised position, your spooked crew take the chance to make a run for it, only for the portcullis to suddenly fall. No-one but that marked man is crushed under its weight.
803280: The ghostly dinner guest shatters! It was just a pane of glass, angled to reflect an old mannequin! "Please!" A dimunitive and smartly-dressed man emerges from the shadows, hands aloft, "I'm Jean-Eugène Poivre, and this is my latest invention!" Relief turns to wonder as they marvel at the life-like mannequin he's created for the illusion. "Permit me to make it up to you!" he beams, flipping a switch that fills the hall with electric light. "Geoffery," he calls up to the rafters, "inform the cooks we have guests tonight!"
803281: Horror! The bullet passes through flesh and blood!" "Patricia...! Patricia!!" wails the illusionist, as he rushes from the wings to be beside the actress — his dying wife. "Oh, lord! Whatever have you done, sirs!" A moment later, she dies in his arms. That your soldiers were duped by a bit of make-up and a costume doesn't say much for their judgement. The expedition leaves the poor man and his tragic theatre set, and departs into the rain, which seems to fall harder and louder than ever before.
803282: The first mate's tremulous voice returns no answer but its own echo, somehow distorted and corrupted by the castle walls. Could it be that whatever now inhabits this place, no longer has the power to speak? Or perhaps it is merely biding its time...
803284: There's a way out over the walls! Strangely, no ladder or stairs are found leading up to the high battlements, but the upper part of the keep appears attached. Through a maze of shadowy rooms and hallways, lit only by the occasional flash, the crew discovers a staircase to the third floor. From there they emerge onto the wall, and descend the dark and lush ivy on its exterior, welcoming the feel of the pouring rain from which they had so recently sought to hide.
803285: This castle was clearly designed to keep people in. Strangely, no ladder or stairs are found leading up to the high battlements, but the upper part of the keep appears attached. After what feels like hours wandering the labyrinthine corridors of the keep, a peculiar door swings open. It appears to lead to a master bedroom. A soft, plaintive song rises from within, where a young woman is found at her mirror. She sits combing her hair, her bridal dress soiled and torn, and her face impossibly pale.
803286: Refuse to believe she is real
803287: Faith steadies the soldier's hand as he approaches the bride, but then he stops abruptly. "You should see your faces!" cackles a diminutive and smartly-dressed man, emerging from the shadows. Suddenly the room fills with electric light. "I'm Jean-Eugène Poivre, and this little beauty is my proudest invention." He winks and twists the bride's head one-hundred and eighty degrees. The automaton is so lifelike, it chills your men even now. They do not take well to learning the illusionist has been toying with them, and leave early the following morning, still very upset.
803288: Their faith cannot prepare them for this. Her head suddenly spins on its axis, her face not young and pale as in the mirror, but shrunken and grey — a thousand-years old! — its empty eye sockets seething with a colony of larvae! The sailors run, rushing through the dark, dark halls, trampling the rickety stairs, and out into the rain. Finding the portcullis raised, they rush for the beyond; a lifetime of insomnia.
803290: The phantom bride shatters! It was just a sheet of glass, angled to reflect a mannequin in a hidden alcove! A small man storms in from the shadows. "Who do you think you are, destroying my precious illusion?" he screams. "Have you any idea how much effort — not to mention expense — I'd invested in this pure sheet of glass, and the lifelike skin of the mannequin you've just pierced with your bullets! Get away from this place — away!" Your people trudge out into the rain.
803291: Horror! The bullet passes through flesh and blood! "Patricia...! Patricia!!" wails the illusionist, as he rushes from the wings to be beside the actress — his dying wife. "Oh, lord! Whatever have you done, sirs!" A moment later, she dies in his arms. That your soldiers were duped by a bit of make-up and a costume doesn't say much for their judgement. The expedition leaves the poor man and his tragic theatre set, and departs into the rain, which seems to fall harder and louder than ever before.
803292: Try again to force the gates
803293: Success! Unable to resist the sailors' immense strength, the portcullis raises just the fraction needed to get everyone underneath. It takes good teamwork on the far side to get the last stragglers under, and the crew emerge shelterless, but free of this nightmarish place.
803294: It's useless. Everyone tries their best, but they simply don't have the strength. Two men strain their shoulders, but still the portcullis cannot be raised an inch. Someone notices a cable leading from the top of the barbican where the portcullis is held, up to a high window on the keep.
803295: Try to scale the walls instead
803296: Finally free of this nightmare! The sailors are able to help each other up to the battlements, despite the interior walls of the castle being smooth and featureless — almost as if they've been designed to keep people in... Once they've clambered down the ivy on the other side of the thick walls, your expedition party begins to look for somewhere safe to sleep — if it's not too cold and wet, that is.
