803297: Only the able-bodied make it. The interior walls of the castle are smooth and featureless — almost as if they've been designed to keep people in... However, only when the skilled climbers reach the battlements do they realise that there's no easy way to help the rest up. "We'll come back for you in the morning," they say. Returning after a damp and sleepless night, they find the portcullis raised, yet can see no sign of their comrades. A thorough search of the castle is conducted, but the devilish place is found to be completely deserted.
803299: It's a foul night in the rain. There's minimal shelter from the elements within these smooth and featureless walls, and the rising moan of the gale is unbearable. Finally, at dawn, the storm relents. At about half past the hour of ten, the castle door swings open, and a friendly-faced man emerges from it. "What in blazes!" he laughs, "What are all you fellows doing out here!" He explains that he is the heir to this castle, which he claims survived a siege in 1422, and that the portcullis is a rather sensitive beast these days. Your men are pretty peeved, not to mention a little feverish, at the thought they could have spent the night in a comfortable four-poster bed.
800468: A matter of the heart. The crew have been enjoying some island hospitality, but many are now refusing to leave. They have fallen in love with the sons and daughters of the local king. Perhaps he can be convinced to allow them to come with you? You can attempt to come to an arrangement, or else wait for him to consult his copper oracle.
800474: The king is not only surprised, but moved to tears by the romantic composers he hears via the gramophone. He insists on a grand banquet to celebrate the union of his children and your crew. Both traditional music and a few cranks of the new-fangled gramophone accompany the beautiful ceremony, and then its bon voyage!
800471: Convince the king your crew's affection is genuine
800475: The king is delighted to see his children wed. Delicate understanding of local custom and a smattering of their language allow a message of true love to be conveyed. The king evidently thinks his children in good hands. Feasting, and to the amusement of all, terrible dancing, follows. For his departing children, it shall be the longest, most fascinating honeymoon.
800476: Something is lost in translation. Yet the king smiles benignly, as if your crew still have a chance to prove themselves. 'He suggests a great hunt,' says your diplomat, 'or else we may await arcane judgment.' His eyes flick to a copper oracle on a dais.
800478: Capture the king a prize animal
800480: The hunt goes quite well. Beautiful boars inhabit the woods, and though tricky to catch, are little trouble for your experts. Though the king will still not allow you to leave with his children, the feast of boar brings everyone together in the moment. The lovers understand this moment is all they have, and the next morning there is an acceptance that it is time to part ways.
800481: The hunt is not perfect. The crew show courage in pursuit of a tiger, which draws the king's admiration. Sadly, they cannot catch it, which leaves the king wondering if your men will be able to provide once married. Thus, he decides not to let his children leave. Some of your crew remain committed to staying behind, and it is with regret you must continue without them.
800482: Your naive hunters fail the test. Forest deer are everywhere, and hunting them hardly seems a challenge. Had your so-named 'hunters' any respect for nature, they'd have realised the sacred deer were not what the king was after. Instead they gather them up greedily. The king makes it perfectly clear your expedition must move on. With heavy hearts, the sailors return to the ship.
800479: Face the verdict of the copper oracle
800483: The oracle predicts a reassuring fate for all. Those who wish to remain for love will live fulfilling lives, but the same shall be true for those still committed to your expedition. All parties feel a sense of peace. Your voyage shall continue without any resentment towards those it leaves behind.
800484: The copper oracle is disappointingly undecided. The king cannot, in good faith, allow his children to leave to an uncertain destiny. His ultimatum is that your crew become part of his extensive family or else they must leave alone. Though understandable, it is nevertheless regrettable when some decide to stay behind.
800485: The copper oracle predicts that your souls cannot be saved. With your crew rotten to the core, the king makes it clear there can be no union with his children, and that you are no longer welcome. Heart-broken and bearing the burden of sin, the crew return to the triviality of duty.
800477: The awkward gestures and diagrams in the sand prove highly offensive to the king and his people. Sensing outrage, the crew back away towards the ship. The angry locals fire arrows at their former amours. Fittingly, one is struck in the heart, and bleeds out into the brine. The rest return lovelorn, to their dreary maps and compasses.
800472: Await the verdict of the copper oracle
800486: The copper oracle sees only purity in your crew's hearts. It predicts a bounteous future for the king's children, and so with tearful pride, he gives the couples his blessing. The traditional ceremony is both spiritually uplifting and wholesome.
800487: The copper oracle reveals a little doubt in your crew's hearts. The king interprets that his children will only be happy if they remain on the island., and that some of your sailors are not in love, but merely infatuated. Still, you must lose the fine crew who have formed genuine bonds.
800488: The copper oracle reveals great doubt in your crew's hearts. The king does not for a minute believe that your inconstant crew are as deep in love as they claim. If they cannot demonstrate otherwise, it might be better if your people left.
800490: Try to convince the king your crew are worthy
800492: Careful diplomacy has him thinking twice. Perhaps there is a way for the crew to prove themselves. A lean champion steps forward. Fighting him may impress the king, or else you can try and outhunt him.
800496: You have your champions. One-by-one the suitors fight the king's champion. Those who prevail, it turns out, are permitted to take their lovers to sea. Some fail, but can at least drown their sorrows during the farewell celebration that follows.
800497: It is not a pleasant sight for the faint of heart. Your best champion is put forward, and subsequently knocked about the head for the entirety of the contest. At the end a cloth is needed to conceal the disfigured face. The king expresses his condolences for your loss, but all is fair in love and war.
800498: It is close but the king's champion is outfoxed. By sundown your best hunter has claimed six boars to their five. The king will still not allow you to leave with his children, but the feast of boar brings everyone together in one moment. The lovers understand a moment is all they have, and the next morning there is an acceptance that it is time to part ways.
800499: Lacking the skill, your hunters try to cheat. Without knowledge of the island's fauna, they decide to follow the king's hunters in the hope of poaching the animal they are tracking. But they are led a merry dance. Three days pass, and your champion is missing presumed dead. The crew have no choice but to depart, tail between their legs.
800493: The king is offended by your insolence. Without a word he boards a boat and heads out to sea. Some foolishly follow, believing he can be reasoned with, but they have even less knowledge of local boats than local customs. Their bodies will be dredged from the reef as your tactless expedition struggles on.
800491: Order the crew to leave at once
800500: Paradise lost! The expedition may be back underway, but the mood is abject as the beautiful island becomes but painful memory. Too painful for one, who is discovered dead, it is said, by way of a broken heart.
800489: The copper oracle proclaims your crew's hearts sinful and wicked. Arm-in-arm with their new-found amours, the sailors await some happy answer. But the moment the king's arm is raised, daggers unsheathe, plunging into the hearts of the would-be lovers. Speechless and unharmed, the rest are free to leave the island, pondering the grave cost of faithlessness.
800473: Leave without the crew who've fallen in love
800501: It is a significant blow. Any happiness the crew might feel at their comrades finding love is consumed by feelings of resentment. How could they have been so selfish? The expedition goes on, but those who are still a part must take on twice as much work.
800114: With water supplies so low, the sight of an island waterfall elicits a mighty cheer from the crew. But up close, high temple walls adorned with monkeys shield access to the water, and the temple entrance is obstructed by a crowd of devotees, deep in ritual.
800115: Have [AssetData([ExpeditionEventRequirement]) Text] shed light on the meaning of the ritual
800120: 'Nothing to fear from this ritual,' beams the anthropologist, having consulted a bound volume entitled 'Creed of the Monkey God'. 'If I am correct, the devotees gather to disperse the malefic spirit of envy. It would be excellent form for us to join in.' At which remark, the crew begin to look a little hesitant.
800123: Sure enough, the ritual unfolds into a jolly dance. With the shaking of rainsticks, and gentle swaying must come broad smiles, for this is how the monkey himself defeated the spirit of envy. A feast of grouse and soursop follows, and [AssetData([ExpeditionEventRequirement]) Text] is presented a monkey-tooth amulet as a gift. Next morning, fresh water is collected from the waterfall and having waved goodbye, the happy crew set sail.
800122: Just ask to get some water
800124: [AssetData([ExpeditionEventRequirement]) Text] negotiates the much needed-water, through a lengthy exchange of sound and gesture, not all of which the crew can be certain is relevant. Having collected the water, the crew are content to leave the unanswered mysteries of the Temple of the Monkey God behind them.
800116: Have the first mate convince the devotees to let you through
800125: The first mate does enough to persuade the locals - with flamboyant intimations of the hands - that the crew should be allowed to pass. Once water has been collected from the waterfall, the crew are able to put the adventure behind them.
800126: The first mate cannot make himself understood, despite employing the most outlandish gestures. The constant waving of the hands and legs unsettles the local people and there is suddenly an air of tension.
800130: The men seem slightly uneasy. Still they charge, and the locals do disperse, clearing the way to the waterfall. But long after the water is refilled, and the ship has sailed, the crew have nightmares in which vengeful monkeys bedevil them for defiling their sacred temple.
800132: Before the sorry men can ready their weapons the devotees have attacked, and yet more rush from the undergrowth. The party desperately dashes for the ship, but several are skewered in a rain of javelins, each hilted with the howling visage of the Monkey God.
800128: Stay calm, and offer them a deal instead
800133: The local people are spellbound by your offer. They enthusiastically invite you to join their ritual.
800137: The ritual unfolds into a jolly dance. With the shaking of rainsticks, and gentle swaying must come broad smiles, for this is how the temple's monkey god defeated the spirit of envy. A feast of grouse and soursop follows, and as a celebration of trade and friendship, a monkey-tooth amulet is given the men as a gift. Next morning, fresh water is collected from the waterfall and having waved goodbye, the happy crew set sail.
800136: Just ask to get some water
800138: Water goes without saying, seems to be the message from the enterprising devotees, who aren't offended the crew won't participate, but seem now to want to resume their ritual. The crew return to the ship, leaving the unanswered mysteries of the Temple of the Monkey God behind them.
800134: The locals are at first interested, but the foremost of them, clad in monkey skins and wearing a linen monkey mask begins scolding his peers, violently knocking offers from their hands with a monkey-pommelled stick. All parties are now just as agitated as before.
800141: The men seem slightly uneasy. Still they charge, and the monkey-mask and his devotees do disperse, clearing the way to the waterfall. But after the water is refilled, and the ship sailed, one of the crew reports nightmares in which vengeful monkeys bedevil him for defiling the sacred temple.
800142: Before the sorry men can ready their weapons monkey-mask has led an attack, and yet more devotees rush from the undergrowth. The men desperately dash for the ship, but several are skewered in a rain of javelins, each hilted with the howling visage of the Monkey God.
800140: Have your men retreat to the ship
800143: Your crew run fearfully from the temple where the devotees stand so firm. The monkey-masked one is heard uttering hard and undecipherable words that many of the crew later become convinced is a curse dooming the expedition.
800117: Offer the devotees some goods in order to pass
800118: Avoid the temple and find another route to the waterfall
800148: The men succeed in finding an alternative route to the waterfall that is also satisfyingly swift. All are happy that they have managed to refill the water so efficiently, and without having to disturb the ritual at the monkey temple.
800149: Your crew tries to find a different way, but it would seem the only option is to reach the high precipice from which the water cascades. The jungle is very dense, and there isn't a clear route up.
800150: Search for a route to the waterfall source
800152: After some scrabbling amid bristly vegetation, the tired crew finally get up to the water source and fill the barrels. The journey back down with the heavy burden is equally exhausting, and scarcely feels worth it.
800153: The men lose their way terribly, becoming separated as they try to prove themselves in the ascent. A dreadful thud sends a squawk of birds from the trees - it is one of the crew, impaled upon a monkey-pommelled javelin. The rest flee for the ship, but few will make it that far.
800151: Give up and return to the ship
800154: 'What a waste of all our time' bellows a vexed sailor, and he is not the only one. The word failure is becoming synonymous with this expedition.
800119: Avoid the island altogether and return to the ship
800155: The crew troop sourly back to the ship, disgruntled at being so near, yet so far from this much-needed water source.
801002: The discovery of several strange artefacts aboard spooks the crew. Tied to the rigging, bunks, boards, and even atop the captain's desk. A warning, a threat? And who put them there? Since the nearby island is uninhabited, it is sensible only to think the perpetrator must be aboard. The crew must know or have seen something last night!
801006: 'For good luck,' remarks the anthropologist, inspecting the spherical red dolls, 'for the setting of goals, and perseverance in achieving them. Some people or spirit of this place believe they can help us home.' At this, your crew are beguiled.
801004: Ask the crew who did this
801007: Your crew are beginning to bond. Someone comes forward, not having expected to cause such a bother. 'They're for me old mum,' he sighs, 'birds - that one's a little robin. Made 'em together when she was ill. Now she's gone...I...' The others are quick to put an arm round his shoulder; they're all in this together.
801008: No one has anything to offer but the priest. It is his belief that some unholy chapter has opened. The next morning, more of the eerie things have appeared. 'Cleanse the idols in holy fire!' he shrieks. 'Nonsense,' says a soldier. "Set guards within, and we shall have this rat."
801011: Side with the priest and prepare a holy fire
801013: The priest gloats over his success. With a maniacal grin, he sets the mound of idols alight. The fire consumes rapidly, shifting vermillion to viridian. Some say they hear the wood scream as it goes. 'Expurgation is God's work, and I am chosen.'
801014: The fire is chaotic, and the buckets of water seem not to extinguish, but provoke. The flame leaps to the priest's cassock like spring-heeled jack, and as it sweeps up his back, he is heard to utter his last words, 'forgive me father, for I have sinned.'
801012: Keep guard and capture the perpetrator
801015: The teenagers are remorseful. 'It was a jape, a piece o' trickery sirs, we regret t'were not received so.' The crew are forgiving - the youths merely wished to contain their homesickness - and call for just fifty strokes of the birch per bottom.
801016: That night, dire musket-shot is heard. A dead boy on deck, local. A second is seen diving to blue. Next morning a rhythm comes from an armada of river boats, armed with guns. There island is inhabited, and they know what you have done.
801020: One warning salvo is enough. The river boats cluster and slow. Though they lower their weapons and allow you to leave, the anger that your crime goes unpunished couldn't be more marked in their faces.
801021: Your ship is a sitting duck. Your crew cannot man stations fast enough to fire or manoeuvre. Enemy boats surround your ship, before scaling its sides. The blood shed on both sides will stain this ship and expedition forever.
801022: Once your ship is underway she is free. Nevertheless your adversaries are excellent shots, and do damage to the sails and aft. The crew will have to make repairs in the days that follow.
801023: A traumatic escape. In the hurry to leave, your ship is spun broadside and exposed to gunfire. There are injuries, but none so deep as the sight of the dead boy's accomplice below. He weeps, and clutches one of the idols - a good luck charm.
801017: The sun is solemn that morning. The bodies of the dead guards are borne to the hold for burial, but not here, upon this cursed rock. Who killed them none know but the sinister effigies. The expedition fumbles on.
801009: A destructive episode. No one has information, or perhaps they withhold it. Consensus tends towards the latter. Someone wants this expedition to fail, and these effigies are a threat. Paranoia festers. At the next port, a large part of the crew opts to quit.
801005: Throw them overboard and move on.
801010: Chilling. As instructed, the crew collect the dolls and throw them overboard. But relief lasts only until the following morning, when the dolls are found returned, placed exactly as they had been.
802041: Clear skies, calm seas, and mutiny! The tension has been building. The everyday strains of an expedition — the rationing of supplies, a lack of recognition from the officers — it has all become too much for the lower-ranks to take. They are refusing to take further orders, and have united behind a charismatic spokesperson. It won't take much to push them to a full-blooded revolt!
802042: Arrange a meeting with the leader of the mutiny
802046: They soon reach an understanding. After all, the demands made by the mutineers are perfectly understandable. The officers address each of the criticisms of the running of the ship, agreeing where possible to make adjustments — and where they find it's not possible, they take the time to explain exactly why things must stay the way they are. Everyone seems most satisfied with such a fair and democratic resolution.
802047: The threat of mutiny is gone, for now. The negotiations begin well, but ultimately remain unresolved, with the first mate too stubborn to make compromises for his inferiors, and the mutineers seemingly unable to see the bigger picture. After a long and tiresome debate, the mutineers agree to disagree, and grudgingly begin taking orders again.
802048: Their leader insists you meet on his turf. "The officers will join us among our squalid bunks, or there'll be no meeting," he says with more than a hint of threat.
802049: Agree to meet in the sailors' quarters
802051: The leader of the mutineers listens to reason. That an officer is willing to meet on the lower decks already shows progress has been made, and the humility he then proceeds to show, while listening to the many gripes and grumbles of the crewmen, is enough to defuse the situation — even if nothing has really changed at all...
802052: The meeting goes nowhere. It is clear the problem lies with their leader. He is a force of nature, too incendiary for any of your officers to handle. With each new compromise offered by your representative, he makes further, more unreasonable demands. Something must be done, and fast.
802057: The doctor agrees to be an accomplice, and his complicity proves vital. Dispensing with his moral objections, your medic produces a poison that causes rapid respiratory failure. A man known to be loyal to the captain secretly administers it, and within a few days the chief firebrand of the mutineers is dead. "Cancer of the lung," says the doctor, "most probably caused by stress." No-one suspects a thing, but the officers must keep a terrible secret.
802058: It is obvious you tried to poison him. The doctor refuses to help, objecting, "It's despicable — and besides, I know nothing of poisons." Instead, you're forced to rely on the help of the ship's cook. The "wine" he concocts is discoloured, and obviously reeks of death, but the poor fellow is too drunk to notice. Unfortunately for you, the doctor chooses to issue an emetic, and saves the firebrand from his untimely demise. "The bastards tried to kill him!" scream the mutineers, as they converge upon the captain's cabin.
802059: In a final attempt to keep order, offer a bribe
802064: They take the bribe, but their loyalty cannot be bought. The trust between the commanding officers and the crew has been shattered. Since there appears no single culprit, it is agreed that all senior officers be put on probation so that any member of the crew may hold them to account for their actions henceforth. Needless to say, the general mood among the officers is low.
802065: Blood is the only payment they will take. Weakened by the poisoned wine, the leader of the rebels appears on a crutch. His followers part in taciturn awe, as he hobbles forward. "Name your scapegoat," he says. One of the junior officers draws the short straw. "Cut out his eyes!" And with two gruesome oyster scoops, the hierarchy aboard your ship is turned upside down. The captain has no choice now but to grant several of the rebels positions of authority aboard ship.
802066: It's a bloody end, but your officers can fight. Their academy training stands them in good stead as the dissident rabble charges. The sailors, equipped with hooks, nailboards and anything else they can find, are no match for your sabre-slashing redcoats. Although the mutiny is over, and its leader, too ill to fight, is safely in the brig, it's unlikely all those radical ideas have simply died with those who had held them.
802067: The officers show themselves unworthy of power. Without loyalty, pride, or even discipline, the redcoat defenders are broken by the rabid horde. The leader of the mutineers, still groggy, makes an example of one of the officers, forcing him to drink the same deadly wine he was given. The captain has no choice but to grant the rebels positions of authority aboard ship. It will be a rocky ride from hereon.
802068: The leader comes quietly, perhaps because soldiers loyal to the expedition have knocked and asked politely — it's more dignified that way. He is on his own now. Guards are stationed all along the route to the brig, separating him from his followers. Without their leader to organise and motivate them, the threat of mutiny becomes little more than a grumble.
802069: The rebels are ready to die for their leader. It could have been a quick and clean arrest, but the mutineers crowding around outside their leader's quarters don't seem afraid. When a fracas sparks into life, they are vicious. The officers jab their swords nervously into the pack, knowing that what they do is wrong. With the loss of life, and the loss of trust, things look grim for this voyage.
802070: The mutineers leave the expedition. The captain and the officers, having failed to provide a solution, cannot hold them to their contracts. Equally, as the senior ranks have refused to negotiate, the leader of the mutineers is now honour bound to take some formal action. An uncomfortable week of silence passes before you make port, and a large portion of the crew leaves as soon as you dock, taking food and other supplies with them.
802053: Your representative is utterly tactless. It is late, he has had too much gin, and he barges into the sailors' quarters barking insults and commands. The crew toss aside their paperbacks and swing down from their hammocks, laying into him with their fists. Perhaps they don't intend to kill him, but nevertheless, that's what they achieve. To settle the matter, the captain agrees to keep their crime a secret, so long as there's no more talk of mutiny.
802050: That's enough disobedience — arrest the chaplain
802071: The leader comes quietly, perhaps because soldiers loyal to the expedition have knocked and asked politely — it's more dignified that way. He is on his own now. Guards are stationed all along the route to the brig, separating him from his followers. Without their leader to organise and motivate them, the threat of mutiny becomes little more than a grumble.
802072: The rebels are ready to die for their leader. It could have been a quick and clean arrest, but the mutineers crowding around outside their leader's quarters don't seem afraid. In fact, when the inevitable fracas whirls into action, they are vicious. The officers thrust their swords nervously into the pack, knowing that what they do is wrong. With the loss of life, and the loss of trust, things will never be the same again.
802076: A pragmatic solution. The amount offered to the man to buy his obedience is enough for him to ignore the incongruity of a monetary settlement — a bribe, as it's more often known. What's more, he's willing to spread the lie that change is afoot. It's not long before the storm of mutiny has passed overhead.
802077: He refuses, insisting you negotiate on his turf. "Give us what we ask, or this mob'll turn, I guarantee it," he threatens.
802044: Make an example of the ringleader
802078: The budding mutiny is crushed. The first lieutenant and two loyalists are all it takes to seize the ringleader and present him before the captain for judgement. The man is condemned to a marooning on the next island they encounter. The swift arrest and punishment impresses the sailors, and renews their respect for their superiors.
802079: The loyalists find it difficult to act against their friends. "Go on then, arrest them!" blares an officer, when they show a moment's hesitation. The ringleader is eventually captured, made a scapegoat and marooned at the next port, but weakness has been shown. A few little cracks have started to appear...
802080: The rebels are ready to die for their leader. It could have been a quick and clean arrest, but the mutineers crowding around outside their leader's quarters don't seem afraid. In fact, when the inevitable fracas whirls into action, they are vicious. The officers thrust their swords nervously into the pack, knowing that what they do is wrong. With the loss of life, and the loss of trust, things will never be the same again.
802081: The mutineers leave the expedition. The captain and the officers, having failed to provide a solution, cannot hold them to their contracts. Equally, as the senior ranks have refused to negotiate, the leader of the mutineers is now honour bound to take some formal action. An uncomfortable week of silence passes before you make port, and a large portion of the crew leaves as soon as you dock, taking food and other supplies with them.
802204: The splendid warriors are all women. Exploring this deserted settlement — which appears to have been the scene of a revolt — seemed a good opportunity for some looting, but your crew aren't the only ones to have had the idea. As they pass the barricades of barrels, tables and chairs, they happen upon a group of warriors, with not a man among them. Indeed, the long-trousered women assume a defensive formation so fluently, it's possible they are more than human.
802205: Let a woman do the talking
802208: She fascinates the warriors, almost as much as they fascinate her. "Many stray into our territories, but rarely does a woman lead them," says the tallest of the goddesses. Neither she nor the others make any further mention of these territories, how far they span, or if their people dwell in towns and cities. Your crew are invited to share in what they have found, however. As the women lope into the trees, eyes ever watchful, you wonder how they will repurpose all they have harvested from these ruins. It is your belief they may have stumbled into this chaos, from a distant, more noble age.
802209: They too share a love of exploration and discovery! Though they know nothing of your language, your envoy takes great pleasure in unravelling his sea chart. Curiosity soon loosens them from their formation, as they crowd around him, sitting on their shields to get a better view. He describes the ship in gestures, and when he gets to the sails, for some reason they fall about with laughter. One of them snatches the map, and makes a suggestion as to where you might think of going next. It could be a shortcut!
802210: The behaviour of your diplomat is disgusting. Instead of trying to communicate your good intentions, the belching toad circles them, looking them up and down as if to appraise their value. When he places a greasy hand on one of the warrior's cheeks, another woman breaks from the pack and plants her lance in his thigh.
802211: Respond to their violence in kind
802213: Firing a few shots skyward is enough. The warriors have only shields and jagged lances, coming as they do from some nobler age. Yet the way they fearfully scurry away suggests they are no strangers to firearms. It feels like a missed opportunity to have got to know them better. All that's left is to tend to the sorry diplomat, whose leg has a very severe bleed.
802214: They are too fast. The distance between your small scouting party and the warriors is made up in moments, as the lithe women dive and roll, and thrust their lances. All your men are killed. The warriors spare your women, however, giving them only wearied looks as they stalk away. The survivors return to the expedition ship, and report the massacre to the others.
802215: The warriors seem interested, but watchful
802218: Your exotic supplies intrigue the warriors. Their curiosity overtakes their anger, and seeing how fascinated they are by the crew's maps, the sailors guess that the women might share in their taste for exploration. Sadly, it appears too late to earn the warriors' trust, and they depart looking cautiously over their shoulders. You must tend to the sorry diplomat before you leave, as the bleed from his leg looks severe.
802219: The warriors take great offence. One of them spits on the jacket of an officer. He responds by moving to draw his weapon, but the women are too fast. The lithe warriors dive and roll, and thrust their lances. Every man in your small scouting party loses their lives. The women are spared, however; the warriors giving them only wearied looks as they stalk away. The survivors return to the expedition ship, and report the massacre to the others.
802220: Your crew's deference pleases the warriors. Surprised by the sailors' genuflection, the women giggle and lower their guard, lifting your explorers' chins with the tips of their lances. They may not speak your language, but their body language is unequivocal — they are fellow adventurers, and wish to celebrate your meeting. A huge bonfire is made from the wooden barricades, and all enjoy their boozy punch and haunches of venison — which the women insist on eating raw. The wild party lasts long into the night.
802221: Not everyone in your party shows respect. Some are snickering about something, and the warrior women presume it concerns them. They spit at the men, who reach hot-bloodedly for their weapons.
802224: This pleases them, since out of everything, they are always most fond of a good fight. Your men are honourable and choose to fight hand-to-hand. It is a noble and even contest, punctuated by the metallic rasp of sword and spear, ending in stalemate. Both combatants have suffered injuries, and the two sides part with greater respect for their foes. Still, their wounds will need looking after...
802225: They are too fast. The distance between your small scouting party and the warriors is made up in moments, as the lithe women dive and roll, and thrust their lances. All your men are killed. The warriors spare your women, however, giving them only wearied looks as they stalk away. The survivors return to the expedition ship, and report the massacre to the others.
802226: The sailors, especially the men, feel humiliated. "Those warrior women were strident," says one, "I had absolutely no idea how I should respond to such provocation. They wanted us to draw our swords, which of course would have been wholly inappropriate!" The women, on the other hand, can't help but dream of escaping this suffocating ship, to take up a lance and shield of their own.
802673: Local authorities come aboard looking for the fugitive you've taken in. A man in rags offered you his services in a port, saying he'd do any odd job for some food and the chance to join your crew. The captain agreed to take him on. He soon grew on your sailors, working hard and filling in wherever needed. But above all he has proved a man of principle — a champion of the vulnerable — and as such, the crew have learned to respect his silence on the matter of his past.
802679: Your crew stick stoically to the same story. "This man," the officials say, holding up a picture of their new friend, "have you seen him?" "Oh no, no," your sailors reply. Still, the officials conduct a cursory search, but the man of many talents has no difficulty in hiding from them. When they've gone, there is a hearty cheer. "Glad to have you with us!" bellows the captain. You have a new recruit!
802680: Your attempt at deception fails. The officer in charge lies that your ship has never docked at the port in question, yet the officials present a logbook stating conclusively that it did. This only serves to further rouse suspicion that he is somewhere on board.
802683: Hidden in plain sight! Sensing how thorough the inspection is going to be, there's only one possible bolthole for your runaway. "Get in the lifeboat, and keep your head down," the crewman whispers, while his pursuers are being detained on some pretence in the captain's cabin. To complete the plan, the lifeboat is then winched above the eyeline, where sure enough, the authorities never think to look. Not wanting to cause further trouble, he insists on leaving at the next port.
802684: "There he is! Seize him!" The fugitive is still trying to make himself comfortable among a pyramid of barrels when his pursuers appear. They tackle him and clap him in chains.
802687: They don't give in easily. Your sailors wait until the officials pass them by before knocking them to the floor, and confiscating their weapons. A shrill whistle sounds from the other ship, and armed men in smart navy uniforms pour up the boarding plank onto your deck. There follows a heavy skirmish, but your sailors gain the upper hand. The authorities surrender and retreat. Though grateful, your fugitive wishes to avoid causing further injury by his presence, and insists on leaving at the next port.
802688: The fugitive dies, along with his pursuers. When your men try to lay hands on the port officials, they put a pistol to the fugitive's head. "Try to stop us, and he gets it," they say. When your men try to be clever, they blow the fugitive's head off, then do the same to one of your men, before they themselves can be subdued. The dead prisoner was very popular aboard ship, and your crew wonder if things could possibly have turned out worse.
802689: Your crew offer no resistance. They part before the two officials as they frogmarch the fugitive over the gangplank to their vessel. He tries to express his thanks to your crew for their efforts, but the official growls "no more of your activism", and slaps him sharply across the chops. The prisoner was very popular aboard your ship, and your crew believe more should have been done to defend him.
802690: Your threat is impressive indeed. Rows of dark, iron mouths poke from their hatches, ready to fire at point blank range! "You must be mad!" says one official, as they skip back across the gangplank to their own ship, suddenly most anxious to leave! Your fugitive is thankful, but does not wish to endanger your expedition further, and waves a warm goodbye at the next port.
802691: Your men hesitate at the order, because they can see the neighbouring ship is not one to be trifled with. Eyeing your sailors as they not-so-secretly prepare for battle, one of the officials sounds his shrill whistle, and a troop of navy-uniformed soldiers rush up from below deck. They fully intend to board you.
802694: They don't give in easily. A second shrill whistle sounds from the other ship, and the navy-uniformed brigade pour up the boarding plank and onto your deck, where your men sit ready for them. There follows a heavy skirmish. Some are injured, but your forces prevail. The authorities surrender and depart. Though grateful, your fugitive wishes to avoid causing further injury by his presence, and insists on alighting at the next port.
802695: There's no time. Your men, still concerned with preparing for the sea battle, are thrown into disarray. "To deck, men! To deck!" is the cry, as they dive for their guns and rush to the deck, only to be cut down, one-by-one by the men in blue. "Fools!" smirks the official, as the fugitive is trussed in chains, "To think so many died for this worthless streak of spittle... Take him away!"
802693: Let them board ship and take the man
802676: They'll have to fight you for him
802696: You have a new recruit! "You're welcome to him!" says the more senior of the two officials brightly, "We had no idea he was so important to you." His colleague glances at him nervously, before wrinkling up a fake smile of his own. It's obvious they only chose to call off their pursuit because your vessel is far more powerful than theirs. With your ship free to continue, the former fugitive raises a glass. "Thank you all," he says, "here's to a triumphant expedition, and beyond!"
802697: The officials seem undaunted. "Oh, I think we have little to fear from a ship as ill-equipped yours. Still, from your hostility, it's clear you're hiding the man we seek." They signal back to their own vessel to ready arms. "Now... think carefully. Do you really want to refuse to give him up?"
802700: It's a point blank exchange, in which your ship manages to get the first shot, disabling half the men opposite. As such, the return fire is not so crippling as it might have been— although significant repairs will still be needed. As the two ships drift apart, the officials are left in helpless, comic isolation on your ship's deck. Someone gives them a good old shove overboard, forcing the other ship to return to rescue them. Your crew make their escape. "I will burden you no further," says the fugitive wearily, "please, allow me to alight at the next opportunity."
802701: It only serves to demonstrate your crew's incompetence, because they are still not ready! The vessel belonging to the local authority fires first — and at such close range, the effect is devastating. Half your gunners lie maimed, and your ship is shredded through. You wave the white flag. The fugitive leaves with the officials of his own free will — after all, he has better chances of survival almost anywhere else!
802702: Your crew offer no resistance. They part before the two officials as they frogmarch the fugitive over the gangplank to their vessel. He tries to express his thanks to your crew for their efforts, but the official growls "no more of your activism", and slaps him sharply across the chops. The prisoner was very popular aboard your ship, and your crew believe more should have been done to defend him.
802677: Offer to pay the fugitive's bail
802703: The fugitive wears a look of stoic resignation, as his terms of release are discussed.
802706: You have a new recruit! "I will repay your trust in me tenfold!" says the talented fellow, as the local authority departs with their payment. He raises a beaker of navy rum, "Thank you all! Here's to a triumphant expedition, and beyond!"
802707: You can't afford him. Seeing that your men are still reluctant to let the fugitive go, the order is given to lower the footbridges, and a troop of navy-uniformed soldiers file into line, ready to board your ship.
802708: The fugitive does not resist. With a look of stoic resignation, the man offers the officials his hands to be shackled. He turns back one last time before he goes, to say "Thank you for everything," — dignified until the very last. The crew shall miss his company greatly.
800280: 'A fearsome predator stalks us!' the cabin-boy whispers. Perhaps he is right, for this resupply has not been as uneventful as hoped. Only the first evening moored in this bay, and a man goes missing - tracks up the beach into jungle. Many wonder how work can be expected to continue...
800286: With the perfect lure placed enticingly in the crook of a tree, there is an inevitability about a capture. Sure enough, yellow eyes pierce the darkness, and a mighty beast pads softly over to the bait. A net is hurriedly cast about it and secured, thus leaving the expedition free to resupply unthreatened.
800287: Your huntmasters are expert, and trace with great care, the soft hollows imprinted by feline paw. Led to a clearing, they correctly judge this to be a lair, where they stand ready with a net. When the cat returns, heaving hot breath, the hunters pounce. With net secure, the expedition is free to resupply unthreatened.
800288: At least one hunter did the right thing, and kept his eyes open while they traced the beast's pawprints. Another was not so wise, and was heard to let out a scream. His comrades were drawn to the spot, and struck the majestic beast down. But not before the damage was done.
800289: Three days pass, and still no word. There is a common feeling something must be done to save those men.
800293: It is only something of a relief when the rescue party return. It's bad news... the hunters are dead. The rescue party described the bright and long-maned beast, and how in a tussle, they slayed it. With the bodies of the hunters buried, the expedition is able to resupply in an atmosphere of respectful silence.
800294: 'Horror! It's picking us off one by one!' bawls a fearful sailor, for now the rescue party too, have failed to return. There is nothing for the disconsolate remainder of the crew to do, but leave this sorry place behind.
800295: Doubtful prayer brings no news of the lost hunters. The men have nowhere to look for guidance, and there is a burdensome feeling that a decision must be made.
800296: Conviction in the lord is of little use here, it seems. Two days later a hunter, whose leg is mangled, limps back into view. After the necessary amputation, he is heard to groan that the others perished. All must leave this savage place.
800297: 'We leave them for dead, when they could be right there now waiting for us!' cries a furious old tar. Like so many others, he is disgusted that good men should give their lives for nothing but impatience!
800298: 'Absurd magic, but it works!' say officers sent to the inland village for help. Having described the beast, they were referred to a witch. She encouraged them to ingest live scorpions, one of each colour; yellow, red and black. This they did reluctantly, but found when they confronted the animal, it took flight. All promptly follow the witch's advice, and sure enough, remain undisturbed for the remainder of the resupply.
800299: 'Our plight means nothing to the locals,' bemoan the officers sent as diplomats. 'Telling them beasts stalk the jungle, is as like alerting a hatter to the presence of hats on his hatstands.'
800300: 'Their deity is desecrated!' urges the officer sent as diplomat. All around the bay, daubed faces appear, bows raised to the expedition camp.
800303: 'A hollow victory', say the men. For the locals lie dead, but the jungle beast stalks on.
800304: Odds against them, the men fight as best they can. Fought back onto the sand, they deflect the rain of arrows with whatever they can lay hands on. A relay is able to return precious equipment to the ship and set sail, but not without a number of casualties, of whom some do not make it.
800305: The onslaught is deadly. Few among your crew have the requisite experience to defend themselves, and so the sand reddens with their blood. Of those who make it as far as the expedition ship, a number succumb to the poison-tip arrows. It is a massacre.
800306: 'Run!' comes the panicked cry. The men drop their work, and tramp desperately through the shallows to the ship. A volley of arrows pierces three, squirting crimson into the clear blue. 'Dead aside, we have lost a great deal more in provisions than we have gained,' laments the quartermaster, as your ship departs that wretched bay.
800307: The ingenious powers of the craftsmen among your crew have fashioned a pitfall for the beast. There is not long to wait before there is a tinkle on the handbell, and all can gather above the trap to see the monster growling at its bottom. The resupply may now happily proceed, knowing that danger is averted.
800308: The beast is too intelligent to fall for makeshift traps. It is clearly evading the pitfall prepared by those supposed to be the expedition's deftest craftsmen. 'Little more we can do,' they shrug.
800309: 'It's a considerable setback,' say senior officers. Fresh water, wood for burning, plants for medicine - it does no good to list what myriad opportunities are missed in bypassing the bay. And all for the sake of fears over one measly wild animal.
800606: Bear attack! The party ponder this very real possibility as threatening grunts stop them dead among the firs. Fifty yards ahead, a huge specimen lurches up on two legs like a totem, standing between them and escape. More grunting echoes nearby. The party stay silent, awaiting guidance.
800611: Boooooom! The valley shudders with the sweet stench of exploded dynamite. The bears hurry away, leaving the crew thoroughly entertained at the superiority of mankind and the power of invention.
800608: Use hunting knowledge to get the better of the bears
800612: Trust in the expert hunters never feels misplaced, even when they recommend the party break into passionate song. For singing the shanty 'Cheerly-ay-oh' brings the crew together, whilst also dispersing the wary bears deep into the forest.
800613: The hunters lack guile. They have enough to lead the crew on a route silent as a church, but not enough to stop a bear sniffing them out. It's easy to believe from its vacant eyes, that it sees you as a potentially delicious kind of threat.
800617: The bear's face proves a good target. Ducking the terrifying whooshes of its paws, someone manages to prime their pistol and shoot it through the eye. The bear drops dead. No-one feels particularly good about killing it, but the way ahead is now clear.
800618: Adaptation is good when a fight isn't going well. The bear flinches but does not drop after the first round of gunfire. There is no time to reload, before it is upon them with its paws. Knocked down the men are smart enough to play dead. After an hour or so facing the floor, the bears lose interest and leave. The crew are able to lick their wounds, and move on.
800619: It's easy to underestimate mummy bears. As the soldiers fluff the loading of their weapons, the bear nonchalantly grasps one by the wrist, and sinks her jaw into his neck. The others panic and flee with their arms in the air. She pursues a second, striking him dead against a rock. Now she and her cubs can finally be left in peace.
800620: Sometimes it helps to know your hill contours. The crew carefully fall away, circumventing the bear's position, and keeping their backs to the mountainside. With the higher ground, the bear appears to lose interest. Hearts pumping, the crew hurry to safety.
800621: Stupidly the crew decide to run, and reach a dead-end. The bear pursues at a leisurely speed, yet with no less menace, and the crew are forced to seek refuge in a cave, or else try climbing the trees.
800623: Hide in the cave and pray
800625: Against all anxiety, the Bear doesn't follow. Still, the men in the cave are too afraid to light a fire, or sleep through the night. Shattered and hungry, they emerge the next morning, only to find their sacrifice was wholly unnecessary.
800626: Bears can see terribly well in the dark, and since your crew have stumbled into its house, where its vulnerable infants sleep, it is not very happy. The crew that do manage to break for daylight have clothes ragged and torn, and cannot speak, for it is clear they were the lucky ones.
800627: The crew climb the trees well enough, but the bear isn't going to make their lives easy. It is a full day and night before it gives up shaking trunks, or climbing halfway up towards the dangling crew. When it finally leaves, the exhausted crew descend, their nerves in shreds.
800628: Bears are awfully good at climbing trees, and as on this occasion, it is not uncommon to see them strike their adversaries from the branches. Its hapless victim plunges from the canopy and lands like a sack of red berries on rocks below. Others injure themselves as the men drop from the trees in a desperate escape.
800614: Call themselves hunters! The tracks thought to lead away from bear territory go instead to a clearing at its heart. The bears at first seem alarmed their picnic is disturbed, until they realise your crew are on the menu. The sound of crunching bone rings in the ears of the few that manage to flee.
800609: Attack the bear blocking the way
800629: The lone bear's haunch is picked out with expert marksmanship. It staggers before bounding off into the woods. Your crew are delighted to return to the safety of the ship, whilst also having done the mighty beast no lasting harm.
800630: The first volley of shots miss, and the bear attacks. A second shot finds its mark, and the wounded bear escapes into the trees, but a man lies dead. His brother cries revenge, and is already off into the woods to hunt the grisly killer.
800632: Track the wounded bear with him
800634: Bittersweet. Your fine tracking skills allow the crew to catch up with the bear and watch it from hiding. It is a she-bear, and is now nuzzling its young cubs. 'That is why she killed him,' says the brother, gone all vitriol. 'Let us leave, and hope my brother's spirit may somehow live on in this place.'
800635: The hot-headed hunt is a success none celebrate. Once found, the bear no longer has strength to defend itself. As the brother drives a stake into its heart, it gives over with a last sad sigh. In that moment a tiny cub pads into the open, crawling weakly under the limp arm of its mother. If only they had understood, the crew could have saved the heartache.
800636: Hunting is impossible with passions running this high. When another man snaps a twig, the vengeful brother attacks him wildly, and the others fail to intervene. The brother's eyes glaze as he slides to the earth, bayonet in his back.
800637: The decision is unpopular. 'Stubborn 'til the end,' say those in the minority. But the greater part have things to say on the subject of dishonour. 'Those brothers loved each other to the end,' remarks one old sailor, 'and what little love did we show for them...'
800631: Out here, bears rule. The wildly inaccurate gunfire serves only to rile the bear into a frenzy, and draw attention to your position. Then a second, larger bear thunders from the undergrowth and mauls a man to death. A few of your piffling soldiery manage to escape with all their limbs attached.
800638: The bears have no chance. Indeed, the camouflage is so good, the crew can barely see one another! Thickly daubed in the colours of the forest, the chameleon crew bypass the bears with ease. A story of ingenuity at which their grandchildren shall marvel!
800639: Even the most hardened sailors find the smell unbearable. Not to mention the indignity of covering oneself in bear excrement for longer than is perfectly necessary. Eventually though the bears depart, leaving the reeking crew free to have a much-needed wash.
800640: Dressing as pantomime trees is a bad idea, and as the bears attack, the flimsy branches the crew intended to cover their faces prove no more effective in self-defence. The ensuing scene might have made for an impressive spectacle on the stage, though only as the most gruesome of tragedies.
802299: In the Grasp of the Tentacular
802300: Could it be the kraken?! What else could possess "tentacles wide as a barrel and long as bowsprits", as your lookout claims to have spotted protruding from the treacle-black swell? Creature of legend or not, a shadow below the surface is hurtling towards your ship at full speed!
802301: Fire a torpedo at the thing
802304: The hulking cephalopod is no match for the torpedo! The self-propelled projectile requires no special effort to dispatch, and yet its underwater prowess is indisputible. It crashes into the kraken with a wallop that sends a profusion of octo-bits frothing to the surface. The crew are delighted to discover the flesh is cooked, yet not at all rubbery.
802306: THUNK! An excellent shot! The harpoon lodges into the creature's amply-sized brain. It takes little effort to haul the reddish mantle and decimette of long pulpous limbs aboard. No-one is going to believe this trophy when they see it — or that something of this size swam at such threatening velocity! Its eyes alone are half a metre wide!
802307: Sloppy shooting from your pod of suckers. The twisting aberration slinks and jets obliquely, its mantle engorged and thrumming with arcane energy. Its lip-like suckers pucker and latch onto the hull, levering its beaked face up above the starboard rail in a game of peek-a-boo. It is vast!
802309: The monstrosity detaches violently! Your men hack fiercely and without relent at a key tentacle until it severs. The loopeyed beast blubbers a pained raspberry, coating the deck with plankton-infused clamminess, before tearing itself back into the sea, with a large section of your ship in tow! Some repairs will be needed!
802310: There are just too many legs! Having been interrupted at dinner, your sailors try to improvise a dissection with their knives and forks, but the monstrosity refuses to become calamari. Its innumerable tendrils cavort, punching holes and tossing sailors at whim! One unfortunate sailor is flung so perfectly that his return trajectory lands him directly, and fatally, atop a flagpole. Having satiated itself on flesh and timber, the kraken detaches, and bolts away with typical flourish.
802312: Right in the mandibles! The kraken inhales the slew of heavy artillery and is propelled outwards and star-like, before plummeting to the depths with a good part of your ship still in its grip. Repairs will be needed! You cannot think why the creature was so offended by your presence, but at least it now has some memento of your meeting to clutch onto.
802313: Your gunmen cannot keep their feet long enough. The ctenidious cephalopod rocks the ship to and fro, shaking your boys from the big guns, before sealing itself over an open window and sucking up men as if it had a straw in an ice cream sundae. Eventually, after deciding it's poked and prodded enough, the monstrosity relinquishes its goily grasp, and flops back to the deep to digest the better part of your crew into a liquid.
802316: A powerful spurt of propulsion! The unnatural power of your steam ship eclipses the jetting shadow from the far, far depths. The ship's horn sounds a farewell salute to the creature, who those present swear is equipped with two clocktower eyes, within which ink-black pupils swim delirious. For now, it seems, its wait for a suitable mate must go on.
802317: The wind is with you. Whatever that bird-beaked nest of serpents below actually is, it relaxes in its piston-like pursuit of your ship once your crew have succeeded in catching the best of the prevailing breeze. Those present swear it was equipped with two clocktower eyes, within which ink-black pupils swam delirious. For now, it seems, its wait for a suitable mate must go on.
802318: Your crew cannot manage to disentangle themselves, for the creature is in search of a mate, and filled with frightful lust. Only once it has clambered up the side, and attached its hectocotylus to your ship, does it begin to have misgivings about the romantic potential of this union, and start thinking about dinner instead...
802321: A track leading over these impenetrable mountains should be a blessing, yet your men are having doubts. Your guide, for a start, absolutely refuses to follow the path. In fact, the very idea scares him. At the base of the mountain, which juts ferrous and fibrous above the greenery like a chunk of braised meat, is a stone head carved in the rock. It grins awfully, and between its huge square teeth is what appears to be a severed arm.
802323: The trail leads through the centre of a hilltop village, the straw shelters improbably nestled between steep-sided slopes. But it is the appearance of the inhabitants that astonishes: unlike all the other peoples of this great rainforest, they tall and pale, blond-haired and blue-eyed. "But why? What can their story be?" someone chuckles, only to find their companions are oddly tense.
802325: Your diplomat establishes a common heritage! At least, their language certainly suggests as much. There are familiar sounding terms such as "gonne" and "gun", for example, although the words for water, tree and mountain are consistent with local dialects. Their mythology appears to centre around a tall, blue-eyed ancestor, who came long ago from the Old World, and eloped up this mountain with a local woman in order to conceive the eagles who now circle its peak. Your party receive the stories with great interest, and are made to feel very welcome.
802326: Your envoy's approach is based upon an assumption. "Hello!" she exclaims suddenly, "What brings you to these godforsaken hills?" But the villagers cannot understand her. They begin to close in on her.
802328: She is saved, at least. "Feels like we killed one of our own today," says a soldier, in reference to the villager they shot. "Not really..." another replies, "...but it's terrible he had to die nonetheless." Your expedition leaves the mountain pass quickly, so the pale and mysterious community can mourn this violation.
802329: The enemy take the high ground, their guns and projectiles proving rather effective for them. They rush their hostage to the neck of the pass, and up onto a large rocky outcrop. It's the perfect cover from which to assault your party, exposed as they are on the bald crest of a slope. Men are dying — it's hopeless to remain. Later, when imagining the fate of the poor diplomat, the survivors cannot help but remember the stone head they saw, and the human limb in its jaws.
802332: It's a dreadful feeling. Scrambling down the mountain, your expedition hears a sudden and piercing scream. "You never know, she might yet survive," someone remarks — but later, as they are imagining the fate of the poor diplomat, your survivors cannot help but remember the giant stone head they saw at the foot of the mountain, and the human limb in its jaws.
802334: It is an opportune moment that your expedition chooses, skirting around and rejoining the mountain track further up. Aside from what is most likely to be some distant Old World heritage, there is nothing especially remarkable about the daily business of this tribe, except that they are far too focused on the collection of honeycomb from a very tall tree to notice you.
802336: Not too clever. Fearing exposure up on the slopes, your men opt to tiptoe through the village. Perhaps they just smell too delicious, because the pallid, hungry-looking villagers emerge from their dwellings as one, equipped with all sorts of sharp-looking implements...
802338: Your diplomat finds common ground, although not what you might expect. It just so happens that these people are about to tuck in to a feast of human remains. Your diplomat reassures the expedition, "It is their practice to eat their loved ones when they die. Rather beautiful when you think about it." Nevertheless, your crew are rather pleased not to have to partake, and continue on their way.
802339: Your diplomat fails to control her nerves. She breaks down whimpering, and one of your manly men muscles in front of her. "Now listen here!" he bellows, "get back you fiends! Get back or I'll cut you down!" Yet, pale and uncomprehending, still they come. Your brute wavers, and looks as if he's seen a ghost. He turns and runs down the mountain with the others. It will be a hard road on from here.
802341: Where discretion fails, force prevails. Your crew are unfazed by the singular appearance of the villagers, and spring into action. Their villagers expressions remain resolute, even as they flee up the mountain to take refuge with the condors. But there is sadness behind those eyes: this isn't fair. Your men loot the village.
802342: Many amongst your expedition will be eaten, or so your survivors believe. They should have fought as if their lives depended on it, but the ferocity and ingenuity with which the mountain ghosts took them was a great shock. The question as to the provenance of the local people has only become cloudier, but those who fled the mountain will not forget them any time soon.
802343: Your explorers find themselves surrounded. Those leading the group have their heads so buried in their maps, they fail to notice they've blundered right through a village. The villagers are oddly tall and pale, with blue eyes and blonde hair. They look hungry, and are equipped with all sorts of sharp-looking implements...
802347: A shortcut may have been ignored, but fair progress is made regardless. Declining the invitation to enter the territory of whomever made that gruesome stone carving, your crew feel a sense of relief, despite the extra effort the alternative route will demand of them. Along the way, your officers surmise that transgressing into the territory of the local people is seldom necessary, or desirable.
802348: Avoiding the tracks means getting lost, the steep contour of the valley overwhelming what limited grasp of the geography your explorers have. They emerge a week of aimless wandering later, devoured not by the cannibals rumoured to inhabit these parts, but by the mosquitoes and leeches so at home near the flooded river.
802352: The faded ink... The gold leaf... Could this map lead to El Doodah? It fluttered into the hands of your sailors, who believe it to be the most bona fide clue in centuries as to the location of the city of gold. They're already dreaming of the hulking neckchains they'll find, and how well they'll set off their earrings. Why, even the captain has suggested hiring a guide! Yet the greedy have come this way before, and it never seems to end well...
802354: El Doodah, you say? Yes, I know something about it...
802356: He has been searching for the Mesoan city his whole life, and the intensity with which he examines the map suggests he is on the verge of a breakthrough. "Further west than I've ever been," he looks to the forest "but there's no reason it couldn't lie beyond Lake Guavatita". A few days' hike up the river basin and Lake Guavatita shows herself, just like the jagged dagger of water on your map. Beside a high waterfall, your guide shows you a stone marked with Mesoan glyphs. "This marks the end of the trail," he says.
802358: Looks like you're on your own. The guide scoffs at your valuation of his services. "Everyone from here to Porto Tristeza will hear what a greedy bunch of conquistador pigs you are!"
802361: The trail ends at a stone covered in glyphs. Following the confluence of high waters, as they weave in and out of one another, you arrive several days later at the lake marked on the faded map. A keen-eyed young whippersnapper notices some unmarked stones have been placed at regular intervals, which culminate at a waterfall, besides a stone whose inscription must have been made long ago.
802363: You strike gold! Metaphorically, at least. Your anthropologist reads from the glyphs, and scampers off yelling, "The fourth rain god! It means North!" When the archaeologist wades back through the small lagoon, they have a big smile on their face, having found a hoard that's of far greater archaeological value than its financial worth! This may not be the city of El Doodah, but it's remarkable enough!
802365: A secret passage! In a nearby rock face you find a gap, scarcely wide enough to slip through, that might easily have been missed but for the thoroughness of the search. One-by-one, the expedition enters to find themselves in a natural cavern, through which a cool wind whips. A little light reveals a rock fall blocking the way ahead, and crawlways branching in all directions.
802367: What wonders laid bare! A sturdy scaffold is built to support the ceiling, before a human chain clears the debris. The antechamber ahead radiates with shining metals! It is a hoard of far greater archaeological value than its material worth! This may not be the city of El Doodah, but it's quite remarkable enough!
802368: The whole roof seems to give way! Perhaps they should have thought to secure the ceiling first, for as they move a large stone, a primeval bellow comes from above. "Run! RUN!" is the cry, as they all rush out. When the noise subsides, the crew return to discover the passage has been sealed. In any case, some have been injured by the falling debris, and must urgently be taken to a doctor.
802370: Your cavers triumph! The clammy confinement of the narrow tunnels makes them hard to negotiate at first, but your potholers never lose their sense of direction, pushing forward on their tummies until a fresh breeze tingles. "There! A city!" The cavern opens out into an extensive underground ruin, preserved by its clay surrounds. El Doodah or not, there are no doubt some remarkable finds to be made!
802371: Few have any experience of caving. The route they take is clammy and claustrophobic, and seems to be leading nowhere when there's a sudden and awful screeching of bats! A man loses his footing and falls through a gap, breaking his leg. The confined space means his rescue is especially tiresome, and takes several hours to complete — the narrow cave filling with moans whenever anyone so much as grazes the injured leg. You are forced to abandon your search for El Doodah.
802372: "Not so much as a glimmer of this golden city! Not even behind the waterfall," the lieutenant teases, "and besides, these 'glyphs'..." He drops to his haunches and feels the grooves in the stone, "Looks like plain water erosion to me." The captain nods. "Alright men, you heard the lieutenant. Time to give up this fool's errand." Your expedition leaves disappointed.
802373: Divine the meaning of the glyph stone
802374: Praise be, a secret passage! One of the men is unexpectedly knowledgeable on Mesoan theology. "That symbol's in my improving bunk book sir, Cap'n, sir — means god of the underworld." Sure enough, in a nearby rock face, your crew find a gap scarcely wide enough to slip through, and one that might easily have been missed. One-by-one, the expedition enters to find themselves in a natural cavern, through which a cool wind whips. A little light reveals a rock fall blocking the way ahead, and crawlways branching in all directions.
802375: The glyph stone provides no inspiration. "It's a myth! A lie!" Your frustrated lieutenant kicks at it. "Did we expect this golden city to simply descend upon a cloud for us?" The captain sees only one way to dispel the frustration. "Alright men, you heard the lieutenant. Time to give up this fool's errand." Your expedition leaves disappointed.
802377: Your men succumb to their greed. The map must have been a cruel hoax! The worst thing was that it raised their hopes. Some of its landmarks — a high waterfall, a boulder improbably perched — are found to really exist. Beyond that, there's nothing — yet gold fever has already set in. Weeks, months go by before some of your people get a grip of themselves again.
802378: Refuse to believe in a city of gold
802379: Everyone is disappointed. Aside from those in it for the riches, many believe a gilt-edged opportunity to unearth important discoveries has been passed up. After all, that is the whole purpose of expeditions such as this, is it not?
802568: The ship's coffers have been emptied! Your purser knew these new recruits had a wicked air about them... As soon as the ship reached port and the sailors were allowed some rest, the three landsmen merged with the local crowd and disappeared - and with them went weeks of pay! The theft was planned in every minute detail - your sailors have been robbed by professionals.
802572: Their fleeing footprints are easily found. The tracks of the thieves' limping leader stand out in the dust. The grazing light of the setting sun highlights the path for your huntsmen to follow, leading them away from the town and closer to its river, where the tracks disappear into the water. The hills rise sharply on the other side.
802574: Look for a ford to cross on foot
802576: A safe passage! The crew's expertise shines as they rapidly spot a shallow part of the river, and cross it without much inconvenience. They go up the sharp hill of the opposite bank and happen upon a vast enclosed field: a pen for horse breeding. A quick discussion with the owner confirms that the thieves stole several animals mere hours ago. The land beyond is barren and unfit for explorers on foot. Your crew needs horses.
802580: The tamed horses easily catch up with your prey. Your hunters lasso the wild animals and break them, before launching through the barren plains. The blurry hot air parts to reveal the thieves' horses, whose speed is no match for wild ones. Your riders surround them, and the menace of both your numbers, and your drawn pistols soon hushes any resistance. The sailors, satisfied and avenged, retrieve their loot and entrust the scoundrels to the local law.
802581: Your sailors are not made to catch land animals. The hunt ends in failure, the most your crew saw of a wild horse being the weathered tracks on the dry roads. Instead of leading your hunters to a herd, the tracks point them to a run-down town of wooden buildings - several houses and a single saloon - its lanterns brightening with the growing darkness. Night is well on its way, and tracking the thieves seems almost impossible now.
802585: The locals agree to help. Your diplomat carefully raises the subject of thieves with a man of imposing authority, the sheriff in charge of the small town. Their modus operandi is familiar to him: a local gang is famous for sneaking around foreign businessmen, but he never would have imagined they'd be so bold as to rob a ship. If the robbery was today, he says, the thieves are sure to come and celebrate at the saloon tonight.
802587: Wait on the town's balconies, ready for an ambush
802589: A clean job. As soon as the thieves come into sight, your sailors stealthily lay their firearms on the guardrails of the balconies, aiming and firing in rapid succession. The shots resonate through the quiet town: one shot, one permanent sleeper. When the sound and smell of the gunshots settles down, the sheriff salutes your crew's help in getting rid of the local pests, and ensures your sailors that their reputation will be made well known throughout the West.
802590: Rout. Your sailors fire as soon as the gang comes into view, taking little time to aim and even less to observe their targets. The bullets graze past the thieves and upset their horses, who rear and jump before running away, along with their riders. A night drizzle starts falling, and soon drowns the bandits' tracks. Ambitious yet inefficient, that's as far as the crew's efforts can go.
802588: Wait at the saloon, ready for a fight
802591: Honour and wages are retrieved.When the gang slams the saloon's doors open, the place is devoid of its usual chirpy atmosphere. Moonbeams disclose the presence of your crew, sat on every possible chair, table and stair step, and already reaching for their guns. The fight is brief. Your sailors overwhelm the thieves and drag them outside, bound and gagged. They pause to salute the sheriff for his help, before heading back to the ship with the satisfaction of a job well done.
802592: Your crew are no match for the criminals. When the gang barges into the saloon, the sailors are still arguing over how to handle the fight in such a closed space. The battle is short-lived. Your sailors lack the rough training and ability of their opponents, and can barely fling insults at them, even less punches. The roughed-up crew is thrown outside, and scampers away from the town - very aware of how lucky they are to still be alive.
802586: Your crew are held responsible for the deserters' actions. Instead of probing around to get an idea of the runaways' reputation, your diplomat immediately asks about the thieves. The men are well-known - in the worst way - and the locals are shocked to hear your crew hosted them, regardless of the theft. The sailors are forced to leave when surrounded by stern-looking gunslingers. The track ends here. More than money, your sailors have lost morale.
802584: Avoid trouble and simply give up
802593: So much effort for such a meagre reward. Feeling the pressure of unseen stares, your crew avoids the shady town and backs away to the harbour city and their ship. Better to decide on your own to withdraw than to be forced to, the sailors tell themselves. Frustration nibbles their thoughts as they set sail.
802594: You can choose either to rent, or buy a mount
802597: The horses catch up with your prey in no time! In a flurry of dust and whinnying, the mounts assail the barren plains. The blurry hot air parts to reveal the thieves, perched atop horses that are already exhausted from their mishandling. Your riders surround them, and the menace of your superior numbers, and your drawn pistols, hushes any resistance. The sailors, both satisfied and avenged, retrieve their loot, and entrust the scoundrels to the local law.
802598: Your crew will make do on its own. The price of the withered mares reeks of a scam, and your sailors refuse to pay a single pound for the animals. Their observations might be influenced by the light weight of their purses.
802577: Your crew find no guarantee of safe crossing. The sailors quickly get tired of the senseless search: the river's depth cannot be appraised by their untrained eyes, and each segment of the water seems both deep and shallow at once. The crew are too reluctant to try their luck, and abandon their search, disgruntled.
802575: Create a raft to cross the river
802599: A safe passage! The raft is basic but sturdy, and it crosses the river without losing so much as a plank. The crew board the opposite bank safely, and climb the hill that rises beyond it. On the other side, they happen upon a vast enclosed field: a pen for horse breeding. A quick discussion with the owner confirms that the thieves stole several animals mere hours ago. The land beyond is barren and unfit for explorers on foot. Your crew need horses.
802600: The raft can't even float. Your sailors bind logs and dead branches together with sturdy knots, but with little actual knowledge of how to assemble a raft. The raft's apparent stability tricks the builders into climbing on to it, and it swirls over the river, wobbling under the weight of sailors and the pressure of the current, before breaking and diving straight into the icy waters below. Few sailors can be rescued from the wreckage.
802573: No tracks are found. The bustling harbour and the late evening conspire to hide the thieves' tracks. Your sailors aren't skilled enough to pick up the faint trail inside the town itself, but they might have better luck around the outskirts.
802603: Finally, tracks to follow! Amidst the numerous footprints left by your sailors, your best huntsmen manage to find the dotted lines left in the dust by the fleeing thieves. There's no mistaking the bent pattern of their limping leader. The prints waddle to the nearest river, where they fade into the water.
802604: Isn't this humiliation enough? Your crew keeps foraging through the outskirts of the town, but they still cannot find any tracks.
802605: Your purser protests, but the decision is final. Going after the thieves, in a territory they seem to know by heart, while the crew itself is in foreign territory? It's a risk you're not willing to take. As the ship sails away from the harbour and the villains it hosts, your sailors mourn the plundered funds.
802606: Your purser protests, but the decision is final. Going after the thieves, in a territory they seem to know by heart, while the crew itself is in foreign territory? It's a risk you're not willing to take. As the ship sails away from the harbour and the villains it hosts, your sailors mourn the plundered funds.
800228: The man spasms, eyes rolling, before finally falling unconscious. His mania had come suddenly, with eight men needed to pacify, and bind him to the mast. Some say he is possessed by daemons and must be done rid of. The officers, less credulous, seek a surer explanation. The only way to silence a worsening quarrel, is to find a solution.
800229: Enlist the aid of the hypnotist
800234: The crew are delighted the man has returned to his normal self. The hypnotist used a pendulum to induce him into deep sleep, before imparting subliminally, some choice words. Within days the fellow is happily back at work. All are buoyant that such a severe case was so artfully cured!
800230: Examine the cause of this wildness in him
800235: It is a superb recovery in the circumstances. The examination uncovers a bluish contusion under the hair. 'We are to act swiftly or he shall die!' says the doctor, as he bores a drill into the man's cranium. Once the blood is drained, the resultant hole is covered with a silver coin, and the head beswaddled with bandages. The man is fully recovered within a few days, and the crew greatly impressed by the actions of the doctor.
800236: The whole examination takes too long, 'though a bluish contusion is found under the hair. 'I must act or he shall soon die!' gulps the doctor, but then proceeds to faff nervously through a medicine bag, until the poor man dies on the operating table. 'You did the best you could,' a colleague offers, but there is a hollowness to it.
