800237: The patient grabs the doctor's head and smashes it against the table. The doctor was tapping his knee to check reflex, when the devil cut loose. 'He wants putting out of his misery,' a sailor cries, once the man is wrestled to the deck again. So they cut his throat. Attention turns to the doctor, but he is a doctor no more. Injury has rendered him insensible; an eight-year-old boy trapped in the body of a man!
800238: Hellish horror ensues, as the doctor insists on checking if 'ought is stuck in the throat'. As he prises open the lion's jaws, the daemon creature lurches up into his throat. So frenzied is this vampiric assault, that there is little the crew can do but to raise their pistols to the gruesomeness. When the gunsmoke clears, doctor and patient lie dead, entwined and contorted beneath a bloody dew.
800231: Try to calm the crew, and pray the man recovers
800239: The crew are convinced by the chaplain that god has a plan for this man. They agree to bind him to his bed while the chaplain prays for his fast recovery. After two weeks he still suffers gaps in his memory, and a paralysis of the face, but thanks are given to the lord above that he is otherwise his usual self.
800240: The sailors are partially convinced there is a spiritual explanation for his deranged behaviour, but insist on chaining him to his bed. 'He must have done something terrible in the eyes of God,' they say. Despite all hope for his fast recovery, he dies not two days later, his malady forever a mystery.
800241: The faithless crew will not trust this to God, but can neither agree if the possessed man should be thrown to sea, as desired by the sailors, or permitted a chance to see out his ordeal, as demanded by the officers.
800242: Side with the officers and warn the sailors to cooperate
800244: The sailors would not dare mutiny, of course, and return to their stations. At first they fear the bed-ridden man will commit some terrible act while they sleep. But they need not have worried, since he dies of the unexplained malady not two days later.
800245: The sailors are outraged and their response is immediate. In greater numbers they overwhelm and restrain the officers, while the sickly subject of their fury is bound and thrown into the deep. Confidence in the leadership of the expedition is undermined and the possibility of further trouble seems never far away.
800243: Convince the officers of the needs of the many
800246: No officer can deny the logic of the argument, yet, when the man is bound and thrown overboard they cannot help but show their grief it is for no fault of his own, and that none had knowledge with which to better help him.
800247: 'It's a bally disgrace! You dishonour a gentleman!' say the officers, as the man is bound and thrown overboard, 'such incompetence shall be reported to the highest authority!' Not only is a man lost, but the expedition brought into disrepute.
800232: Guard him round the clock in his cabin
800248: There was little for the guards to report, bar occasionally 'quelling the mad dog' with liquor. After a fortnight, the poor man recovers with no recollection of anything, and while his hand is partially paralysed, he is still able to perform his usual duties.
800249: The damn guards are found with sacks over their heads. They swear they did not see their attacker, but weakly-tied hands suggest collusion. Of course the patient's bed is vacant, and he seems to be missing, permanently. After that, rumours circulate, and no-one seems to have any trust in anyone else.
800233: Ignore the officers and get rid of him before it's too late
800250: The officers react with disgust to your decision to toss him overboard, and state in no uncertain terms that the whole matter will be reported. But the sailors are quite obviously relieved that his demonic presence has been exorcised.
800664: The crew are beset by insatiable and painful itching! From lieutenants down to pigeon-keepers, they twist and turn in their bunks and cannot sleep. It is affecting their capacity to carry out the most basic duties, something must be done!
800669: Washing a splendid idea at sea? Who knew?! The itching is very soon forgotten, as the sailors cavort through rainbows of expurgating bubbles. The rich perfume below deck is a welcome reminder of family and bygone days.
800670: 'Only jellyfish!' says the cultivated doctor cheerfully. 'Our refreshing swim at that cove appears to be the cause. It must have been rife with their larvae!' The crew marvel at the clever diagnosis, and as the itching subsides, bask in the pioneering case-study they have performed for the benefit of humankind.
800671: The red welts seem to perplex the doctor. 'There is evidence of the parasitic,' he splutters as he peers through his magnifying glass, 'but then it could be nothing at all!'
800673: Examine the cabins for some sort of parasite
800675: There are bedbugs everywhere! There must be something that can be done to exterminate these disc-bodied hangers-on!
800679: The matter is craftily 'put-to-bed'. Despite the time-consuming upheaval, the crew are surprised to have their cabins so well refurbished. 'They're too soft on us,' says a jolly cove inspecting the new bunks, but my britches haven't itched all day.'
800680: What dreary decor!' says the Lieutenant tartly. Matters deteriorate when some ill-fashioned bunks collapse. 'I'd rather have the itching back,' says an exhausted-looking sailor. Like others, he has to sleep out on the hard decking, until some competent craftsmen can come aboard.
800681: It is a job half-done. For most the problem goes away, but some must live with the itching. Wherever the bugs' nasty little hidey-hole is, it must still reel with lousy punters, each telling stories of the sailor blood they drained the night before.
800676: They cannot see the wood for the trees! Evidence of fleas would be everywhere to the right pair of eyes. Two weeks pass, and murine typhus breaks out. Rashes, fever and vomiting grip the fleas' hosts, who are never able to find the cause of their itching agony.
800674: Have the afflicted bathe in holy water
800682: The priest's most divine bottle does the trick. 'This water is indeed holy!' he says, as the fearsome muscovite vodka from 1791 is uncorked and slapped over the itches of the queuing sailors. 'Shame to use it like this, but I'd rather sleep,' he cackles.
800683: 'Is nothing sacred anymore?' Says the priest, who turns up his nose at the suggestion of using his water for something so humdrum. 'The lord hath bigger fish to fry,' he says pointedly. As well as the vile and incessant itching, the crew now have a parsimonious priest to contend with.
800672: The doctor is a demented quack. When the condition is established correctly as crusted scabies - contagious, but hardly dangerous - the doctor's experiment is for the affected to bathe in an acid solution. Needless to say, his victims do not survive their injuries. When the expedition returns, it is entirely possible he may be stripped of his profession.
800667: Find somewhere to stop and be rid of it
800684: Sand and sun is a panacea! An acute sense of direction leads the ship to an island paradise. A freshwater lagoon relieves the itching, and the much-needed relaxation will stand all in good stead for the journey ahead.
800685: Bringing contagion to port might be a bad idea. The itching is at its worst by the time the expedition reaches the bustling alien seaport, something the local authorities don't fail to notice. The harbour-master's tug escorts you to quarantine. How do you escape?
800687: Lie that the sickness isn't contagious
800690: The lie works like a charm. A doctor promptly comes aboard to confirm this hypothesis. Although she sternly points out the condition is contagious after all, she also recognises it to be a mild complaint. 'Crabs,' the translator says, face flushing. The crew are too relieved to feel embarrassed.
800692: It is obvious you are lying, and the authorities are not impressed. They allow several days to pass, without any word on your ship's release, adversely affecting the morale of your crew.
800688: Threaten them into letting you go
800693: They don't want any trouble. A doctor comes aboard ship and goes nervously about his business. Although the atmosphere is somewhat cagey, medicines for your crew's skin conditions are provided, and the expedition can continue on its way.
800694: You underestimate them. Two surprise warships hove round the landspit and close in to firing range. There is no choice but to run. As your ship crashes wildly out between jetties, the escort ship pincers, and opens fire. The effect is catastrophic. Your modest vessel flees in tatters, and many good sailors are dead or wounded. For the rest, the itching is set to continue.
800695: It's a long time before the authorities deal with you, with bureaucracy seemingly a way of life here. When you finally have access to a medical professional, there is already a post-mortem to be conducted. It appears chemicals leeched into the water supply and caused the rashes and sickness. With the water changed, the others recover, but it cannot redeem the loss of a life.
800686: It's impossible for your aimless navigators to concentrate. The expedition fidgets wildly off course, with no land in sight. Meanwhile the assassin bugs continue to spread their dreadful disease. Even they'd probably make better navigators! Then there wouldn't have to be quite so much death!
800668: Let them itch, it's common at sea
800696: It is a particularly awful itch however. The disgusting lice infesting the ship, and discomfort thereof has many questioning the worth of your expedition. There is only so much scratching a crew can take before they lose all appetite for the journey ahead.
800877: These parasites must have come from the marsh goo; all that waist-high wading. Now they nestle deep in your crew, who, at risk of harm from their own madcap cures, really need professional help!
800881: A delectable disinfectant! The suffering take immense pleasure scouring themselves in a whacking great tub of the stuff. Indeed, so diverting is this new form of alcohol absorption, that even those without parasites take turns.
800882: The doctor concocts a panacea, which not only purges the belly-dwelling roundworm, but more besides. Garlic, wormwood, and lemon quietly see off a myriad other complaints of your spoon-dodging sailors.
800883: The doctors disagree. 'Madam! Bloodletting gives our patients only a fifty-fifty chance!' says one. 'Sir, tinctures are seldom beneficial OR effective on parasites!' says the other.
800884: It does go away, eventually. 'My arm looked like a wormcake for a while,' one sailor laments, 'but that little smattering of holes filled-up with pus now - signs my body is winning the war.'
800885: Mass amputation for all?! The festering parasites have gnawed their way to bone! Limbs must be chopped, or else their bodies shall rattle with bemaggoted cavities!
800889: A fine placebo. As if by magic, the intestinal worms lose the will to go on. The doctor freely admits this is more likely down to positive patient attitude, than his revolting tincture.
800890: The unpleasant medicine doesn't help. Constant trips to the privy are now the only release for your bug-ridden crew. The doctor admits to the failure of the tincture, but thankfully has something for diarrhoea.
800891: The tincture is poison! Having seen their first shipmate choke on his dose, the rest decide they'd rather live with a six-foot tapeworm in their bellies.
800892: Somehow it works, and the patients are rid of the parasite. The doctor seems unsurprised, 'human physiology may be complex, but treatment need not be.' A pretty vague case summary, but who cares?!
800893: Perfect preparation for amputation! At least that's what your crazed doctor would have you believe. Once her macabre experiment is concluded there is surely only one course of action for the afflicted...the crew are aghast.
800894: It does go away, eventually. 'My arm looked like a wormcake for a while,' one sailor laments, 'but that little smattering of holes filled-up with pus now - signs my body is winning the war.'
800895: Mass amputation for all?! The festering parasites have gnawed their way to bone! Limbs must be chopped, or else their bodies shall rattle with bemaggoted cavities!
800901: As good as could be expected. Out with parasites, in with polished peg legs and helpful hook-hands. The crew look not nearly as enthusiastic as you might think however.
800902: Extraordinary that you trusted that quack! She is sideshow surgeon, carving up her victims with the zeal of a ripper, and the accuracy of a pissing schoolboy. At least the screams will die away soon enough...
800903: Nothing can save them. Though a mercy that they may choose their manner of death - unmolested by the ship's quack - it is death nonetheless. The parasite has sucked the life from your expedition.
802084: Sailor under the mast! Weeks of harsh weather have taken their toll on the ship, and the violent gusts of wind this morning have toppled the mizzenmast. For a moment, the ropes tying it to the other masts hold it in place, but there's only so much weight they can take: they break with a snap, letting the mizzenmast plummet on the deck. A sailor now wails, his leg caught under a pole twice his size.
802085: Cover the leg with a mix of soap and water, and pull it away
802088: The sailor is easily pulled from under the mast. The foamy water allows the crushed leg to slither away from the debris, and the limb emerges covered in rainbow bubbles and bloody splinters. The man will live - and maybe, with a miracle or two, his leg will mend.
802086: Cut the leg with a bone saw
802089: An extreme but commendable choice. The sailor is given rum to drink and a cloth to bite before he is held in place, and his leg bound with a tight tourniquet. The doctor's labour is gruesome, and the man can feel the grinding cuts as they tear through him, and he screams through the cloth as he howls and he roars - and yet the doctor stays composed and focused. When the leg is finally cut and the sailor dragged away, the crew feels reassured that they are in capable hands.
802090: Butchery. The doctor's hands tremble more than his victim does, and the saw draws zigzags through his patient's flesh, each cut unable to connect with the previous ones. The trapped sailor's screams become whimpers, then silence. The doctor has to be stopped before he can ruin any more of the unfortunate corpse, and his blood-clad figure sends a warning to whoever might need his help in future.
802087: Lift the mast with a makeshift lever
802091: The man is freed. Using one of the partners broken by the mast, the crew fits sturdy pieces of timber between the deck and the fallen mast, adding plank after plank in the opening, before gradually raising the mast with ropes and pulleys tied to the mainmast. They manage to lift the mast long enough to free the sailor, and the doctor immediately tends to his crushed leg.
802092: The vague idea of a lever never becomes real. The sailors try to lift the mizzenmast by rolling logs underneath, but the huge wooden pole is far too heavy for its rolling movements to be controlled. The mast lurches forward and rolls from the sailor's leg to his chest, pushing his insides out. The view stays with the sailors for days before they can finally reach a decent harbour, get rid of the broken mast, and clean up the grisly mess underneath.
802711: Castaways request your help, but where could they be? Shark-baiting is a common distraction for your sailors, but their latest catch provided much more entertainment than expected. In its belly was a bottle, and in the bottle were three sheets of paper, each a copy of the same message in different languages. Piecing together the documents to make up for their weathered content, the crew can make out a call for help and a latitude, but nothing more.
802712: Examine the entrails of the shark for clues
802715: The stomach of the shark reveals its travels. Glittering corals, exotic scales, and characteristic fish bones - your doctors finish their inspection of the shark's entrails and confirm your destination: to the Southern coral barriers! When the ship reaches the correct latitude, several islands litter the horizon. The crew hesitates to come any closer. The water is shallower than usual, and filled with sharp coral reefs.
802718: Navigate closer to the islands and their reefs
802720: Your ship avoids the deadly reefs and finds the castaways! The vessel groans as it swims through the clear waters, the deepest corals reflecting its shadow as it narrowly avoids them. It takes a short while to find the castaways, entrenched among the dunes of a secluded beach, sprouting from it with squeals of joy and disbelief. Their captain offers his unalienable loyalty, and your crew gladly welcomes the newcomers.
802721: The ship cannot pass the underwater barrier. Despite your navigator's efforts, the ship bumps against the coral reef - the manoeuvre is too complex and too risky for her. The crew are forced to turn their backs on the paradisiacal islands. Whether the castaways were real, and whether they were indeed stranded here, they will never know.
802719: Stay away and have the look-out search for castaways
802722: Found them! Your look-out shows their brilliance when they spot the thin smoke line of a campfire in the distance. A dinghy is sent to retrieve the castaways, and comes back filled to the brim with men with overgrown beards, torn clothes, and awed expressions. Their captain pledges himself to your crew. Once shaved and washed, the castaways prove themselves to be excellent sailors - and even better companions.
802723: The look-out draws a blank. Scanning the islands from afar is a difficult exercise, made even harder by the lack of experience. The crew soon realises that it will never find anyone from such a distance. Reluctant to risk the ship's integrity over the mere possibility of the castaways' existence, your sailors choose to leave and forget.
802724: The homemade autopsy is a mess. The shark's entrails are cut along with their contents, and spilled over the deck is a nauseous mass of gore and artefacts of unknown origin. The doctor cannot make sense of the anarchy he's created.
802725: Interpret the patterns in the shark's entrails
802727: Relentless faith guides the most deserving. In the spilled guts of the shark, your navigators see the shapes of islands, your doctors see the patterns of life forms, and your boatswain sees the promise of rewards. Driven by an inner force beyond simple greed, the crew sails past coral reefs and insidious currents, and finds the island on which the castaways had been waiting for rescue. Their relief is glorious, and their captain promises to serve your crew!
802728: There is nothing to find but deceit. Your cooper burns some sage among the remains of the shark, and sniffs the lumpy smoke. If forces do talk to him, they might have been beyond what he could handle: he suddenly pounces on the closest sailor, crushing her throat between his hands. Three more fall before his frenzy drives him overboard with an otherworldly scream. The castaways are cursed, and the sailors mourn their comrades for the rest of the trip.
802729: Shark, bottle and messages are thrown overboard. Several sailors protest against the rash decision - they'd have preferred to exhaust all options before giving up, or at least kept the messages to share them at the next harbour. The imagined blame and grief of the castaways haunts them for a while.
802713: Map the islands matching the partial coordinates
802730: The search defines a specific area. Many islands match the latitude, but far fewer could be mapped on an actual shipping route. By deducing where the castaways' ship might have gone, your navigators identify a handful of islands which could host the castaways. After two weeks of smooth sailing, your ship reaches the area: a necklace of islands linked by strands of deadly coral reef.
802731: Your navigator is overwhelmed by the mass of possibilities. Unable to agree on a proper searching method, yet alone define a list of reasonable possibilities, they abandon their task and admit the crew might as well try to work out the contents of the entrails. It's said as a joke, however, some sailors consider the idea.
802714: There's no time to spare for such things
802732: The bottle and its messages are thrown back into the sea. The crew's regrets drift away with the bottle, and the castaways are soon forgotten.
802735: Your chaplain is going overboard with his preaching. Blaming the expedition's mishaps and misfortunes on the supposed heresy of the ship's officers, the man of faith manages to rouse the gradual distrust and anger of the sailors. His preaching is now part of the crew's daily routine. His words find an echo in the mouths of the sailors, and your lieutenants can see their authority slipping away.
802736: Demonstrate that his doubts are fuelled by a mental illness
802739: The man of faith belongs in an asylum. Your doctor interrupts the chaplain's daily sermon and accuses him of megalomania, listing the traits of the madness: desire for attention, a craving for control, and an overwhelming urge to rouse the paranoia of others in order to match one's own. The portrait is a perfect depiction of the chaplain, and, despite their former affection for the man, the sailors agree that he should be sedated with laudanum for the rest of the trip.
802740: The doctor only proves his own paranoia. Your doctor interrupts the chaplain's daily sermon with a loud declaration, stating that the man of faith is, in fact, a soul tormented by a mental illness. With all eyes on him, your doctor utters a list of personal opinions rather than medical facts, and the chaplain welcomes his doubts with benevolence. His influence flourishes, and your lieutenants have to make do with him for the rest of the trip.
802737: Discredit him in a direct confrontation
802741: Your diplomat has a greater way with words. She silently enters the lower deck during the chaplain's daily preaching, and waits in a corner of a room. When the man of faith finally loses his nerve and asks her what she wants, she lists two hours worth of the chaplain's arguments and, without pause, offers counterpoints for each of them. The humiliation is magnificent, and the chaplain's babbling defence convinces the crew of his puerility. They lose interest.
802742: Your diplomat was not ready to face the chaplain. She confronts the preacher before the crew, and flaunts her interpretation of the chaplain's mistakes, stating how wrong he is without taking into account the weeks of argument he'd built with his followers. Her diatribe convinces none but herself, and the chaplain simply remarks that her anger is proof of his being right. Your lieutenants have to make do with his whims for the rest of the trip.
802738: Simply punish him, without taking measures against his ideas
802743: Not the most diplomatic solution, but it works. Trusted sailors interrupt the chaplain during his daily preaching and drag him to the upper deck, where your first mate welcomes the man of faith with a devoted flogging. The display of violence mostly proves the preacher's point, but the menace of the officers' ire is greater than the crew's distrust in them. The trip resumes in a climate of tension.
802800: Behind bars! The prolonged stay of your ship in this harbour is not what you intended. Obscure laws were breached, and your whole crew has found themselves arrested under the pretence that the region's borders, whose nature remains unknown, were not respected. Heavily armed foreigners lead your crew through the sinuous roads of their city and into the local jail; after passing by a row of freshly hanged criminals, the sailors are locked up. Only two guards keep watch, their heads bobbing with fatigue. Are they underestimating your crew?
802804: Just two guards is not enough to contain your science. The doctor brings out a sachet of vials and packets, and produces leathery pouches filled with white powders, some matte, some glittering like sugar. He mixes a bit of this one and a bit of that one, gauging measures with the eye of the seasoned practitioner, then calls to the guards. When the unsuspecting wardens are close enough, the doctor blows the mixture in their face. The men drop dead!
802806: Disguise yourselves as guards and escort the rest of the crew
802808: The escape is flawless. Two of your sailors don the guards' uniforms and drag the rest of the chained crew through the prison. When they are stopped at the exit, they mimic the local accent, briefly explain the liberation, and kick one of the chained sailors for good measure. The legitimate wardens buy the lie! It takes an even greater effort to refrain from laughing before reaching the ship and leaving the port.
802809: An attempt way beyond their ability. Two sailors put on the guards' uniforms and lead the crew through the prison, until some legitimate guards stop them and enquire about the strange cortège. The disguised men's fidgety attitude and suspiciously foreign accent is enough to convince the wardens to check their original cell: the guards' bodies are found, and with them comes the heavy charge of murder. The following day, the trial is held.
802812: Offer to pay a fine, however high it might be
802814: The judges give your captain a stern look
802817: The price is high, but fair. Most of the expedition's budget is squandered in the brutal fine, and though the crew are cleared of their charges, they find themselves forced to ration their supplies for the rest of the trip. The doctor and his accursed ideas are blamed, and the man is turned into a scapegoat: his rations are regularly stolen, damaging his health and abilities - and, worse, the crew blatantly avoid his treatments.
802818: Who would accept such a meager payment? Murder is not a subject to be triffled with, and the foreign court makes its opinion clear: your crew will pay in the hardest way possible. To show they value life more than your sailors, the judges impose a non-lethal punishment, devising a program of forced labour and precise observation to ensure the sailors suffer as much as possible without dying. Months of hell follow before the crew can leave.
802813: Plead that they were just following orders, and have the crew repudiate Her Majesty
802819: That lie is believable, but it doesn't erase your crew's crimes. The foreign judges put aside any idea of the death sentence, and focus instead on finding a punishment befitting the crime. The crew are arranged into a procession, and made to cross the city in chains while chanting the ill-will of their Queen. Their patriotism tainted, the sailors never dare to speak her name again.
802820: Who would believe such an obvious lie? Why would their Queen ask for such a menial task as poisoning overseas guards? To match the crime, the crew's lieutenants are forced to drink hemlock solutions, before being trapped in a single cell with the rest of the crew. The lieutenants gag and wheeze for days in agony, their skin puffing and their muscles stiffening in impossible positions, until their breathing itself is locked into place. Only then are the sailors allowed to leave.
802807: Avoid drawing any attention and sneak outside
802821: The perfect crime! Despite their numbers, your sailors manage to sneak through the prison and into the streets, where they become shadows under the moonless night. Led by your most competent hunters, they creep through the back alleys and back yards, until their obscurity returns them to their ship. Feeling like the protagonists of an adventure novel, and revelling in the sentiment, they leave the harbour in the gliding vessel - all lights off, and no sound made.
802822: They are caught! Your sailors' lack of discretion is awkward, and it's only a matter of minutes before a patrol spots them. Without any prepared disguise or lie, they're instantly arrested - and worse, the bodies of the poisoned guards are found on the way back to their cell. The next morning, they're judged not just for their meager trespassing, but for actual murder.
802805: The doctor showcases his ignorance. He produces a pouch of arsenic before calling the guards. When the jailers are close enough, the doctor is ready to blow the powder in their face - however, his lack of knowledge of the poison's properties backfires. The soft inhalation of the doctor is enough to bring the highly volatile poison to his lips, and he leaps back, coughing and wheezing. The guards immediately understand this was attempted murder.
802823: A nice display of craftsmanship. The crew digs a tunnel with skill, taking care to reinforce the structure and analyse the soil's nature as they progress. They avoid the most friable sections of the city's ground and emerge on the coast, exactly as calculated. Your ship's not too far, but a frigate stands guard. However, its lights are off, and the guards onboard might be sleeping rather than actually keeping watch.
802829: Swift as a whisper. Your sailors embark on the ship and deploy its sails in an excruciatingly slow manner, timing their flapping and clinking with the melody of the backwash. The vessel creaks softly and lets the sea take it, drifting away from the harbour with delicate movements of to and fro. Soon, the city is but a point on the horizon, and the sailors allow themselves to explode in a clamour of celebration.
802831: Ridiculously visible. Your sailors tiptoe past the guarding frigate with their shadows stretching across the whole deck, their stressed whispers ringing through the night. As a testimony to their poor hunting skill, it takes a barrel in their cheeks for them to realize they have been spotted. The next morning, the judges' verdict takes into account the escape attempt and condemns half of your crew to a month of forced labour.
802832: Offer to pay a fine instead
802834: The judges give your captain a stern look
802837: Bribery is a reasonable option. The payment offered satisfies the judges, who agree to let your sailors go. The crew mutter about the absurd trial and its even more absurd resolution, but their relief shows.
802838: Not enough. The judges scoff at your attempt to bribe them with a so-called fine, and advise your crew to try a higher amount next time. To show they're not so cheap, they extend your crew's penalty to two months of forced labour, and place the sailors under the tightest surveillance. The two months are a mixture of menial and unrewarding tasks, and frequent and unwarranted whipping.
802833: Force your crew into complying with the unreasonable demand
802839: The crew comply. Following their superiors' orders, the sailors accept the judges' penalty and fulfil their obligations to the best of their abilities. One month of forced labour seems harsh, though, even for the local population, who supports the crew's effort and vouch for their liberation. The crew earn an early release, and are left tired but touched by the unexpected appreciation.
802840: The crew refuse to comply. The insistence of your first mate cannot convince the sailors to sacrifice themselves for the good of the crew, and the heated debate that follows is cut short by the judges. If your crew cannot decide who to send into forced labour, all of them will go! Forced to submit, the crew invest their strength into one month of meaningless tasks and incessant bickering among themselves.
802828: Bombard the frigate as you leave
802841: An explosive escape! The crew feels whole again aboard their ship, and they now have the tools to face their opponents. The loaded canons fire a volley of precise blasts at the foreign frigate and its harbour, setting the whole coast aflame. Your ship sails away with the blaze in its back, a vision of grandiose might which fills the sailors with pride.
802842: A failed attempt. The sailors lack the skills required to load their cannons under the cover of night. Misguided movements and poor knowledge of the armament makes the canons overflow with powder. When they're fired, the weapons explode and take their gunner with them, offering a loud indication of the escapees' position. The crew are seized and sent back to their cell. At dawn, the judges sentence half the crew to a month of forced labour.
802825: A dead end. The crew can handle basic digging, but their progress is reluctant, slowed by the constant fear of being buried in the makeshift tunnel. At the first obstacle they encounter - a large foundation pillar which blocks the way - the sailors hurriedly agree that there is nothing more that can be done with the tunnel. They return to their cell, relieved.
802826: Buried alive. The sailors have but a vague idea of how to dig an escape tunnel. They grind the earth with their bare hands, the pungent soil getting stuck under their nails and lining their clothes, hair, skin. As air comes to lack, so too does their judgement, and the crew push forward, blind to the crumbling rock. The tunnel collapses in on them, and what few sailors were still outside are judged and released without sentence - the death of their companions is deemed punishment enough.
802803: Prepare your defence for the upcoming trial
802844: An epic trial! At their first chance to speak, your crew engage in an extensive and thrilling retelling of their adventures, captivating the audience and the judges. They climb and rock benches to mimic past naval battles, engage the public by asking them timely and suspenseful questions, and modify their tales according to the audience's whims. Their trespassing is made part of the story, and as they retell the trial itself, the judges insist on letting them go. They leave as heroes!
802849: Your defence doesn't move the judges. The trial follows obscure local laws, and their meandering unravelling goes beyond what your diplomat is used to. Her words stumble upon the judges' traps, and her lack of understanding of the legal subtleties of the situation is obvious to anyone. To the dismay of your crew, the judges' verdict is harsh: one month of public labour for at least half of your sailors.
802851: Your diplomat is beyond awkward. At the trial, she interrupts the judges to insist on meaningless details, pointing out not your crew's innocence, but rather the reasons why their guilt is, to quote her directly, "not that bad". Her lack of professionalism and conviction is irritating, and the judges interrupt the hearing with a hasty judgement just to stop her. Your crew are coerced into one full month of forced labour, a disproportionate and disheartening sentence.
802901: The crevasse swallowed your sailors. Attempting to cross the mountain pass was a risk, and your crew paid the price for their desire to test the odds. The rocky path turned to frozen snow, then to the still body of a glacier, its ominous presence plaguing the air with the smell of winter. Night swelled faster than anticipated, and it didn't take long for the less cautious explorers to discover the frailty of ice mantles.
802902: Build a snow anchor to descend into the crevasse
802905: The snow anchor is a reliable solution. Your explorers rope themselves together, passing a safety line of sturdy hemp around their waists, through the mounds of packed snow, and into the hands of selected athletes. They control the rope as the rescue team expertly climbs down. The fallen sailors are in poor condition, and the feeble light and jagged walls do not hint at an easy rescue.
802907: Bind their broken limbs with splints and help them climb
802909: The best course of action for a most hazardous situation. The splints are not only immobilizing the wounded limbs of the fallen sailors, they're supporting them too, and with the help of their rescuers, they manage to climb to a high enough portion of the ice wall for the others to pull them up. Even the wounded, despite their shaking bodies and frozen injuries, find the strength to join the following cheer.
802910: The splints are torture devices. The splints are well assembled, but the sailors' lack of anatomical knowledge sees them simply binding the splints "wherever", as the wooden aids force the wounded into unnatural movements and postures. When the men are finally pulled up, they're in even more of a dire state than after their fall.
802908: Bind the wounded to the safety rope and pull them up
802913: The men are brought to safety! Your sailors bind the wounded with a clever construction of marine knots, providing support to the fallen sailors while spreading their weight across the safety rope. Pulling them up is so easy, the injured can even spare a laugh while swinging across the ice wall. The successful teamwork has brought your sailors closer together than ever, and it's a group of brothers and sisters which brings the wounded back to the ship.
802914: This will never work. The wounded are bound to the safety rope in the roughest way possible, their injuries pressed against the coarse hemp till the fibres are coloured red. Despite the need to leave quickly, there's no way the men can be pulled up without worsening their state. Your sailors need help. Will the crew still on the ship notice their prolonged absence?
802915: Send scouts in the night to find help
802917: Help at last. Your scouts navigate the night-filled glacier with care, marking their route with etchings in the ice. They bring back sailors and an actual pulley, allowing them to rescue the wounded without causing any more harm. The injured men are in a poor state, and will probably suffer from this trial in the long term, but for now they simply savour their survival.
802918: The rescue team also faces the trials of the glacier. Of the two scouts sent, only one comes back, and with him a team of sailors frozen by their numerous detours and hours spent getting lost in the mountain. The pulley they bring is the perfect solution for rescuing the fallen men. The wounded are many, both among the victims and their rescuers, yet none complain: they are alive, if missing a limb or two.
802916: Camp and hunt for food while waiting for rescue
802919: Sufficient supplies are found. Your hunters are much better at crafting snares than rescue harnesses, and they gather game on a regular enough basis that the team can survive until help finally arrives. The diet of bony rabbits wasn't enough to keep your sailors in perfect health, but a couple weeks of care and proper food should put them back on their feet.
802920: The rescue team finds their comrades famished and wasted. Your hunters couldn't find sufficient game in the unforgiving mountain, and the diet of molten ice aggravated the wounded's condition past what they could humanely endure. The sailors stagger back to the ship, leaving two dead behind.
802906: The snow anchor fails your sailors terribly. For most of your crew, a snow anchor is but a vague concept. The rescuers bind themselves to a frail heap of packed snow, and descend into the crevasse one by one. One, two, three men slide along the walls of ice, their weight pulling on the cracking anchor. When the fourth jumps into the rift, the anchor falls with him, and with it the very edge of the ice - burying the crevasse and sealing it forever.
802903: Look for another way into the crevasse
802921: A way in! Following the glacier and identifying its contours by the bumps and gaps of its snow cape, your sailors find a spot of crunchy and brittle ice which covers the entrance of a steep slope leading into the crevasse. The wounded men lie at the bottom, doing their best to muffle their whimpers of pain.
802926: Carry the wounded up the slope
802930: Up they go! Your sailors are athletes of great physical condition, and the wounded are no exception. They clench their teeth as they're pulled onto their companions' backs and carried up the tricky slope, helping their rescuers by balancing their movements and ignoring their gnawing pain. The morning greets them in a glorious scene of dumbfounded relief.
802931: It works, but at what cost? The wounded are pulled more than they are carried, their rescuers lacking both the physical and mental strength required to treat the injured with the care and delicacy they need. When the last man is pulled from the slope, a gruesome noise announces that parts of him have decided to stay in the tunnel. The body is abandoned as the crew hurries back to the ship, disgruntled.
802922: An alternate entrance is found after a long while. Alternate is a euphemism: the sailors went deep into the entrails of the glacier, and instead of finding a way into the crevasse, they discerned a fault in the thin ice wall. Breaking it allowed them inside, but their delayed arrival, rather than soothing the fallen men, instead triggers their ire: couldn't they have come faster? Don't they see their freezing limbs? Don't they know the fright they caused?
802934: The groggy men are cooperating at last. A just dosage of tranquillisers tones down their panic while keeping them conscious, and the wounded let themselves be guided out of the crevasse and back to the ship. When the drugs and the cold wear off, they realise how oblivious they were to the real extent of their injuries.
802935: Their artificial calm lasts eternally. The dosage of tranquillisers is a bit on the nose, and doesn't even take into account the weakened state of the patients. Their panic calms down at an alarming speed, and their consciousness lapses, followed by a sleep so deep it takes away both their breath, and their heartbeat. At least they died peacefully.
802933: Talk them into a calmer behaviour
802936: They calm down and can finally be rescued. Your sailors are respectful of the wounded's pain and sympathise with them, soothing their angst with empathy and welcomed admiration. The injured stifle their insults and try to live to their companions' expectations, holding their whimpers until they're back on the ship. Their wounds are a nasty sight, but their pride is beaming.
802937: Their panic soars, pushing them to their death. Your sailors try to motivate the wounded through accurate descriptions of their fate, pointing at their darkened limbs and prophesying their coming fall. The injured enter a state of pure terror, screaming continuously and unable to hear themselves, crawling away from the news bearers and deeper into the chasm, until the snow dampens their screams and the sound of their final fall.
802923: The glacier forbids your sailors from finding their way through it. The twisting paths of the frozen structure are too much for the crew, who encountered enough trouble following the main marked glacier route. They're forced to abandon their quest, and must instead go back to the broken mantle and its crevasse. The cold steadily bites and weakens them, and they soon take the same purple tint as the men they are trying to save.
802938: Have the weakened sailors try to pull the others up
802940: Your sailors' best efforts cannot compensate for the loss of time. The crew's physical ability is excellent, but the cold makes no exceptions when it comes to eating flesh. The wounded are pulled up, and the fangs of ice tear their feet and legs away, the crevasse keeping the trophies as fees for the men's freedom. They're brought back to the ship, but can never truly take part in the expedition again.
802941: A terrible initiative. Several sailors slip into the crevasse, pushing and pulling the wounded up the frozen walls at the cost of what little energy they have. Their panting draws lines of mist around them, and their faint clouds of breath thicken, and thicken, and suddenly evaporate. There is no more saving to be done for the injured and their rescuers.
802939: Put the wounded out of their misery before leaving
802942: Heartbreaking. Could they have resolved this in any other way? Your sailors try to ignore the question while they point their guns at their companions, men too frozen now to realize what's about to happen. They die silently, and the absence of protest weighs heavier than any voiced reproach on the would-be rescuers.
802943: They had it coming. This is not your crew's first encounter with the dangers of the wild, yet they persisted in being foolhardy and ignored the basic rules of mountain hiking. Let their fate be a lesson for the other idiots.
803045: This man is severely ill! A group of sailors bang on the door to the doctor's cabin. They carry a feverish friend, who between two moments of altered sleep mutters about a burning radiance and closes his eyes to protect himself from the deck's half-light. The doctor's inspection could reveal more symptoms, but shouldn't the crazed patient be secluded instead?
803046: Inspect the man at the risk of contamination
803048: The symptoms speak for themselves. The man's neck is stiff, his breathing distraught, his cheeks paralysed. As the doctor explains to the rest of the crew the details of meningitis, the lying patient suddenly trembles, taken by a seizure of such intensity that his whole body arches upwards, bent in a pyramidal pose of impossible tension. He screams out the name of your doctor before falling down, dead.
803050: This was the delirium of a dying man
803055: There is no truth but the voice of science. The accusation was the plea of a sick fool. Your doctor knows what ravages meningitis can do to the mind of its victims, and his collected account of symptoms convinces your crew of your doctor's innocence and acute knowledge. He is free to inspect the men on board, and identifies several others who carry the symptoms. The sick are promptly isolated and disembarked at the next harbour, and your expedition emerges unscathed.
803056: The doctor's truth isn't convincing. He fumbles through his explanations, as his limited knowledge of the dead man's illness begins to show. Even if the doctor did seem to correctly identify the ailment, he fails to justify the impressive death the crew just witnessed. Doubts linger as the expedition goes on, and the doctor spends the rest of trip isolated in a quarantine of defiance and distrust.
803051: This was the accusation of a victim
803057: Heavenly truths hide in the last wishes of a man. The doctor is pressed for answers and asked to swear his innocence before the Lord: a feat too great, and a lie to heavy for him to bear. He confesses to having poisoned the sailor with mercury over a dispute of faith against facts - ironically, the doctor's own fear of the Light made him confess his sins. He is hanged, and your crew find relief in the punishment of the murderer.
803058: Isn't this judgement too hasty? The doctor is immediately accused of having murdered the sick sailor, but he isn't enough of a believer to confess before the cross. He is nevertheless hanged for his supposed crimes. Relief tints the mood of your crew, but many know the punishment was hasty and unjust.
803049: Your doctor is at a loss. Fear of the light sounds like an ailment belonging to the realm of the Lord, and the man of science is too blinded by his fright to notice the change in his patient. In a fit of unforeseen anger, the sick man leaps on his healer and attempts to claw his eyes out, before being restrained by the surrounding sailors. What madness is this?
803059: Observe the evolution of the lunatic's symptoms
803061: Rabies, no doubt - confine him! The man's unnatural fury keeps growing under the observation of the doctor, who finally discerns familiar patterns in his patient's behaviour. His massive salivation and rejection of any form of drink leaves little room for doubt: he has rabies. The sailors confine him into the hold without remorse, and wait for the illness to steal his life.
803062: The symptoms culminate in death. The roped patient wriggles, drooling, screeching and screaming for the lights to be gone, until a seizure of astonishing magnitude takes him, leaving his cadaver frozen in an impossible position. The doctor realises, far too late, that he might have been facing a case of rabies. Around him, the crew grow restless: what if this failure of a scientist was still wrong?
803063: Find evidence on the dead man's body
803065: The flesh carries proof. In the thigh of the dead man, your doctor discerns burn marks unlike any other, appended over a festering wound. This is the work of a priest, who applied a heated key of Saint Hubert over the bite of a rabid dog - in the hope, visibly misplaced, that the Saint would cure the ailment. The sailor had known of his fate, but chose to endanger his companions regardless. He deserved death.
803066: Your crew has had enough of the doctor's incapability. The man of science probes the body, tearing its clothes to reveal bruised skin and vulnerable flesh - a sight which convinces the sailors that they have seen the boundaries of his skill. The doctor is seized and roped alongside the cadaver he was desecrating, being left to ponder his calling in the depths of the hull. At the next harbour, your crew grimly realise that the doctor's wrinkled mass will never do harm nor good again.
803064: Find evidence in the dead man's belongings
803067: Undisputable evidence points to a grim story. The inspection of the dead man's belongings lands no result, but your sailors know better than to consider this failure as final. They extend their search to his sleeping quarters, and within the loose planks of an amateurish repair, they find their proof: a key of Saint Hubert, a vital artefact for any believer suspecting the menace of rabies. The sailor knew of his ailment and chose to hide it. This truth pains your crew, but the closure brings relief.
803068: No proof, no trust. Your sailors are no good at sleuthing, especially under pressure, and they find no proof pointing to the nature of the dead man's illness. Suspicion rises as the doctor orders the immediate burial at sea of the cadaver. Long after the cloth-wrapped body was thrown into the sea, the cadaver of the dead man is found hidden in the hull. There is little doubt as to who was thrown overboard in its place.
803060: Confine the madman in the hold
803069: Your sailors will have nothing to do with this lunacy. Sending the sick man to the depths of the hold is a cruel choice, but it lowers the risk of any otherworldly contamination. His howls bedevil the ship until his voice becomes whisper, then silence. His body is buried at sea in a hurried parody of ceremony, as the sailors avoid discussing his unknown illness.
803070: The sick die alone. Afraid of the man's state and the contagion he could potentially spread, your sailors lock him up in an empty cabin. He offers no resistance, and during the following days, his presence is reduced to sporadic whimpers and the occasional monologue. When the voice finally dies out, the sailors carefully wrap his body in cloth and bury him at sea, both relieved and sorry that they let him die a dog's death.
803115: A ship trapped in the floe! While navigating the treacherous Northern seas, your expedition happens upon frozen waters, whose masses spread over the horizon and plant their roots deep below the surface. Their dominion has imprisoned a ship much like yours. Skin parched, voice torn, eyes buried deep in their skulls, the stranded sailors sacrifice their last bits of strength to beg for help.
803080: Scurvy. While inspecting the mouths of the stranded sailors, your doctor's fingers go straight through their gums as if they were made of paper, and the teeth below quit their lodging with a shake and a pull. The ill men admit to having already buried two of their own at sea. More will follow if they do not eat fresh food soon.
803082: Part with a large portion of your supplies
803084: The starved sailors eye your food with envy
803087: Your loss will help their survival, no doubt. The donated supplies are enough for the strangers to hold out until rescue comes. Your crew promises to look for the nearest harbour and call for help there - a promise which they are likely to keep, forced as they will be to resupply in order to avoid their own starvation.
803088: There are not enough supplies for both your crew and theirs. Your sailors stop rummaging through their cargo, and must deny the stranded men their hope of renewed supplies. The poor souls are too weak to vent their anger, but their empty looks and cursing whispers follow your crew long after the ghost ship has been swallowed by the horizon.
803083: Hunt the floe for fresh meat
803089: The icy domain gives a profuse bounty. Your fishermen forsake the idea of exploring the floe, knowing that the local game hides underwater. Adapting to the hostile environment, they catch enough seals to feed the whole crew, and the feast, even if it doesn't miraculously heal the sick, seems to at least replenish their spirit. They encourage your crew to use your ship's cannons to break the ice encasing their ship - despite the risk of damaging their hull.
803094: The ship is freed! Your artillery men take hold of the stranded ship's cannons, ordering the crew to coordinate their frozen artillery with your ship's own firepower. The combined shots from both vessels trace the contours of the ice, breaking it with successive volleys until the floe parts and lets go, much to the appreciation of both crews. One of the sailors who helped fire the icy cannons even offers to join your voyage, having been taken in by your crew's kindness and brilliant skills.
803095: Your shots break the ice, along with their hull. Shooting a cannonball through an exact thickness of ice without going any further requires a degree of control that your artillery man doesn't have. The blast pierces through the floe with a resounding crack, but the splinters projected by the impact are both ice and wood. The stranded sailors are thankful for your help - and the water did cushion most of your cannonball's power - but your crew still feels guilt at seeing their ship hobble away.
803093: Promise to call in help and leave
803096: Your crew promises to send help. They leave the stranded men after telling them of steam-powered icebreakers and expeditions versed in the art of rescuing people such as them, and the tales seem to satisfy their angst. Your sailors hope that the next harbour will indeed provide such saviours.
803090: The hunters can't find enough food. Your sailors manage to track, find and trap a few seals, but the bounty's not enough to feed a whole crew of ailing men. It might be enough for them to hold out until a rescue mission arrives, however - if there were less of them, or if they followed a strict rationing discipline.
803097: Invite as many as you can on board
803099: They are desperate for help, and accept your proposal. Your diplomat pressures the strangers more than she reassures them, and her pragmatic approach to the problem manages to convince them. About a third of the sick embark upon your ship, whereas the remaining sailors huddle together to share the meagre food that was hunted for them. Going back and forth between the closest harbour and the trapped ship drains both your crew and your time, but the rescued men are indefinitely grateful.
803100: Your diplomat cannot convince anyone to stay behind. Rather than depicting the reasons behind your crew's decision, she bluntly announces the number of strangers allowed on board, and sparks an immediate frenzy. The skeletal men rise on trembling legs, their limbs pulled forward by the puppet strings of hunger, rushing into each other until most strings are cut. The culled crew climbs aboard your ship, and their soulless presence plagues the rest of the expedition.
803101: The system is strict, but it allows them to hold their ground. One of your officers, and two of your biggest, most impressive sailors go down below deck on the stranded ship to distribute food portions, and teach the men about the merits and secrets of disciplined rationing. The crew nod their understanding, silent as your ship sails away. Hopefully they will follow your advice, and most will still be alive when a rescue ship comes to their aid.
803102: Your frail discipline falls apart. One of your officers and a handful of escorting sailors order the starved men to ration the meat, lest they suffer from even more famine while your ship goes to look for help. Their lack of presence and conviction has no impact on the sailors, who throw themselves on the supplies and transform into beasts; frail animals who lack the strength to rip each other apart despite their will to do so. Your ship leaves in a hurry, leaving the fools to their madness.
803091: The floe is barren. Unable to catch any game on the frozen ice and the surrounding hills of snow, despite the numerous tracks sprinkling the area, your hunters come back empty-handed and ashamed. The stranded sailors appreciate the effort, but their eyes grow duller still. They're still desperate for any kind of help.
803081: The unknown illness might attack your crew. Your doctor cannot pierce the mystery of the strangers' ailment: their ghost-like bodies fascinate as much as they terrify. Too scared to properly inspect their cadaverous skin, he hurriedly affirms that any sort of prolonged contact with them would put your own sailors in danger. Your ship whisks your crew away from the imaginary threat, leaving the strangers to die.
803077: Break the floe with your cannons
803103: A job carried out with few hitches. Making sure that they don't damage the ship itself, your sailors fire cannonball after cannonball, taking the time to appraise and readjust their aim with each new shot. The ship's hull is grazed by the first shots, and soon the floe parts before the vessel, the ice blocks gliding against each other with menacing cracks. The trapped crew profusely thank yours! Your sailors revel in their selfless act, trying to ignore the emaciated faces and feeble voices.
803104: A reckless failure. Your sailors have no notion of subtlety, and even less understanding of their own firepower. The very first cannonball crashes straight through the ice, shooting beneath the waves and into the trapped hull below. Frozen foam explodes and stains the floe with streaks of grey, which all point at the gaping hole in the wooden frame. The stranded crew tremble back and forth to secure the leak, and refuse any more help.
803107: Can we spare enough supplies for them?
803110: The best that could have been done. The strangers accept your sailors' offer with reluctance, eyeing the leakage they caused more than the food that they offer. The compensation is enough to put your own crew in need of rationing, but it does not absolve their mistakes. Your ship leaves with promises to call for help at the next harbour, eager to leave the judging stares.
803111: The situation turns as bad as it could get. Enraged by your retraction, the stranded crew flings resounding insults at your crew, followed by splinters from the broken hull, then the crates they'd prepared to store your offering, and finally, actual men. Fuelled by their ire and moving despite their cadaverous state, the assailants fire at will, oblivious to the retort of your crew. When the wraiths finally give in to death, your officers start to count the bodies.
803106: They can take care of themselves, leave
803112: Your crew leave the stranded men to fend for themselves. There's no mistaking the leak for a negligible issue: if the skeletal state of the sailors is any indication, they'll never have the strength to fix their ship. Allowing them to keep their pride might have been the granting of a last wish.
803113: The strangers are left to their grim fate. One of your sailors crystallises your crew's fears by signing himself as the trapped ship disappears into the distance. The wraiths onboard were so close to death, they had already taken its guise.
800172: 'I do hope you've nothing to hide?' smirks the Royal Inspector, as his soldiers help him aboard from the row boat. Sailors twitch. Your ship is certain to contravene her majesty's law, since it has encroached into demilitarised waters.
800177: 'Very good', grimaces the Royal Inspector, scarcely concealing his displeasure at having to let you off the hook. His remonstrations with his soldiers as he wobbles aboard the row boat are a great source of amusement for the crew in days to come.
800178: The Inspector's lip wobbles. 'I beg you,' he says, 'I have a gift, if only you will spare us.' Sure enough, the gift is brought aboard as promised. But it is only once the Inspector and his soldiers are gone, that it feels safe enough to inspect the new acquisition.
800179: The Inspector's face pales as he eyes the tigerish crew. He bows, and takes a half-step backward - a signal for his soldiers to disembark with him. Once gone, the crew breathe a great sigh of relief, knowing it to have been a close shave.
800180: 'This is far from over!' the Inspector snarls as he evacuates his men to the row boat. Sure enough, back aboard the royal clipper, he is seen making preparations to attack.
800185: Set sail and try to outrun them
800187: Slippery as an eel, steady navigation keeps your ship on the windward side, just out of the Inspector's clutches. After a tense pursuit he is forced to give up, to the crew's great relief.
800188: Though the ungainly clipper is outmanoeuvred, the expedition is now many miles off course, and your ship's exhausted navigators must summon all their remaining stamina to get things back on track.
800189: It's upsetting that the Inspector's clipper is near out of sight, when a hopeful last shot finds its mark, crashing in the main deck of your ship, and killing a luckless sailor. Despite having escaped, the crew are rattled by such ill luck.
800190: Complete confusion among the navigators makes your ship a sitting duck, and the Inspector's clipper gleefully riddles it with cannonfire. Many die or are wounded, and the ship is left in shreds.
800191: The last they expect is a quick counter. Surprised and windless, they're an easy mark. Your cannons flog the Inspector's clipper without reply, and before long, it is bubbling to the depths. The relieved crew scout the flotsam for spoils.
800192: Though the royal clipper has it worse, it also deals significant damage to your ship in the chaotic exchange. With casualties and repairs on both sides, the ships agree to part, so that they may lick their wounds.
800193: The speed and power of the royal clipper is impossible to match despite best efforts. Your ship takes significant damage, and a young sailor is killed by shrapnel. Retreat is the only option. Mercifully the Inspector chooses not to make pursuit.
800194: The superior clipper chews through your ship with its dread bank of cannons - the ruthless Inspector intent on bringing traitors to their knees. 'We surrender!' the crew cry, but the plea falls on deaf ears. Once he has shredded the ship to bits, the smug Inspector turns his clipper about, and disappears into the distance.
800181: There is a commotion and the Inspector's soldiers are already among the crew. Being exceptionally well-drilled, they quickly force the crew to drop their weapons. 'Now,' says the Inspector, 'if you are quite finished, I'd like to continue my inspection of your vessel!'
800195: Allow him to inspect the ship
800197: 'Though this appears to be a trade vessel,' the Inspector says, 'Combat was a consideration when these sails were fashioned - unacceptable in Her Majesty's seas. Unless…' he winks grotesquely, '...we can come to some arrangement?'
800200: 'Load these crates aboard the clipper! What are you waiting for?' he huffs to his men. When they are done, he smirks and offers the merest of bows, before sailing away with the plunder.
800201: 'You will remain here until they are dismantled...' trills the Inspector, '...those perverse modifications to your sails contravening sovereign law of the sea.' As the nit-picking Inspector leaves, it is clear an arduous refit is needed before your expedition will be allowed to continue.
800196: 'This is obviously a military vessel,' the Inspector says, 'in sovereign sea subject to the amnesty.' He toys with the gold button of his greatcoat. 'There will be severe consequences, unless... I hope you don't intend to offer me a bribe?'
800205: 'I don't know what you were thinking, bringing an armed ship into these peaceful waters,' he says, 'but I take great pleasure in imposing upon you. the longest possible route around.' Once the Inspector has gone, the crew look to one another in dismay.
800182: A disastrous melee ensues, in which the crew do not acquit themselves well. Some are skewered, the rest disarmed. The Inspector calls three captive sailors forward. 'Hang these men,' he says, and they are promptly strung from a beam until dead. Your ship, he decrees, must leave sovereign waters and take the long way round.
800184: A disastrous melee ensues, in which the crew do not acquit themselves well. Some are skewered, the rest disarmed. The Inspector picks out the captive specialist. 'Hang this traitor,' he says, and promptly strings them from a beam until dead. Your ship, he decrees, must leave sovereign waters and take the long way round.
800175: Talk him out of the inspection
800206: "Rather excellent company", says the Inspector over a glass of port, "I've been dying for something to break the tedium of the sea." Surprising even his own soldiers, the Inspector demands a gift be brought over from the clipper to mark the occasion. Of course, when he finally leaves, the crew collapse about in relief.
800207: 'Very well,' says the Inspector, after being given the first mate's 'special tour' of nothing in particular. He silently surveys the vessel for a torturous moment, before declaring 'it all seems above board.' Of course, as soon as he and his soldiers have disembarked, the crew of your ship collapse about in grievous relief.
800208: 'Save your breath, windbag,' says the Inspector, with an air of a man accustomed to weaselling. 'Show me the damn ship, or I shall become vexed!'
800209: 'You've talked yourself into very serious trouble,' the Inspector sneers, pointing to three unlucky sailors. 'Hang them,' he says, and they are promptly strung from a beam until dead. Your ship, he decrees, must leave sovereign waters and take the long way round.
800210: 'You've talked yourself into very serious trouble,' the Inspector sneers, and points at your specialist. 'Hang this traitor,' he says, and promptly strings them from a beam until dead. Your ship, he decrees, must leave sovereign waters and take the long way round.
801609: The crew face the bloody customs of foreign lands. After a night of feasting, the sailors believe that meeting the foreign prince and his sea-travelling court is the highlight of their trip. However, morning comes with news of a sudden death among the court, as your crew find themselves immediately accused of murder. The prince demands a trial by combat, and your men are left with little freedom but the choice of the challenge's nature.
801610: Send your strongest fighter for a brawl
801613: What could a lord do against a sea-forged champion? The prince's warrior is nothing more than a scarecrow in shiny armor, and your own cotton-clad fighter scoffs at his tacky opponent. The walking wardrobe is tripped, grabbed, and thrown overboard in a single movement. As per foreign laws, your crew receives compensation and their name is cleared.
801614: No word is brutal enough to describe your opponent. If his plate armor is scaled to match the man inside, then that man is a giant. The human mountain reaches to grab your fighter and crushes his skull like he would an apple. Word of your crew's feebleness and alleged crimes is sent for all cities to know and spread.
801611: Send your best shot for a pistol duel
801615: Your gunslinger shoots faster than his own shadow. His opponent drops to the ground before anyone can see or even understand that a gun has been fired, and only the banging sound and fuming barrel testify to the attack. The prince wonders how lucky your sharpshooter is, then reluctantly graces the crew and presents them with compensation for his offence.
801616: Speed is not in your gunslinger's vocabulary. The prince's duelist, displaying the look of men who fill graves but never dig them, is the sharpest shooter your sailors have ever seen. Your best shot is dead before he even touches the handle of his gun. Judging his passing to be too low a price, the prince randomly selects men among your crew and has them hanged for good measure.
801612: Send your brightest officer for a trial of wits
801617: The foreigners are drawn in by your officer's pace. He inspects the body, noticing knife cuts of varying depths and bleeding. Through methodical questioning, the officer presses the foreigners and reveals the deception: each wound was made by a different hand, the victim was killed by all of them! The prince buys the sailors' silence and they leave wondering what could have motivated the curious murder.
801618: A mute would have pleaded better. The officer engages in a battle of arguments with the prince's vizier, and each of his meager claims are met with factual evidence of their contrary. The prince cuts the exchange with exasperation and has the officer taken to be quartered till torn apart as a final judgement for the supposed crime. No scream ever matches the ones heard that day.
802021: These hoodlums are asking for it. To each harbour its own ill-famed tavern, and this one is no exception. While your crew enjoys a beer at the counter, the tavern's door slams open, the bartender stiffens and the volume of conversations dwindles: the newcomers are regulars of the bad kind. One of the scruffy men elbows your doctor and gasps as the alcohol splashes on his unkempt clothes. He immediately grabs your sailor by the collar, and demands an apology.
802022: They want to fight? Let them come!
802025: Your crew crushes them. The collar-grabbed doctor slaps away the hand of the hoodlum, seizes his sleeve and pulls him over his shoulder, sending him crashing into a table. With a roar, the other thugs pounce on your sailors, who greet them with jabs to the chin and sternum, downing the attackers with no more than two hits per man - the seconds for the pleasure of good fighting form. The tavern applauds the action, and the bartender offers a round to celebrate a well deserved beating.
802026: The crew overestimated themselves. As he calls for the other sailors to help, the doctor gets his head smashed into the counter. His crewmates scream for revenge, and look like toddlers agitating their little arms to try and hit the big bad guys. The thugs are not in the mood to play along, and one of them stabs a bawling sailor in the liver to make them shut up. They slowly die as the thugs depart, leaving the tavern in a stupor.
802023: Offer them a drink to ease the tension
802027: The language of alcohol is universal. The thugs take you up on your offer, and eye the sailors' purses as they pass the money around to pay for the beers. As the first round arrives, one of the hoodlums speaks up and announces that they will have a drinking contest with the crew. The idea is one-sided, and weirdly different from their previous aggressive attitude.
802029: Show them the drinking ability of seafarers
802031: They call that cat piss strong? There's no question regarding who wins the drinking contest: your crew are still standing and enjoying the beers long after the thugs have hit the ground, curled into whatever their stomach rejected. The pungent smell of vomit and cheap ale does not deter the sailors, who casually finish their steins, pay for them, and drag the hoodlums to the closest man of law.
802032: What kind of liquid fire do they make this with? The crew are used to strong drinks and exotic ales, but the tavern's special mixture of bourbon, sugar and Ricard is way past what they can handle. The thugs are accustomed to this local horror and barely wobble, while your sailors pass out one after the other. When they wake up, obviously, their purses are missing.
802030: Drug their drinks to avoid the confrontation
802033: War anaesthetics are remarkably useful against small-time thugs. After a few rounds spent boasting their virile resistance to any kind of liquor, the crew notice the drop in attention of their opponents, and their doctor seizes the opportunity, lacing the incoming mugs with just the right dosage of chloroform. The snoring hoodlums are delivered to the local authorities, who enjoy the unexpected present.
802034: The dosage doesn't put the thugs to sleep: it kills them. The doctor sidles among the thugs, lacing their drinks and snickering in expectation. Soon the effects appear: the gang shows drowsiness, then nausea, before losing control of their movements and tumbling against the counter, their faces taking on a waxy yellow color. The crew can do nothing as the hoodlums break into seizures and foam at the mouth. They win the drinking contest by default, as murderers of their opponents.
802028: Bribing them with alcohol doesn't seem to work. Your crew invites the men to sit and share a beer, on them, to try and bring the tension down. The thug doesn't let go of the doctor, and points at the aligned liquors behind the bartender. A glass of all of these, he says, and a bottle of your best whatever. That's way more than they can drink - and way more than your sailors can afford.
802035: If it's a fight they want, they'll get one
802037: The crew are humiliated. They empty their purses trying to pay for the excessive demands of the thugs. Ale. Stew. Liquors. Meats. When sunrise pushes the hoodlums to leave the tavern, the sailors are stuck with cooking, dishwashing and dust-wiping until the bartender considers their debt paid.
802024: This is a waste of time - simply apologise
802038: Your sailors apologise through gritted teeth. Pleased by their groveling, the thugs don't pester them anymore, yet the heavy stares of the other clients push your crew to leave the tavern. Next time, they'll show them. Next time.
803026: Sails frozen, food rotten, and a ship on the brink of breaking. It's a blizzard! All notion of time and direction has long been lost: a never-ending tempest of snow surrounds the ship, blurring the limits between night and day, or sky and sea. Stalactites have imprisoned your sails, binding them to the masts and making them creak under the unexpected weight. Your crew fear they might break, but should anyone venture outside while violent winds whip the upper deck?
802991: Climb the mast and detach the frozen sails
802993: The ship can safely withstand the blizzard. Several sailors of impressive build climb your masts to unhook and detach the heavy sails, and despite the slippery wood and tightly frozen ropes, they manage to free the masts of the dangerous weight. The barren poles stand tall against the receding storm. Morning light soon pierces the clouds - a good omen to salute your crew's efforts, and accompany their celebration.
802994: The task is far from easy. Your sailors have good strength, and are used to climbing the masts, but they lack either luck or skill when it comes to speed. Before they can reach the foremast, the foresail breaks out of its bounds and flaps wildly against the weakened mast, while the other sails continue to foster stalactites of increasing length and weight. The foremast emits a shrilling sound of protest.
802996: Aim at the ties holding the rogue sail
803011: The rogue sail is taken down! Precise shots take out its ties without so much as scratching the foremast, and the sail is sent to disappear into the storm. The lack of the sail's furious whipping seems to be enough for the mast to hold its ground. When the blizzard recedes, your ship is lacking a sail, but nothing more.
803013: Alas, your mast is not spared. Your sailors shoot at the ties of the foresail, but the task is too meticulous for them: they shoot at the ropes, the poles, and the mast itself. The raging sail is swallowed by the storm, while the foremast collapses and crushes the starboard. In a final irony, the storm soon calms down, letting your crew see how a lack of meddling would have caused less damage.
802997: Fire all guns and shake off the ice
803014: The stalactites are dealt with. In a bold act of defiance towards logic and prudence, your artillery men fire their cannons to send precisely gauged vibrations throughout your ship. The foremast protests but resists, while the pikes of ice parasitising its sails break and rain on the deck in a cacophony of tingling sounds. Your maimed ship has but to wait for the blizzard to run out of breath now.
803015: Reckless, and proportionately paid. Gauging the difference between power which might break the stalactites only, and power which might also break the mast is beyond the understanding of most humans, your artillery men included. The tremor of the cannons shakes the whole ship, provoking the crashing fall of the foremast. Ironically, the blizzard reacts by calming down, leaving the sailors to their broken ship.
802995: A resounding failure. Your sailors clearly don't have the ability to climb the masts, whether in this storm or in clear weather - how could they even be allowed on a ship? As they bicker over their deficiency, the main mast beckons their attention: its base is entirely frozen, and the wood screams against the invading cold.
803016: Strengthen the mast with chains and planks
803020: A straightforward, if rough solution. Planks and poles are erected around the masts, and bound by ropes and chains in the hope that the swaying barricade will prevent the masts from breaking. Despite its movement, the construction is sturdy, and actually accompanies the masts as they move in the wind, giving them a welcome support. When the blizzard leaves, your ship is plucked naked, but its masts still stand.
803021: The trigger of catastrophy. Your sailors tie planks and poles around the masts, pulling chains around them as tightly as they can, oblivious to the carpentry laws that apply to the movement of towering objects. The masts try to break free of their man-made prisons, and soon do, crashing onto the deck one after the other. As if chased by the hysteria below, the blizzard flees, lettings its sunrays fall on the barren carcass of your ship.
803019: Boil seawater to gather ice-melting salt
803022: Somehow, it works. Your sailors take the time to slowly distil seawater in order to avoid improper condensation. The salt is acquired faster than anticipated, and spread over the base of the main mast, forcing the ice back to its liquid form. The blizzard keeps filling the sails until it runs out of breath and recedes, but the furious weather was enough to greatly maim the ship. There will be extensive repairs.
803023: There was no chance of success. To gather salt, your sailors keep away from the wind and bury below the deck to light a fire under a pot of seawater. Their condenser is poorly handled, and causes the water to fall back into the pot, leaving the crew to believe the fire isn't burning hard enough. They fan the flames. Hell rises. The blizzard is fed gusts of murky smoke, and spits it back out before receding, revealing the half-burnt carcass of your ship.
802992: Stay inside and hope the supplies last
803024: Prudence and faith pay off. Your sailors huddle together in the lower deck, resisting the temptation to go check the masts and their frozen sails.
