Time trickles away as the storm recedes, and when the blizzard is no more than a light drizzle, the sun emerges to illuminate your ship. It's perfectly unscathed, and slowly drifts towards the coast, where a harbour is already in sight.
803025: Your sailors' feeble trust is not enough to fuel their patience. The storm lingers, and with each new gust of raging wind the main mast complains and moans, until the distinct sounds of breaking wood resonate through the ship. That's enough waiting! Several sailors rush to the upper deck in the hope of either strengthening or defrosting the mast.
800337: At the cry of 'mines!', all rush to the prow. Sure enough, several of the conical terrors bob seductively below. 'Who knows how many of these infernal machines have passed us by, or yet await us. A false move, and this sea shall be a lake of fire! What the devil do we do?'
800338: Use dynamite to start a chain reaction
800339: 'The way ahead is clear as the eye can see!' says the delighted officer, folding up his telescope. As the last motes of fire trail down into the waves and fizzle, the crew can but admire such brave use of dynamite. 'Better than fireworks!' says another, 'The men have never been so entertained!'
800341: 'We are masters of the sea!' sing the triumphant crew, as the ship weaves easily beyond the last line of mines. 'Even Odysseus, when faced with Scylla and Charybdis, lost men. We have lost none of our company, and our bonds only strengthen!' Soon, a special bottle is being uncorked, and toasts raised to the continued success of the expedition!
800342: 'What was that noise?' gulps the helmsman, but fortunately a metallic scraping is not the prelude to a mighty boom. As the ship is fitfully steered betwixt the mines, hearts palpitate, and sailors wring sweat from their jerseys. When the all clear is finally given, there is not a sailor who fails to offer up a prayer to their goddess.
800343: While at first plain sailing, the minefield is now gooey with danger. A line of densely-packed mines stand between the ship and freedom. "With a makeshift device, we might be able to clear the path ahead," explains the officer, "either that, or we just try our best to weave through it."
800349: 'She survived! It worked!' calls the lookout, as makeshift grapples trailing behind the little dinghy are able to hook the mines aside. Relief only comes, of course, once the expedition ship is clear of this last line of mines. 'How did we get in such a pickle?' says one. 'At least we're out of it,' says another.
800350: A nervous sailor rows towards the line of mines. The makeshift grappling hooks trailing behind his dinghy are intended to drag mines out of the path of the expedition ship. Unfortunately the sailor is a sacrificial goat. A grapple shatters the horns of a nearby mine, and the boat and its sailor explode in plume. Safe passage means nothing to those from whom a good friend was taken.
800351: The idea is a terrible one from the start. The lengthy poles, comprised of other poles, are unwieldy and inaccurate, even in the hands of a several strong men. The crew's attempt to poke mines away when they draw near is suicide. Two booms come in succession, and a few feeble cheers at escape are drowned by the deafening wails. Few are left to bail water, when so many lie dead or injured.
802896: Try to weave through the minefield
802897: "What was that noise?" gulps the helmsman, but fortunately a metallic scraping is not the prelude to a mighty boom. As the ship is fitfully steered betwixt the mines, hearts palpitate, and sailors wring sweat from their jerseys. When the all clear is finally given, there is not a sailor who fails to offer up a prayer to their goddess.
802898: The awfulness has barely begun. Restless waves conceal a thickening of the mines, and the ship's haphazard path makes impact inevitable. "Brace!" comes a scream from port-side, just prior to a shower of men and timber being propelled violently upward. That no further detonations follow is of little relief to a crew who've lost a good many sailors, and sustained such significant damage to their ship.
800344: The awfulness has barely begun. Restless waves conceal a thickening of the mines, and the ship's haphazard path makes impact inevitable. 'Brace!' scream port-side, just prior to a portion of men and timber being propelled violently upward. That no further detonations follow is of little relief to a crew who have lost many good sailors, and sustained such significant damage to their ship.
800352: Go through diplomatic papers in search of any clues
800353: The search is a fruitful one. The well-organised diplomatic library includes a comprehensive folio of papers on nearby mine positions. This enables the navigators to chart a safe course through the waters. The very same paper remarks that the mines were moored during the war, in order to protect a now-disused outpost. You stop by the outpost and pick up anything that looks useful.
800354: The search is worthwhile. After a few hours scouring the diplomatic archives, a paper on nearby mine positions is found. This gives the navigators the difficult task of charting a safe course through the waters. No-one is quite sure if the information given is up-to-the-minute, but when the last line of mines is cleared, all are suitably relieved.
800355: The documents in the ship archives at first seem exact. A map is discovered showing the mine positions. It is only once a course has been plotted, and your ship is sailing at speed on its supposedly safe track, that a magnificent bang has the whole crew scrambling. The speed seemed to soften the mine's devastation, but there is still a nasty hole in the hull. A second glance at the map shows it is rather out-of-date. The reckless blunder has cost no lives, but the significant task of repair greatly wearies the crew.
800356: Optimism makes way for abject terror, as the map of mines that is found and used for navigation turns out to be completely false. Terrible detonations devastate the ship's timbers, and countless lives are lost. 'Misinformation is worse than no information,' an officer laments, as his tears bleed the ink of the erroneous chart, which as it happens, refers to a different stretch of water.
800357: Turn around and try to escape
800358: A few saintly volunteers approach, offering to scout back the way you came and ease your escape. Asked if they aren't afraid of the cone-shaped mines, they reply 'The lord will see us through.'
800361: The volunteers exude calm, as their lone dinghy traces a path much akin to that which got you into this mess. Although their silent vigil transports you to safety, all agree they should never have ended up in a minefield in the first place.
800362: While the path the volunteers cut is a true one, it does not account for the difference in size between the two ships. It only takes a narrow graze to explode one of the mines, and though no lives are lost, the damage to your ship is significant. The crew are dismayed by the situation.
800363: For the godless dinghy, doom seems inevitable the moment it drops and a man slops overboard. This inauspicious beginning foreshadows the disaster to follow. Prayers unheard, steering in the rough current proves impossible. The little boat is last seen careening towards the sinister cones it sought to avoid. 'The terrible loss of life shall remain with me all my days,' says a devastated officer.
800364: It is horrifying that most significant members of the crew are aboard this fragile dinghy. Of course one would not wish a mine to explode any loyal man, but when it bellows up below a collection of your finest, death stings all the more. The crew are understandably devastated at the destruction they have witnessed first-hand. Life feels as if it may never be the same again.
800360: Tell them to stay on the ship
800365: Your faith goes untried in the nervous silence, as the ship escapes the mine trap the same way it entered. All agree they should never have ended up in a minefield in the first place.
800366: Your faith does not go untried. The sinister cones have moved about over time, and no matter how truly the ship follows its original course, it is inevitable a mine will burst into the hull. Luckily when the blast comes, no man dies. Still, the burdensome schedule of repair disheartens the crew.
800367: None of it is of any use. Your godforsaken crew do not realise how the sinister cones move about over time. No matter how true the course, more than one mine shakes the ship's belly as it limps clear. Many lives are lost, and the damage to the ship is severe.
800576: The map of these endless dunes is a swindle. The first officer turns to berate the guide from whom they were purchased, but the fellow is already gone, as if the sands had swallowed him up. A solitary well offers a slight dribble of consolation, but your men must otherwise come to terms with being rather lost.
800577: Use a reflective object to signal help
800581: A local rider comes to the rescue. He saunters over on his camel, and explains the well is part of a lost city, accessible over a small rise. The crew are enchanted by the grand quarry, swept over by the sands of time, observations of which shall no doubt bring them fame on their return. After proof of their remarkable discovery has been gathered, the rider is only too glad to lead the elated crew back to more familiar dunes.
800582: Clear desert nights are perfect for astronomers. Beneath a black cloak lucid with the constellations, your expert navigators school the remainder in mankind's relation to the heavenly bodies. It is a moment of realisation for many. Enlightened, the crew return to the ship filled with the wonder of the desert and their place in the universe.
800583: Something of a path appears, though as much by luck as star-gazing. A little way along it, a silhouette crenellates the night - an imposing fortress. Too tired for trouble, you wonder if it is worth knocking at the grand door.
800586: Ask at the fort for help
800588: The occupant Sultan welcomes you in. He introduces himself in his own tongue, and is impressed by your interpreters. "You are far from what you seek. Stay, replenish for the journey ahead." Thus the crew enjoy the Sultan's hospitality while they can, for it will ease the last stretch of their journey.
800589: You lack the means to communicate. Believing you to be an invasion force, the paranoid Sultan orders hot oil be poured from the ramparts. There is no escaping for one, eaten alive by the molten cascade. Resuming your desert path is the only option. The journey is a wearying lament for a fallen friend, meandering slowly back to civilisation.
800587: Ignore the fort and continue along the path
800590: It is a long and draining journey. Finally the crew limp exhausted into a settlement, from where it will no doubt be possible to procure the appropriate charts. Most would be happy never to see those grumpy old camels ever again.
800584: The "stars are fickle", say your officers by way of excuse. After travelling for a while, the familiar shape of the well appears in the darkness. Your men have been walking in a circle.
800585: The stars utterly perplex your party. With romantic notions dashed, the crew look around for some landmark, but instead find a featureless wasteland. They are desperately lost. Water, food and hope are in increasingly short supply. But even in a desert, there must be a way...
800594: Desperate thanks are due to a dung beetle. As it scuttles along, those less capable in coleopterology cast doubt on the value of pursuing it. There is a minor scuffle in the sand before at last the bloody-nosed experts are listened to. The jolly beetle leads to owl dung, and owls in turn to farmland. Thus the embittered and exhausted crew are saved from desiccation.
800595: A wild goose chase to desolation. Though the ostrich your crew have found cannot fly, it lollops along at surprisingly high speed. They try in vain to follow, but the sun is twice its usual size, and the bird is gone. Hot sand melts soles, and feet begin to swell. The water is out. Those that make it must have some evolutionary adaptation, because for most the desert is to be their graveyard.
800596: Your reprobates have no knowledge of desert mysteries. The divining rod has wasted enough of your time, and your caravan is nearly through the water.
800597: A pretty price for divine mercy. The Y-shaped stick leads all on a meandering path. One insists on stopping to dig, and is left behind. It is a wasted, and fatal effort. After two days of hardship, the rest stumble over a crest to discover the wide blue sea, their mocking ship upon it.
800598: The sun is unspeakably hot. As the bedraggled lumber back to civilisation, there are wiltings among them. It is too much for the others to turn their heads. Bodies slumping to ash and dust, lost to the waves of a powder sea.
800579: Wait for a sign of the true path
800599: Star of wonder, star of light! Your wise magi are stirred by an unusually bright celestial body, that is surely a sign! It foretells a spiritual pilgrimage through the desert leading to a Garden of Eden. A grove of flowing streams, orange and incense, where like-minded devotees congregate. Your crew feel blessed, and the expedition can resume with new-found devotion.
800600: Are the gods testing you? You wait and wait but there is not yet a sign.
800601: The omen is a ravaging howl. "Water in the desert?! it's coming from everywhere!" Already up to their necks in strong current, the weak swimmers flounder like ants in a bathtub. Those that do not drown must wait until morning to look upon the aftermath. "A flood from heaven, to punish the wicked," say the survivors, as they trudge back to civilisation.
800602: You are extremely lucky to survive. The crew whinge and whine the whole way about scattergun strategy. After a day without shade, a fight even breaks out. But sticking to the fixed heading eventually leads, not before time, back to some kind of reality.
800603: Your expedition boils. Further and further it goes, into the desert's incandescent interior. Each soul more and more convinced that redemption is over the next dune. But it is not. Three days later, the party might have felt relief at the sight of a caravan, but instead end up wishing they had died with their comrades.
801643: Your crew attempts the crossing of a vicious strait. Like Odysseus along the coasts of Sicily, they see a subsidiary current running counter to the main flow, its strength so wild it brings fish with deformed eyes and luminescent bellies to the surface. What creatures are not swallowed by this whirlpool end up impaled on the shore's nasty teeth.
801646: Avoid the whirlpool and maneuver to dodge the shore
801648: Odysseus didn't have the ability of your navigators. Through a series of tight maneuvers and expert understanding of the furious currents, they drive the ship between the whirlpool and the shore, using the provided momentum to dash ahead. The moment is as brief as it is intense, and the crew rejoice, laughing like children under the cold droplets of crashing waves.
801649: The maneuver is even more complicated than expected. The ship is driven alongside the whirlpool and flirts with the shore, the racket of the water covering the orders shouted by officers. The current speeds up, inexorably pulling the ship towards the reef.
801651: Spin the ship to take the damage on its flank
801653: A frontal crash is avoided, but it is a crash nonetheless. The whole ship protests against the unnatural movement, its rudder straining against the current and its hull complaining loudly against the maneuver until the impact silences it. The repairs are much lighter than they could have been.
801654: Your navigators cannot control the wild ship. The maneuver sends it spinning and it plunges into the reef prow first. If it weren't for the metal cast protecting the vessel, the crew would have been crushed as well. The repairs, which take place both in the swirling waters and on the knife-like rocks, are excruciating.
801652: Bombard the shore in an attempt to slow the ship
801655: Power faces power in a risky but successful attempt. All cannons are fired in the shore's direction, in a surprisingly efficient effort to slow the ship down. The ship lands on the devastated coast and the hull is barely grated by the remains of the broken stone spears.
801656: What did they expect, attacking nature itself? The massive teeth of stone barely tremble under the cannon's fire, and the recoil is a futile strength against the voracious current. The rock jaw catches the ship and grinds the upper deck, sending several sailors to be served as the strait's daily food.
801650: Fear clouds the navigators' readings. Unable to choose between several possible courses which could all end in disaster, they opt for a stunned silence and let the crew maneuver on their own. The ship crashes on the shore in an explosion of metal and wood which sends a dozen men overboard and straight into the rock fangs of the coast. It is more a wreck than a ship which escapes the deadly strait.
801647: Avoid the shore and hope the whirlpool won't suck the ship in
801657: The sailors' fright gives them wings. The crew reacts to each order with unparalleled speed, too occupied to plead the heavens to think of discussing the risky manoeuvres that are asked of them. When at last the whirlpool is passed, their belief that the Almighty might have his eyes on this ship is stronger than ever.
801658: There are only so many disasters faith can prevent. When they understand that the whirlpool is a monster none should face, the sailors fall to their knees to pray and beg, abandoning what meaningless impact they could have had on the ship's trajectory. Like Circe prophesied to Odysseus, the currents attack the ship, the men, and a hero.
802116: Tremors, ash rain, and an oddly bright night: it's an eruption! The island was too lush and bountiful to be harmless. The lava responsible for the fertile ground creeps from the mouth of the waking volcano, and towards the jungle where a party of your men had erected camp for the night.
802117: Go back to the ship despite the darkness.
802119: The ship is quickly found. The burning lights of the volcano illuminate the jungle, and a handful of seasoned explorers lead the rest of the sailors back to the ship, zigzagging between shadows and fleeing animals. The vessel departs as the island is engulfed by flames, a vision as terrible as it is magnificent.
802120: The sailors are swallowed by the jungle's maze. Dense trees, moving shadows, screeching animals and the crew itself, whose silhouettes are deformed by the scorching heat - too many visions allow panic to spread among the men, who cannot recognise the path, and never make it back to the ship.
802118: Find shelter against the incoming lava
802121: Shelter! The crew finds a decrepit stone chapel, the remains of a colonialist power, and deems it better refuge than their cloth-made tents. An officer estimates that the lava will be on them soon: there's no choice but to spend the night here.
802125: Pray for the chapel to hold
802127: The chapel miraculously stands its ground. Lava rolls against its walls and forks around the white stone, melting its paint and parching its plaster. Nestled on the only facade left untouched by the flow, the chapel's wooden door seems like the most fragile object the sailors have ever seen. When day comes, they are safe and elated, and all kiss the blessed door before leaving.
802128: Their faith is nothing but hypocrisy in need. The crew remembers old prayers from their worshipping days, but the years have eroded both their memory and their beliefs. They can only watch as the lava packs against the chapel's stained glass and breaks through. The spray of molten stone and broken glass scars all of them but kills none: a bite to remind them of their lack of dedication.
802126: Dig trenches in the holy ground
802129: The trenches are dug with military efficiency. Despite the darkness and the imminent danger, the sailors manage to dig deep trenches in no time, and the pits redirect the lava as it flows down the hill. The sailors bunker down in the chapel as the lava runs around the outside, illuminating the stained glass, leaving them to rejoice in the warm comfort of their shelter.
802130: Too much pressure and too little grit. The sailors can dig little more than scattered and knee-deep pits, which have a negligible impact on the lava's course. As the crew scurries inside the chapel, so to does the lava, its smoke burning throats and forever robbing the men of their voices.
802122: Your crew are lost and perplexed. Even your most committed explorers cannot wrap their heads around the complexity of the jungle, which changes with every newly burnt tree. It seems that every path might end in lava-devoured dead ends.
802131: Follow a random animal and trust its instincts
802133: The animals run to the beach, and your crew follows. Tracking down the herd of shrill, squealing, screeching critters could be done with eyes closed, and the sailors are led to the shore where they had beached. The ship departs in a hurry, leaving the animals to die in the ruthless volcano fire.
802134: Your hunters find no pattern in the animals' frenzy. The sailors run in a display of panic and poor judgment, mimicking the animals' desperate behavior. The crew still on the ship can only watch in horror as the island's greatest predator burns all its prey, be they beast or human.
802132: Pick a random path and trust your instincts
802135: Fear is the most reliable instinct. The sailors scamper through the jungle, chasing after their lava-lit shadows. They stumble upon the beach by pure miracle, and hop on the ship with molten tongues on their heels. The ship departs with a slightly charred hull, but a safe crew.
802136: Fear is a treacherous adviser. Seeing that the only unburnt path is up, the sailors climb the jungle's trees in an attempt to escape the lava flow. Ground, then bark, then branches, then humans: everything burns. In the distance, the ship's remaining crew stay transfixed as they witness the volcano island devouring itself.
802139: "They steal your children?" The air hangs heavy around the sailors as their question withers in the hut. Their hosts consider the explorers, half-hopeful, half-guilty from the certitude that non-paying jobs are not the ones your crew enjoys. One child has to be offered with each new moon, an elder explains as she gestures towards the nearby river, or else bandits raid the surrounding settlements. Tomorrow, the bandits' steamboat will come to claim this village's due.
802140: Board the bandits' steamer with your gunboat
802144: Your assault is swift, and without a single casualty. The kidnappers offer no resistance, as their carcass of a craft faces your own fresh-from-the-factory gunboat. They reluctantly lead you to their hideout - a sweatshop with no employees other than the stolen kids. Your crew sets the hideout afire, heads back to the village, and returns the children to their exultant parents. Though they can offer no reward but tears and smiles, your crew basks in the warmth of this priceless payment.
802141: Shadow the kidnappers back to their hideout with a river skiff
802145: Your crew navigates through the mangrove with aplomb. The unusual environment doesn't manage to stop their steady rowing, and the sailors soon reach an outpost marking the entrance of the bandits' camp. Sobbing children are taken from the kidnappers' steamboat, and dragged towards a distant barn. Half a dozen armed men guard the building.
802148: Attack the bandits before they reach the barn
802150: The bandits don't know what hit them. Using the element of surprise to their advantage, your sailors break into the camp and stifle the children's escorts before they can call for help. They hush the kids, and squat behind what few bushes offer protection, monitoring the other bandits. The attack wasn't noticed.
802152: Go all out on the bandits and save the remaining children
802154: The sailors and kids create a breathtaking chaos. The crew shoots and skewers, while the children kick and bite their former oppressors, calling for others to do the same. A deluge of shrieking kids and young adults emerge from the barn and attack the guards, thrilled by your crew's display of strength. The band of unlikely fighters seize the bandits' steamboat, helping themselves to its supplies, before triumphantly returning to the coast.
802155: Audacity does not make up for their lack of numbers. The crew manages to take down five guards before the noise attracts more armed bandits, and the sailors are driven back to their boat before they can liberate any more children. They flee to the village, and share what they've discovered with the villagers, glad to have freed some kids, but all too aware that many more remain captive.
802153: Acknowledge the danger, and leave with the children you've already saved
802156: The decision to run is not a simple one. The sailors recognize how dangerous the assault could be, and retreat to the village along with the few children they've saved. They share what they've discovered with the villagers - and maybe another day, with a subtler approach, more men, and more planning... things could be different. As the ship leaves, the crew focuses more on the good they did, rather than what they could have done.
802151: The sailors are unfit for a swift assault. Their unchoreographed clumsiness and dissonant roars drives their opponents back not because of their strength, but because of the unconventional display. After an instant of bafflement, the kidnappers shout for others to join them, and the whole gang soon surrounds your crew. They part to let their leader, a beast of a man, face the puny intruders.
802159: Your sailors' cause fuels their victory. Driven by their will to save the children, your sailors do not waver in front of the bandits' leader, all muscles and swords with rage in his eyes. It takes six fighters to face the man, piling up on him in a torrent of dust and groans until he finally stops rampaging. Disheartened by this defeat, and their leader's meaningless pride, the remaining kidnappers are brought to their knees, and the children are freed. The crew returns to the village triumphant!
802160: The mastodon tramples your sailors. The rescuers lack resistance, and are wiped out by the bandits' leader, their corpses sent flying among the children who can do nothing but watch in horror. In an ultimate act of hatred, a young girl is sent back to her village to retell the carnage, and warn future intruders against trying to rescue the children again.
802161: No sailor is harmed, no child is saved. The crew manage to run back to the village, avoiding the multiple gunshots fired by the kidnappers. That no sailor was wounded is a miracle, but it's hard to celebrate much when the rescue team failed to rescue a single child.
802149: Hide amongst the trees and wait for nightfall
802162: The crew becomes one with the trees. Unseen and unheard, the sailors bury themselves in the forest, and observe their future targets. An opportunity arises when a group of bandits leave their posts to bathe in the river: splashing and talking, they don't hear your men approach.
802164: Steal their clothes to disguise yourselves as bandits
802166: Your sailors use their disguises to orchestrate the children's escape. Dressed in bandits' rough coats and sashes, the crew infiltrates the barn-turned-sweat-shop, where the children are forced to work. One by one, they lead the kids out of the camp and into their skiff, each child carrying stolen supplies. When the boat finally leaves, the camp is left without fuel, food, or ammunition. It will be some time before the bandits can do any more harm.
802167: The poorly-disguised intruders are identified and given chase. When asked by an actual bandit about their shift, one of your undercover sailors tries to answer: they fumble and bumble until the bandit grabs them and shouts, "intruders!". They make a run for it with the others, leaving both kidnappers and children behind.
802165: Capture the men and use them as hostages
802168: A flawless move, from start to finish. After swiftly capturing the naked bandits, the sailors advance, only to discover the camp's true nature: a child-powered sweatshop. It's soon obvious that the bandits' leader is the only one who doesn't care for the hostages, and the man is forcibly exchanged by his crew in return for the promise that your sailors will never set foot in there again. The rescuers return to the village with children on their shoulders, a culprit to be judged, and goods to be shared.
802169: The naked men overpower your fighters. The element of surprise fails to compensate for your crew's lack of strength, and they're easily repelled by the bathing bandits. Instead of killing them, the kidnappers order the sailors to strip, and send them on their way so everyone can see them for what they are - rescuers who were unable to rescue anyone, and who were humiliated in the process.
802163: The sailors are not attuned to the notion of stealth. They argue about the best place to hide, and end up lining up behind what could be the thinnest trees in the entire forest, their bulging shapes attracting more than a little unwanted attention from the kidnappers. Their leader, more beast than man, advances to inspect the intruders, and laughs at the puny men.
802172: The crew are puny indeed, and they are butchered. The bandits' leader needs no help in fighting your rescuers, who spend more time trying to avoid being hit than actually fighting back. They flee the camp, scatter into the woods, and are hunted down like game. The few sailors who make it back to the coast are so disoriented, they can't even remember the location of the kidnappers' camp, making the deaths of their companions pointless.
802146: The terrain is not one your crew are used to. They get stuck in the mangrove roots, and their swearing can be heard all the way to the coast. When they manage to get free, the bandits' steamboat is waiting, its railings lined with guns.
802173: Bluff and pretend backup is on its way
802176: Your bluff works! The kidnappers have a heated discussion before handing over what few children they have onboard, unnerved by the menace your crew just invented. The sailors retreat to the village and return the children to their families, still amazed by their deception, but upset they could save so few.
802177: They do not buy your bluff. Holding your crew at gunpoint, the bandits casually wait for the reinforcements to show up - but they never arrive. To teach your crew a lesson, the kidnappers grab one of the kids onboard, and cut his tongue before throwing it into your raft: a lesson to you liars. Your sailors withdraw to the village, regretting having only made things worse.
802181: A pricey but worthy trade. Trying to hide their distaste for treating children like goods, your sailors bring the kids onboard. They are in a state of shock, but they look physically sound.
802183: The children are safe with you, punish their abductors
802186: Your retribution is ruthless. The kidnappers are still counting up the goods you bought the children with when the crew attacks, and its assault is brutal. The steamboat is set aflame, and the bandits die by fire or bullet. The crew returns the kids to the safety of their homes, but the children now see them as no different from their captors: beasts, driven by violent instincts.
802187: Your sailors are overpowered. The kidnappers have fought much harder battles against much lesser men, and your crew's attack is dismissed with scorn. The bandits could easily have retrieved the children, but their strange sense of honor makes them consider that goods bought are goods acquired. The crew are sent back to the village with the kids, both looking equally dishevelled and aghast.
802184: The children will be safer with their parents, let the kidnappers leave
802188: A pity to let the culprits escape so easily. The sailors return the children to their respective families, but the kids' joy fails to hide how many more could have been saved given a little extra effort.
802189: You don't meet the bandits' expectations. To teach your crew a lesson, the kidnappers grab one of the kids onboard and cut his thumb, tossing it into your raft: a lesson for the penniless. Your sailors withdraw to the village, regretting having only made things worse.
802190: There's only so much your sailors can do. They back away under the menace of the bandits' guns, doing their best not to trigger an attack, and row back to the coast. The parents of the abducted children thank them for their effort, but their strangled hopes make their voices break. The sailors leave knowing they could have done better.
802147: Rather than bandits, the crew finds their leftovers. The bayou's fog makes for a maze your sailors cannot navigate, causing them to lose their quarry. Disturbingly, while trying to find their bearings, your crew ends up making a discovery more harrowing than they could ever imagine: a pit filled both with torn shoes, and their torn young makers. The image stays with them until they try to describe it to the villagers and break down, unable to depict the young faces and their blank eyes. They leave, disgusted by their inability to end this savagery.
802142: Stay on your ship and open fire when the steamboat appears
802191: A masterful shot! Using one of your precious spiral-muzzled cannons, the crew fires a single shot which pierces straight through the steamboat's engines. The boat gradually stops puffing and drifts to your own ship, where sailors can pick off the bandits, and retrieve the three stolen children.
802194: Scare the kidnappers into revealing the position of their hideout
802197: Your seafarers coerce the river-dwellers into speaking the truth. There is a world of knowledge and pain into your men's eyes, and the bandits are overwhelmed before a single word is spoken. Their hideout is easy prey for your crew, which storms through the den and triumphantly returns the children to their parents, along with the bandits' possessions and supplies.
802198: The intention is there, but not the result. The bandits recognize your sailors for what they are: sharp-shooters, but weaklings when it comes to close-range confrontation. The crew's threats mean nothing to them. Knowing that these men are the only ones who know where the rest of the children are being held, your crew hands them over to the villagers along with the kids they found, and leave with a feeling of defeat.
802196: Enough risks for today: return the children and be on your way
802199: Thoughts of the remaining captives follow your crew. The villagers are thrilled to have the handful of children returned to them and profusely thank their saviors, making the crew's remorse all the worse. The sailors are happy for them, but they know they could have done more.
802192: Poor use of your firepower. The sailors handling the cannons are just as important as the weapons themselves. As your crew aren't quite as well-oiled as the machinery, they fail to adjust the quantity of powder being used, firing the artillery to its maximum range without any kind of aiming. They might as well have lit signal fires. The bandits' boat makes a brutal turn and retreats into the bayou at full speed.
802201: Shadow the kidnappers back to their hideout with a river skiff
802193: Both bandits and captives are killed. The villagers watch in horror as your ship fires its cannons at the small steamboat as soon as it is in sight, annihilating the frail vessel and all life onboard. Mothers and fathers rush to the water, screaming and crying as tiny bodies slowly emerge. If your crew had a greater control over themselves and the ship, maybe they wouldn't have had to bear the weight of these children's deaths.
802143: Ignore the bandits and go on your way
802200: Not all sailors share your lack of compassion. Some men and women refuse to leave, and the officers have no choice but to let them do as they please lest they lose even more of the crew's trust. Many sailors argue that staying to help was the right choice, but the ship has already set sail when they voice their opinion.
802229: A boulder-blocked entrance and a booby-trapped corridor: typical Mesoan temple. After a fall down a slide and a crash into uncharted caves, your team of explorers jokes about the situation in an attempt to forget its deathly aspect. They know what people say of Mesoan mazes: the deeper you go, the shinier it gets.
802230: Follow the suggested route and progress through the traps
802232: The obvious traps are easily evaded. The sailors contort themselves to avoid sharp stones and plated triggers, flowing through the corridor with the ease of seasoned explorers or cutpurses. They quickly reach the pocket of the temple: a vast chasm crossed by a meager bridge with no handrails. Could this be a trial of courage?
802234: You pass the trial! As they wave their arms to keep their balance, your sailors brush against ropes suspended around the bridge, hidden by a clever camouflage of paint and shadow play. They grasp the ropes to steady their footing, and a distant mechanism clicks. A rumbling door opens on the other side of the chasm, revealing the exit - and, on its threshold, a shiny artifact.
802235: Nothing rewards your sailors' recklessness. It's unclear whether the bridge is shaking because of its own frailty, or because of your explorers' quivering legs. Soon the crew are on their knees, creeping across the moldy planks and begging for their mothers. They reach the other side without a scratch, save for their wounded pride, and find a tunnel which leads them outside after some more crawling.
802237: The climb is child's play. Rock walls provide a much steadier footing than wind-flogged masts. The sailors reach the bottom of the chasm, where they find an army of ropes stretching into the darkness above: the entrails of the temple's mechanisms! They find what might have been the Mesoan engineers' entrance, and leave the temple with filled pockets and memories.
802238: The crew aren't as strong as they think. An officer loses her nerve and her grip, slipping down the stone, with a soft thud marking the end of her fall. Smooth slithering sounds hush her desperate cries. The floor is covered in snakes!
802239: Find a way among the snakes
802241: The sailors manage to flee. Too occupied by the convulsing mass of the fallen officer, the reptiles don't notice the furtive crew as they tip toes past them and escape through the first tunnel available. The explorers emerge outside the temple, stunned by their survival.
802242: They cannot read the snakes' behaviour. The sailors progress across the wriggling floor, so focused on their movements that they don't see the mass of snakes backing away from them, and piling against the sole exit. The crew has no choice but to run into the tunnel before it ends up filled with snakes, and several sailors end up as reptile diner.
802240: Scare the snakes away with torches
802243: The crew stand their ground as well as they can. The burning torches are swung before the snakes, forcing them back from the sailors. The officer is pulled to her feet and dragged with the rest of the crew through a windy tunnel, leading them outside, empty-handed, but safe.
802244: What should the snakes be scared of, exactly? Your crew flap the torches around them in a ballet of shaking hands and dripping sweat, but fail to make even one step forward before a young sailor waves his torch past the limits of safety. The snakes leap on your crew, leaving none but a single witness alive.
802245: The challenge demands more coordination than the crew has. Surprised by the brushing elbow of a comrade, a sailor squeals in terror and jumps back, triggering trap after trap of flying arrows, flaming oils, poison sprays. Once the most sensational traps have simmered down, the roof collapses and seals the exit, as sand slowly starts to fall from the walls.
802249: The patterns of the mechanism do not escape your hunters' probing. Upon close and cool-headed inspection, one the sand-spewing hourglass engravings appears to be protruding from the wall. The sailors smash the button, forcing the wall to open and reveal an exit. They flee from the sand, and the temple itself.
802250: If there is a mechanism, the crew cannot find it. Sand keeps pouring into the room, blinding the sailors as it forces its way into their noses and mouths. The explorers utter muted screams. As the sand packs up against the walls, one of them crumbles under the weight and lets the sailors spill outside of the temple: some alive, most dead.
802248: Try and find a weak wall to break
802251: The old wall caves in effortlessly. Following the sand pouring from the cracks, the explorers identify the wall from which most grains seem to be falling. They stave it in, causing a dusty outpour which fills their lungs, before clearing to reveal sunlight. They hasten through the self-made exit, and end up on the beach on which they'd left their ship.
802252: The explorers bang on the walls helplessly. Sand keeps pouring into the room, ricocheting off the sailors, blinding them as it forces its way into their noses and mouth. The crew utters muted screams. As the sand packs up against the walls, one of them crumbles under the weight and lets the sailors spill outside of the temple: some alive, most dead.
802231: Create your own path and push the boulder away
802253: The boulder moves! The combined effort of the crew manages to lift the giant stone out of its socket. As the boulder rolls, a loud snap resonates and the rock bounces back into place. A wall falls behind the sailors and, in a concert of grating dirt and destroyed stone, it starts to advance towards the crew.
802255: Push against the wall to stop it
802257: The ancient wall cannot resist your crew's pressure. They grunt in unison and breathe in rhythm with their effort. One, two. The wall stops in its tracks. One. It shivers. Two. The wall crumbles, revealing a large opening under its railings: the crew finds the body of a less lucky adventurer, one hand clawing at the threshold of a gaping exit, the other gripping an oversized diamond.
802258:
The wall is unfazed by your crew's efforts. As an explorer gets to her knees to pray in the face of her imminent death, she notices an engraving much less elaborate than the temple's decorations: letters that have been scribbled in a language she can actually understand!
"Crawling by day, airborne by night."
Right underneath the scribbling are four buttons depicting animals.
802263: Wrong answer. The brick above the button opens and an arrow flies into the crew, perforating the throat of a sailor, and leaving a red line in the cheek of the button-presser. The floor under the explorers tilts and they roll, a helpless mass of arms and legs which slides along the tunnel before being expelled outside the temple.
802264: Wrong answer. As she presses the button, the sailor feels no resistance, and keeps pushing the carved stone until her full arm is in the wall. She can feel something furry on her skin, a little bit rough, and a bit... She screams! As fangs dig into her flesh, a legion of bats emerge through the newly opened wall - and the only way out is through the bats' nest. The crew emerges from the temple covered in blood, and crippled with a lasting fear of the dark.
802265: Right answer! The sailor hits the butterfly button and celebrates as the wall stops advancing, and bricks whirl into the floor to form a staircase. The crew emerges from the temple, wondering about the intentions of whoever thought to carve such needlessly complicated riddles in their mother tongue.
802266: Wrong answer.As the cockroach is pressed, the insect shivers and shakes the dust off its shell. It's alive! The ceiling opens and a swarm of cockroaches flies into the room, aiming for the sailors' mouths. The crew smash the insects with whatever objects they have at hand, their horror giving them wings of their own, pushing them to climb the walls until they reach the outside.
802267: The unfazed explorers rapidly find an exit. They notice how the floor's cobblestones move to let the advancing wall pass, and wait for the right moment to jump into the space between wall and floor. One by one, they land into the room below, where a large opening to the outside lets in the morning light, revealing a spectacle of spiderwebs surrounding a delicate piece of sculpted mahogany.
802268: The sailors do not find an exit. All stones look alike, and the crew lacks the ability to appraise which rock might be more important than the others. The advancing wall looms ever closer, ready to crush their bones, before suddenly leaning forward and pushing the sailors to the floor, which in turn opens to eject the explorers outside the temple. Yes, they are alive - but the very sight of a stone wall will scare them for years to come.
802254: The boulder doesn't move. Your explorers push, nudge and thrust, but the exit stays sealed. They have no choice but to obey the maze's invitation.
802472: This tempest is beyond anything you have ever faced. The smell of salt is everywhere. The freezing water pierces everyone. The winds and waves hit your ship with impossible violence, making the vessel groan and tremble with each new strike, the air so full of sea-spray one could drown in it. Is there anything mere humans can do in the face of such godlike wrath?
802474: Pray that the usual method will work and reef the sails
802478: Trust in your habits pays. Years of executing the same maneuvers have ingrained them into your crew's instincts. The sailors reef sail after sail despite the poor visibility - they do not need sight, for they are guided by the invisible hand of practice. Only the fore and aft sails are left to flail in the wind to keep a semblance of control over the ship.
802483: The vessel emerges from the storm, unscathed. The barren masts of your ship part the tempest as the crew maneuver its jib sails and the spanker, both ridiculously small pieces of cloth in the face of the storm's fury. Still, the maneuver magnifies the importance of these sails and allows you to masterfully skirt the storm, leaving the curtain of rain just as lightning begins to strike. Entranced, the crew contemplates how they managed to defy such a grand power.
802484: Waiting would have been a better option. Though the force of training helped your crew reef the sails, it doesn't reveal how to navigate the furious tempest. Sailing with nothing but the jib sails and spanker is a feat no one on your ship is capable of. The vessel is tossed about helplessly, until the storm decides to calm down.
802482: Wait for the storm to pass
802543: The storm passes. With the sails reefed to avoid damage, the sailors have only themselves to care about: they bury under the deck in wet bundles, shivering under the biting cold of the unremitting downpour. The endless wait is dispelled by a timid sun, and the expedition can finally resume.
802479: What is faith in yourself against the rage of the heavens? The sails thrash against their mast, escaping the hands of your sailors as they desperately try to reel them in. The freezing rain becomes hail, and the crew's strength melts under the relentless pounding. About half the sails are secured as the first bolts of lightning crackle over the horizon.
802486: Order the crew to finish reefing the sails
802488: Just in time! The lieutenants' preaching hits the sailors harder than the hail itself, and the crew pours their last drops of effort into reefing the remaining sail. As they finish attaching the spanker, the full strength of the tempest hits the ship. To the relief of the crew, the reefed sails take no damage, but the ship lurches helplessly, carried by the whims of the storm until it finally calms down.
802489: There's no courage in these cowards. Despite the repeated calls of the lieutenants and the urgency of the situation, the sailors stay frozen in the face of the thunderstorm, awed mice before a famished cat. You can beat them into life, or say your prayers.
802492: The threat works. The perspective of a flogging somewhat outweighs the menace of the thunderstorm, and the sailors resume their work in a panic. The sails are reefed and secured right before the heart of the storm crashes into your ship. Letting the tempest haul you through the ocean is not a pleasant experience, but at least the sailboat didn't take any damage.
802493: The threat of punishment is weak and unwarranted. Rendered distraught by the storm and unable to gather their wits, your lieutenants have no power over the crew. Your sailors are too busy saving their skins to mind orders, especially when given with so little conviction. Your ship is consumed by the tempest, chewed up, ground down and spat out. Its skeletal remains drift away from the storm.
802496:
Your prayers are heard.
"A thousand may fall at your side,
Ten thousand at your right hand,
But it will not come near you.
You will only observe with your eyes,
And see the punishment of the wicked."
As your priest intones, perched atop the bow, so does the storm seem to soften. A miracle? When the skies clear, however, it would appear that some sailors were judged to be wicked.
802497: The thunderstorm hits your ship with full force. Call it divine punition or pure coincidence, but the tempest gathers around the vessel, and hell begins. Lightning strikes the masts and tears through the sails, igniting brief fires that are immediately doused by the hail. The deck is water, the ship is a wave - and it crashes against the sea, again and again. When at last the first sunrays bless the sailboat, its shape is left torn and mangled.
802487: Maneuver with what sails you have left
802498: To safety! Maneuvering with only half your sails while facing oversized waves, pounding hail and incoming lightning is as difficult as it sounds. And yet the crew does it. Relying not on the sails, but on the ship's bilge keel and its keel-protecting apron, they spear through the wind without being driven sideways. The boat leaps over the trough of the waves, pushed by the raging force of the elements, offering as much resistance it can possibly can - until, at last, the tempest is left behind.
802499: A close call. Navigating with so few sails proves more difficult than expected, and the proximity of the thunderstorm makes the sea even wilder. The ship rolls among the gigantic waves, lifted and shifted by the whims of the tempest. The crew's maneuvers amount to choosing which less terrible wave they wish to crash into. When the storm recedes, the damage is somewhat acceptable.
802500: Too slow. The crew's skills are limited to classic sailing, perhaps in a bit of bad weather, but not in a storm of this magnitude. And not on a ship with half its sails reefed, and the other half flailing in the gale. Ignoring the urgency of the free sails, the sailors try to maneuver the ship, and manage to present its full flank to the waves. The tempest gladly takes the offering. It crashes into the ship, tearing both sails and men from it, before spewing the remains into calmer seas.
802475: Frenzied measures for frenzied times: open all sails and ride the storm
802501: Riding the wild wind isn't dangerous enough for your crew. In a display of complete control over the ship, they somehow manage to find an invisible corridor of safe passage among the waves. The gales that should have torn the sails apart instead fill them, making the sailboat dance with a majesty at least as grand as the storm itself. Instead of leaving the tempest, the crew rides it until it calms down on its own, exhausted from carrying its new masters.
802502: A move as wasteful as it was risky. Meek doesn't even begin to describe your sailors' approach: they deploy the sails in an incoherent manner, letting the wind take hold of the ship. The vessel yaws to one side, then to other, its rudder barely in contact with the water. A wave grabs a sailor and runs away with him. Any more of this, and the whole crew will follow!
802503: Time the anchor's release to counterbalance the ship
802507: A bold move! Releasing the anchor right as the ship reaches an upright position and begins to yaw is the perfect timing to stop the chaotic rolling. The sailboat protests against the maneuver, trembling under the insistence of the waves, but obediently follows your crew's demands as they finally steer it away from the storm. Unnerved but alive, the sailors agree that they have seen and done enough risk-taking for the day.
802508: A move too bold. Timing the anchor's release to the yawing of the ship takes more competence and composure than your crew can muster. The iron cross drops as the ship rolls to the opposite side and, instead of driving the ship back to a steady position, the anchor grinds against the flank, tearing planks and railings as it falls. The waves finish the job. When the storm finally recedes, the ship is adrift, its flank gutted.
802504: Fill the bottom of the hold to keep it steady
802509: Safe and sound. Ignoring the battering rain as they navigate the pitching deck with skill, the sailors organise a human chain to store the upper deck's goods in the depths of the ship. The temporary ballast, accompanied by the human weight of the sailors, manages to lower the waterline and quells the ship's rolls. Hidden in the hull, and unable to do any more for their ship, the crew must wait for the storm to calm down on its own.
802510: Mayhem. Disheartened by the enormity of the task, the sailors hardly listen to their lieutenants. Four crew members attempt to follow orders and unfasten the deck's supplies, only to have them roll away and slide across the deck as the ship pitches in the storm, knocking down sailors and pushing them overboard, before breaking the ship's railings and toppling its weakened masts. When the sun emerges, it reveals the emaciated silhouette of a ghost ship.
802476: Use the steam engines to carefully follow the trough of the waves
802511: Slow and steady.Maybe too slow? Careful maneuvers keep your ship under favourable winds, and keep the menace of transverse waves at bay, but the storm shows no sign of relenting.
802513: Overheat the engines to outrun the storm
802515: A power stronger than the elements themselves. Through skillful manipulation of the engines, the crew pushes the machinery to its utmost limit; the screw propeller moving far beyond what human sight can perceive, propelling the steam ship with remarkable speed. The vessel breaks through the waves and away from the storm in a thrilling display of man-made might.
802516: You should have been more patient. The crew cannot manage such a brusque change of pace, and their meager knowledge of the machinery is not enough to demand so much from the engines without paying an equivalent price. The ship vaults away from the storm in a cacophony of complaining metal and agonizing devices - when at last the tempest is gone, the engines require your immediate attention and repairs.
802514: Maintain a steady pace and let the storm push you off track
802544: A negligible change of course. Letting the storm push your ship as it pleases upsets the most hot-headed sailors, but those with an actual brain upstairs appreciate the prudent approach. When the storm recedes, the ship's slight change of course takes a full week to be corrected - a decent trade-off in exchange for your safety.
802512: You would have been better off with a windjammer. Navigating the ship through the storm proves trickier than expected, and the navigators' lack of familiarity with steam ships shows as they rely on the sails to maneuver, despite the ship's peculiar lack of a middle mast. It doesn't take long for the ship to protest against the poor handling. It yaws, and a loud rumble erupts from the hull: the ballast has come unfastened!
802521: Fasten the ballast back into place
802523:
Your prayers are heard.
"A thousand may fall at your side,
Ten thousand at your right hand,
But it will not come near you.
You will only observe with your eyes,
And see the punishment of the wicked."
As your priest intones, perched atop the bow, so does the storm seem to soften. A miracle? When the skies clear, however, it would appear that some sailors were judged to be wicked.
802524: Too heavy, too dangerous. Your sailors are ill-prepared to handle the massive basalt stones that act as ballast. They try to secure the stones in place, but the ship continues to pitch: their footing is unsteady, and the rocks are so, so heavy. A sudden yaw sends the basalt rolling into them, and your sailors are knocked down, crushed like clay figures. There is nothing more to be done but wait for the ire of the tempest to pass.
802522: Make use of the steamship's sails to survive
802525: You run a pretty decent storm jib! Navigating the steam ship like a good old sailboat, the navigators rely on the sails alone to steady the ship's erratic movements, and strain the rudder this way and that. It is fearless! The gale hits the wet sails with all its might, inflating them to their limit, as the sudden force breaks the ship out of its pitching. The navigators seize the opportunity to escape the storm, to the delighted clamour of the crew.
802526: Disaster. Proving once more how inept they are at navigating this ship, your sailors attempt that which should never be attempted: they try to go against the wind. As the ship twirls, a gale strikes it with full force, transforming its yaw into a full-length broaching. The masts plunge into the sea, and there is no more up or down, and no more sky or deck. Everything is water. When the seas drain away, allowing the ship to sway back into position, there is no trace of the sailors taken by the storm.
802477: Overwork the steam engines to boldly escape the storm
802527: A power stronger than the elements themselves. Through skillful manipulation of the engines, the crew pushes the machinery to its utmost limit; the screw propeller moving far beyond what human sight can perceive, propelling the steam ship with remarkable speed. The vessel breaks through the waves and away from the storm in a thrilling display of man-made might.
802528: The delicate machinery is handled brutishly. Assuming that the engine's heat is directly proportional to the ship's speed, the engineer overheats the steamer and brings the boiler way over capacity. The temperature rises, the pressure swells and the metal quivers, until one of the engines explodes, killing the engineer on the spot.
802529: Attempt to use the remaining engine without your engineer
802531: An unexpected turnaround. A sailor steps forward: she's spent the trip observing the engineer, she says, and thinks she can handle the machinery. The lack of other volunteers, frightened by the engineer's death, leaves her the only candidate. She handles the remaining engine with a notable, if amateurish skill, and the steam ship emerges from the storm in one piece. Still, several sailors whisper about the ill luck of letting a woman save them.
802533: From bad to worse. The sailors have even less skill than the engineer who, let us insist on this point, died while trying to practise his specialty. The crew tries to push this thing and pull that other thing. The pieces of metal are kicked to the best of the crew's abilities, until the air pump's valve bursts open, filling the entire room with burning steam, and forcing the sailors outside. The valve must be closed, and a volunteer offers to face the miniature hell.
802534: Forget engineering, and hope the Lord will protect the volunteer
802537: If not skill, at least courage is rewarded. The volunteer rushes inside the engine room to close the leaking valve, screaming a Glory Be as the steam broils his skin. Both steam and storm recede once the valve is slammed shut, and the crew can take its time repairing the abused machinery. The volunteer spends the rest of the trip preaching the Lord's grace, his incessant sermon making the other sailors regret the tempest and its terrifying shrieks.
802538: Hell indeed. Whether the volunteer lacked faith, or the Lord lacked attention, it is only for Him to know. The man enters the engine room and can hardly touch the leaking valve before the steam devours him whole, large blisters feeding on his flesh while the whistling valve covers his screams. There is no distinguishing the man's agony from the machinery's cries, and the door is hurriedly sealed shut. The inhumane shrieks continue to resound through the ship for the rest of the trip.
802536: Insist on using your crafting wits, and protect him yourself
802539: The best of a spread of bad options. The volunteer penetrates the engine room wrapped in layers of wet cloths, as the crew provides ventilation by rapidly opening and closing the door, avoiding the steam with damp armour of their own. The man manages to close the valve, and the rest of the steam is evacuated in the same ridiculously plain manner. The immediate danger is avoided, and the crew wisely decides to avoid any more risk-taking, and wait for the storm to end on its own.
802540: Don't you know when to stop? The sailor covers himself in damp cloths and enters the engine room, only for the steam to contaminate his wet armour with its insufferable heat. He springs from the room covered in blisters, a monster of molten skin which howls agony beyond human comprehension, his cries echoed by the tempest itself. The steam follows him out of the room, and burns all the sailors within its grasp, taking delight in the stolen flesh until it finally recedes, replete thanks to the stubbornness of the crew.
802530: Shut off the engines and rely on your sails
802541: Audacious! Abandoning the steam engines, the crew focuses its efforts on using all available sails on the ship. The sailors may not have faced tempests this grand before, but they have crossed seas and braved oceans aboard all kinds of vessels: navigation is in their blood. They face the winds, ignore the waves, and lock the steering wheel into place, allowing the ship to stay steady until the storm passes. Not the most natural of solutions for a steam ship, but a good display of skill nonetheless.
802542: Reckless! Attempting to face the tempest without the ship's main power source is folly, and the crew cannot handle the safety sails as well as they imagined. They try to face the waves to break their momentum, but the ship's mishandling lets it drift - and offers its flanks to the tempest. When the sun finally pierces the clouds, it reveals a spectacle of lacerated sails, flooded supplies, and disgruntled sailors.
802610: Your sailors face the mountain without a map. After racing from guide to guide through the depths of the mountain range, the crew find themselves devoid of a chaperone: the guide supposed to take them on the last leg hasn't shown up at the time you agreed. Forget what initial goal you had in mind - getting off the snow-topped peak is the only priority now.
802611: Traverse the mountain on your own
802613: Your navigators make do without a guide. They take note of landmarks as they progress, relying on their compasses to follow a single direction, staying put during the night despite their dwindling supplies. At long last, they find a stream of melted snow, and follow it downhill to the foot of the mountain. The crew survived, but it was a tough effort.
802614: A guide would have been helpful. Your sailors navigate the mountain paths to the best of their ability, but they aren't skilled enough for the task at hand. The narrow roads disappear beneath the mist of the snow and branch out around the skeletal trees, forcing your crew to spread out. When the explorers reach a decent camping ground and count their numbers, five of them are missing.
802618: Go forward, leaving marks for the lost sailors to follow
802620: The foot of the mountain, at last. The crew progress step by step, testing the frozen snow for gaps while leaving piles of stones for the lost sailors to follow. Building the landmarks takes time, but it helps avoid any backtracking. The main group is soon joined by the missing sailors, who are disgruntled at having been left behind, despite the crew's best efforts to guide them. Soon their ordeal is over, however, as they reach the end of the mountain range in silence, left speechless with relief.
802621: The explorers get more lost with each passing day. They venture deep into the mountain and quickly abandon the idea of leaving marks for the lost sailors, too concerned for their own survival. The frost solidifies their clothes, steals their toes and rots their food.
802622: Follow a stream of melted snow running downhill
802625: Your sailors manage to follow the stream to the foot of the mountain. The stream flows in and out of the frozen ground, playing hide and seek with the desperate crew. They are not the only ones using the trickle as a guide: just before reaching the plains below the mountain, they meet with the missing sailors, who are quenching their burning thirst in the meagre snow stream. It's unclear which of the two teams is the most pitiful, but all are alive.
802626: Where did they come from? Where should they go? The melting snow splits into a web of entangled streams, which buries under the ground and resurfaces without any apparent logic. The crew are taken by the illusion that the forest around them is flat, and can no longer tell if they are climbing or descending. They split like the streams themselves, to each sailor their trickle - but like the streams, not all of them find the foot of the mountain.
802623: Force your way through the mounds of powder snow
802627: The sailors draw strength from their last resources. They ignore the colossal distance they have to cross, and focus on small milestones instead. Two steps to that tree. Three steps to that rock. The snow parts as they advance, drawing dark trenches which run across the pure white mantle, and which eventually - finally - reach the foot of the mountain. The crew stumble and fall in relief when they realise they made it out alive.
802628: The sailors are too weakened by the cold. They dig through the powder snow, only for it to collapse in again without revealing any safe path. Their endurance crippled by the frost, they abandon the task and try to focus on less demanding options.
802624: Prioritise your supplies and look for food
802629: The crew extend their stay in the cold to gather supplies. Game is scarce, and hunting takes time. However, the food makes for a decent meal, and the smell of roasted hare fills the sailors' stomachs almost as well as the meat itself. The light from the fire spreads through the forest at night, and beckons the missing sailors. Reunited, the crew avoid talking about abandoning their companions, and they leave the mountain in silence.
802630: Your hunters fall prey to the mountain. Animals' tracks sprinkle the fresh snow, but their owners are invisible, hidden in holes and burrows. The hunters are unused to such terrain. As they progress through the forest, discussing where snares could be most efficient, the frozen ground suddenly breaks beneath them, and a handful of sailors fall into a deep fault.
802619: Go back and look for the missing sailors
802631: The missing sailors are found, and with them an exit. The idea of losing their companions pushes the hunters to persevere. Broken twigs, brushed moss, mud splashes: everything is a hint. They follow the trail to a crossing and find the lost sailors, who welcome them heartily: better yet, they've found a beaten path which leads straight to the foot of the mountain! That they believed in the others and waited for them is a reward in and of itself.
802632: The fresh snow hides the dangers underneath. A powdery white frosting covers everything in sight, and the skies melt into the ground, disguising the horizon. The hunters advance on instinct alone, unable to spot any hints of their previous passage. They find the missing sailors only by encountering the same fate: the frozen ground breaks under their weight. The thin crust of ice hid a fault! Three of the lost men are down there - and two hunters just joined them.
802633: Pull the sailors from the fault, at the risk of falling
802637: The rescue comes at the price of their remaining strength. It takes ten sailors to get one man out of the fault: three to pull, six to hold and one to keep an eye on the trembling layer of ice. The snow weighs them down, pushing when they pull, hissing when they call out. When the last sailor is hauled from the rift, both the rescuers and rescued are broken. They drag themselves downhill. and manage to leave the clutch of the mountain.
802638: The ordeal is much bigger than your sailors. They launch ropes into the rift, but the slippery walls of ice cannot be climbed. The rescuers attempt to haul the others up, and they plant their feet into the ground, pulling, heaving and panting, their physical reserves long drained by the cold. As they fall to their knees and break their nails on the frozen hemp, the rift cracks, and the mountain opens its mouth wide. The crewmates it swallows are never seen again.
802639: Salvation at the price of their humanity. Ignoring the begging screams of their companions, the sailors make a large detour to avoid falling into the frozen rift. As they find a beaten path heading downhill, a sailor catches up to the group, panting: he admits to having thrown some pickaxes and ropes down the fault. The crew congratulate him for his selflessness, and pretend his good deed is enough to ease their conscience.
802640: The path is easy to recognize, but it is tortuous and unforgiving. The crew fight against the elements, hurrying through the mountain passages with haste, lest their tracks disappear and leave them without hints to follow. When they finally escape the mountain range, they cannot remember how many nights they spent walking, and how many days they spent starving.
802643: An overweight ship is easy prey for stormy waves. The oil merchants your crew met at the last harbour paid good money for their cargo to be stored aboard your ship, but the weight isn't really something your vessel can handle. At the first signs of tempest winds and cutting waves, the unusual ballast makes your ship heel furiously.
802646: Safe. The cast-iron shank of the anchor plunges into the shifting waves with a large splash, the amount of chain being just right for it to take a good hold of the seabed. The ship wobbles, washed by the winds and the waves, but manages to stay put. The sailors simply wait for the storm to pass, and hope the extra load will not cause any more problems.
802647: A miss - the crew should go hide in the lower decks. The anchor is released, its chain unravelling by itself more than it is controlled, and the large iron cross reaches the bottom with too much play to properly grip the sea floor. As it becomes apparent the anchor won't be of any help, the lieutenants order the crew to descend to the bottom decks of the swinging ship - but the oil merchants refuse to leave the apparent safety of their upper cabins.
802648: Take the time to present this solution as the best
802650: The lost time was necessary. Your lieutenants carefully convince the merchants, detailing all available options one by one, despite the increasingly high pressure from the waves, and the rocking of the ship. Their stoicism more than their arguments convinces the merchants to follow the orders, and they join the rest of the crew on the lower deck until the storm comes to pass.
802651: A waste of time.Pressed by the urgency of the situation and unable to get their thoughts in order, your lieutenants cannot properly convince the merchants. As they begin to lose their nerve, the ship swerves and slams into the shore. Whistling winds invade the perforated hull, and water seeps in its wake.
802652: Repair the hole while the water is still pouring
802654: Your crew are used to making repairs in poor conditions. Ignoring the swinging floor, the sailors focus on the hull, their legs deep in the pouring water. Drenched supplies lap around their legs as they fight to plug the hole. The seal will not last long, but it should hold until the next harbour.
802655: Your crew's speed cannot match the water's. Overwhelmed by the current, and unable to prioritise their tasks or even shape a plan for the repairs, the sailors quickly abandon the idea of patching up the hull. They flee to the upper deck, and brace themselves as the ship crashes on the shore. The repairs take weeks.
802653: Move the ballast to lift the hole above sea level
802656: The forced instability protects the ship. Your sailors huff and puff as they push the large sacks of basalt stones across the belly of the ship, progressively tipping the vessel's balance until its pierced flank leans away from the water. The ship is carefully led to the shore, where the crew can finally start repairs.
802657: A ludicrous plan. Your sailors wheeze and gasp as they try to pull the basalt sacks, but their efforts are not enough to make the ballast budge. The ship remains level, allowing more and more water in, as it sinks under the intrusion. Several sailors drown, trapped between the deck's roof and the swirling currents, and their bodies cannot be evacuated before the storm calms down.
802649: Drug them to avoid losing any more time
802658: Safe and drunk. The merchants accept the liquid courage and drink its laced contents, falling asleep before they can finish their bottle. They're dragged to the lower deck along with the rest of the crew and whatever supplies the sailors could carry, their combined weight counterbalancing the pounding of the waves. The storm soon calms down, leaving the crew to deal with the hangover of their passengers.
802659: Too weak. The drinks your sailors offer the merchants in an attempt to soothe their anger are far too poorly made to have any kind of impact on them. As they continue to struggle against your crew, a vivid growl resonates through the ship. You came too close to shore, and the reefs have pierced your hull! Water starts to pour into the lower decks.
802645: Improvise a sea anchor on the surface of the water
802660: The sea anchor works as intended. Your sailors quickly cable up a weighty assemblage, and after fastening it securely, let it drop into the waves. It pulls against the water to increase the ship's drag, gaining it enough stability to keep its broadside away from the waves. The crew, relieved, can wait for the storm to pass.
802661: The sea anchor sinks as soon as it touches the water. The sailors tack together some extra sails to try and assemble a sea anchor, but the ballooning cloths snap as soon as they're thrown into the waves. As the ship is pushed towards the shore, the backwash gets more and more ample, until a rogue wave of ludicrous proportions rises above the sea. The merchant passengers beg your crew to save them!
802665: Fearless. Despite the battering gale and clobbering currents, your crew manage to keep the ship straight, as you face the rogue wave head on. The wave crashes into your vessel with all its rage and natural power, but the straight bow cuts its fury in two, and the ship avoids most of the damage - a rock among the waters. When the storm calms down, your crew focus on the repairs, and consider how exceptional their survival was.
802666: Too audacious. The gusts of wind fill your sails, and the frantic currents pull at your hull. Your crew are far too untrained to keep control over the ship. Entailed by the sea's passion, the ship leaps and falls, dancing until the shore catches it and stops its mad waltz. The vessel's carcass finally remains still, as water and bodies flow from its bent silhouette.
802664: Throw the oil cargo overboard to calm the seas
802669: The water's anger dies out! Moving the merchants aside with ease and dismissing their plea, your sailors heave the oil barrels over the railings, and let their contents spill around the ship. The oil hugs the water and rolls over the waves, dissolving the wind's grip, and slowing the water's movement. The threat of the waves is no more, but the merchants' trust and cargo were lost in the process.
802670: Their greed overcomes your strength. The sailors first try to reason, and then try to force the merchants into giving up their precious oil, but your crew are weak in both body and spirit, while the merchants built their fortunes on hard-headedness. Long after the ship has been hit, crushed, and stranded, the merchants's cadavers are found lying on the shore's pebbles, still clutching their barrels of cargo.
803305:
"The whales are still around us!"
Impossibly large trails of water break the wake of the ship, and the froth parts to reveal dark, leathery skin. The whales are gaining speed, and their impact is imminent.
803306: Launch the steam ship at full speed
803307: The wonders of technology! The steam engines roar above the whales' chant, and the ship lunges away from the creatures in a cacophony of grating metal and whistling vapor. An investment well spent.
803308: Maneuver the ship to avoid the whales
803309: A masterful maneuver! The captain stirs the ship alongside the school of whales, and the animals glide past the boat in a slow and graceful ballet. The crew salute their captain's skill, and revel in the moment.
803310: Hard to avoid what you cannot see. The whales are everywhere: on the sides, in front, at the back, and beneath the ship. The captain strains against the limits of his skill, but he cannot avoid the impacts coming from below, and part of the cargo is sent flying before the ship can escape.
803311: A school of whales is not a road you can simply navigate. As the ship shifts to the side, the closest whale reacts to the sudden movement by playing dead: it stops swimming, and lets itself fall at an agonizingly slow speed. The impact with the rudder is brutal, and bends the vital mechanism.
803313: A feat of strength for a gratuitous kill. The harpoon impales the leading whale, and the rest of the school collides with its body, their advance being suddenly, and brutally stopped. The ship leaves without a scratch.
803314: The harpoon strikes a calf, causing the school to attack. The wounded whale swirls to try and get rid of the iron rod, and its elders surround it, pushing the ship away from their young. The boat lists heavily to the side, and several men fall overboard.
803315: Throw a roped harpoon to save the drowning sailors
803316: A harpoon is sacrificed to rescue the men. The men grab the harpoon's anchoring rope and climb back on board, just in time to see the rope snap and fall into the abyss. The ship flees before any whales resurface.
803317: The rescue harpoon triggers the whales' attack. The roped weapon could have made a good rescue device, but the giant marine mammals were already restless from the previous throw. A whale simply tilts up its head, and a massive wave engulfs the drowning sailors, crashing against the ship, and ramming it away from the begging and screaming men.
803318: Get away from the flustered whales
