803319: The fate of the drowning men is sealed. As the ship retreats from the whales, the captain prays aloud for the sailors' survival. No one among the crew is naive enough to believe his words, but they all pretend.
803320: Sing a military favorite to scare the whales away
803321:
The whales dance away from the ship.
"Eternal Father, strong to save,
Whose arm hath bound the restless wave,
Oh, hear us when we cry to Thee,
For those in peril on the sea!"
In a unison born out of a common love of the hymn, the sailors sing and brace themselves for impact — only to realize the creatures have drifted away. A tale of dancing whales will be part of this expedition's story!
803322: The performance's efficiency is questionable. Trying their best to be in unison, the sailors shout their hearts out more than they sing, and the underwater creatures don't seem to care. The group screaming occupies the crew for a long time, allowing the ship to drift closer to the school of whales.
803323: The crew embarrass themselves. The underwater whales cannot hear the sounds squirming from the ship, and it's for the best. Dejected, their ears ringing, the sailors blame each other for the performance, and the team's unity and pride are deeply dented. Getting squashed by a whale would have been a better option.
803324: Send a man in the diving bell to fix the rudder
803325: The sailor has rarely worked with such a view. As the hours disappear while he fixes the rudder, the whales continue their inexorable advance in a vision of lethargic, yet grandiose movement. When the rudder is repaired, the whales are still passing by - and too close for comfort.
803332: The diving bell's rope tightens, then floats back up. Both equipment and sailor are lost to the unfathomable depths and their gigantic inhabitants. The crew ponders whether the accident was caused by chance, or animal malevolence.
803335: Fire canons in the water to scare the whales away
803336: The tiny cannonballs somehow drive the massive creatures away. As the sea foams and whitens under the force of the impacts, it hides what reaction the whales may have. When the froth clears, the animals seem to have dived away from the ship, but the men stay tense for a long while.
803337: Ten pound cannonballs against creatures of a hundred tons? A whale slams into the ship, then another one, then another. The repetitive impacts make the crew believe the attacks are intentional, and they rally into begging prayers and whimpers. When the ocean's fury recedes, they're left to count the sailors thrown overboard.
803338: Wait for the whales to leave
803339: The whales are not eager to retreat. Used to being a predatorless presence, a whale shoves aside the obstacle in its way, and the ship is sent rocking. The damage is extensive and will take days to fix. The creatures go on in indifference, reminding the crew of their meagerness.
803333: Keep sailing straight ahead, at the risk of collision
803334: Neither ship nor whale tries to avoid the impact. Used to being a predatorless presence, the whale shoves aside the obstacle in its way and the ship is sent rocking. The creatures go on in indifference, reminding the crew of their meagerness.
800313: 'It's too narrow and shallow this far upriver!' warns the steersman. Escorting Mr. Cardinale to the site of his rainforest opera house now seems all the more preposterous! The great patron of the arts twizzles his moustache in frustration! Apart from braving the difficulty ahead, only traversing a nearby hill might reconnect the expedition with the upper river.
800314: Use your gunboat to navigate the shallows
800318: The design of the gunboat is vital to your success. Being of moderate size, and yet possessing the manoeuvring capabilities of a much smaller ship, the gunboat is able to navigate the awkward river shallows with ease. Mr. Cardinale is delighted that you have delivered him to the site of his proposed Opera House, and promises to talk favourably of each and every man when he returns to civilisation.
800315: Have the ship transported over the hill to rejoin the river further up
800319: 'What a champion performance!' squeals Mr. Cardinale, from the comfort of his cushioned chair. The great ship seems to swim up and over the hill. The long timbers on which it rolls, and corkscrew winches at intervals up the slope work perfectly. 'I shall put in a good word for you all at the club,' promises Cardinale, as the ship splashes down safely on the other side. The men are immensely proud of the miracle they have performed.
800320: Getting a ship over a hill is mad, but it works. 'Is this absolutely necessary?' muses Mr. Cardinale, having watched the crew slip for a week in mud. But the rolling timbers and makeshift winches they have crafted prove adequate, and the ship finally scrapes down the other side, into the upper river. Mr. Cardinale barely offers a word of thanks, perturbed perhaps, by the indignity of it all.
800321: There simply aren't enough materials to conduct such an elaborate enterprise. The crew think with a few extra bits and bobs, dragging the ship up the hill might be possible.
800323: Proceed uphill without materials, belief will guide us through
800325: The men have the conviction to safely hoist the ship up and over the hill. It is a fatiguing week, but belief in making the impossible possible possesses them. When the ship finally splashes into the water, Mr. Cardinale has barely a Christian word of thanks for the crew. It has taken a long enough after all.
800326: It is all going so well, this mad idea, with winches and cables scarcely sufficient for the task. But exertion eventually tells. As the ship rocks over the crest of the hill, there is not enough to keep it there, and it hurtles wildly down the other side. It is lucky the ship is not swept away in the river current. Still, it sustains significant damage from impact with the trees.
800327: 'I think it's going to give way!' cries the terrified Mr. Cardinale. The feet of your men slip and slide on the slope, as the unholy weight of the ship overcomes the winches, and it plummets back down the hill. Men try to get out of the way, but are crushed beneath the keel. The hideous accident signals the end of Cardinale's operatic ambitions.
800324: Ask the locals gathered around the scene if they are able to help
800328: The locals are willing to provide help and materials. While it takes the crew time to incorporate the materials into their winch design, the locals are happy to wait. Good relations make the feat of hoisting a ship over a hill less painful than it might have been. The boat finally clatters down into the water of the upper river. All are most grateful to the locals, without whom none of this would have been possible.
800329: A few locals vaguely offer to help, but their lukewarm efforts do little to relieve the exhausted crew. The ridiculous hill-climb takes more than a week. When the ship finally slips into the water over the other side, not even Mr. Cardinale has energy enough to care.
800330: The locals have absolutely no interest in helping you, and fade into the trees. Beleaguered by shouts from Mr. Cardinale, the men meekly follow orders. The mad persistence has disastrous consequences. The ship plummets back down the hill! Many try to get out of the way, but are crushed beneath the keel. The hideous accident signals the end of Cardinale's operatic ambitions.
800322: 'I think it's going to give way!' cries the terrified Mr. Cardinale. The feet of your men slip and slide on the mudstrewn slope, as the great weight of the ship plummets it back down the hill. Many try to get out of the way, but are crushed beneath the keel. A hideous accident caused by inadequate materials, that signals the end of Cardinale's operatic ambitions.
800316: Attempt to carefully navigate the narrow passage
800331: Competent navigation rescues your ship from the mother of all rivers. Mr. Cardinale is tremulous throughout, believing his dreams may beach like a river dolphin at any time. But over the course of three tricky days, information is relayed quickly enough between wheel and forecastle to avoid any harmful collisions. There is relief all around when the corner is made and the river broadens again.
800332: 'Rapids?!' exhales Mr. Cardinale crossly. Ahead white water churns. There is nothing for it but to push on. As the ship strains against the current, there are dreadful noises from rocks on the keel. The crew wince at each and every thump and screech. Finally, after a week, the river broadens again, and the crew can inspect the damage - it doesn't look good.
800333: It is a heart-breaking experience. Days go by in the effort to lever the ship out of the sandy shallows, where it does not belong. It is battered by rocks and rapids, and leaks like a rusted bucket. Mr. Cardinale kicks up and awful fuss. Finally when it feels like progress is being made, the next bend reveals a harrowing sight - an insurmountable waterfall! Never have the crew felt more hopeless.
800317: Decline to proceed any further and return to sea
800334: Mr. Cardinale is incensed that his grand plans for the rainforest Opera House have been thwarted. Some of the men find his blustering funny, but the officers are horrified that such an influential figure has been rebuffed, and are afraid to show their faces in society ever again.
800933: Trapped in the snow! When the furious blizzard relents, the exploration party see the mountain pass ahead is blocked. Some say the rough terrain can be crossed, others say they saw a small fork in the path not too far back.
800938: The crew feel happy awe, at the resulting avalanche. There, as the pass beyond is revealed, they swear they see something lurching away. Giant and hirsute, it leaves no print but in the imagination.
800935: Craft something to traverse the terrain
800939: The skis are highly effective. Simply fashioned, and with a clever coating of paraffin. Some prove expert skiers, glissading with a flourish to the finish line, but all make it to the bottom. The whole thing has turned out to be a good bit of fun.
800947: Toboggans are better where it's flat. Though solidly made, the going is fast. One sled veers into a ravine. A cry below: 'Officer injured', but the wind is picking up.
800952: The doctor works quickly. Just what is needed with another blizzard brewing. 'Temporary strapping,' he says, 'but should get us home.' The officer and rest of the party make shelter with little time left to spare.
800953: The doctor knows nothing of urgency. 'Give my patient space!' he snaps at those trying to move things along. Meanwhile, a blizzard sweeps the ravine, and the onset of frostbite is enough to split the party. Neither the doctor nor his unfortunate patient are to be seen again.
800954: You knew deep down not all would make it. 'They're all returned but the injured fellow,' comes the news. 'There was no saving him, the way he was. Ice stripped the meat from his bones like a chef's mandorre.'
800948: The clumsy snowshoes fail you. Whether it is in their design or construction, every step sinks the party deeper. The cold will claim lives before the storm is weathered.
800943: It is not much of a detour. The going is steady and before long the warm fire of the base camp appears in view. The blizzard is something to tell the grandchildren, provided frostbite hasn't seen to that...
800944: The path is both steep and perilous. A narrow ledge along a sheer cliff lies ahead. Some men are ready to give up. All the while a strange noise keens below the gnashing gale.
800957: A heavenly, enlightened voice calls. None stop to look down, so enchanted are they. Over a verge, appears a shrine with a great bell - the source of the sound - and beyond, a pilgrims' path to the foot of the mountain.
800958: A non-believer falls to his death. 'Those lacking conviction shall be tried and judged in this place,' echoes the priest. The rest edge to safety, consoled by the apparent goodness in their hearts.
800960: Nothing but a demonic howl. The blizzard rises anew. Without hope to keep them aloft, it is no surprise when a ledge gives way, damning to hell below.
800956: Urge your party to face their fears
800961: A song of solidarity rises through the line of snow-crusted faces. Clinging to what they most cherish, they edge to safety. Had they not been reminded of such incentives, it is doubtful they would have survived.
800962: Only some take strength. The rest remain in a frozen huddle. They may have lacked courage to negotiate the high ledge, but will welcome in their icy death with creditable stoicism.
800945: A far more treacherous path, but your crew are committed now. A steep cliff ahead must be negotiated, and your ropes are too short.
800965: Craft longer ropes and swing down
800966: All are saved, at a cost. Putting the ropes together is quite a task with frozen fingers. That the party are able to cling to the rope as they descend is a small miracle. Nevertheless, frostbite will do lasting damage to their digits.
800967: A small but critical detail is overlooked. Grip. A man falls from the top of the rope with a cry, tumbling those below him into the abyss like meat from a skewer. Only a few frozen grimaces survive.
800968: It is a risky business. Though the cliff isn't lacking in handholds, this is a test of individual endurance. Some were never going to be up to it. As they fall, the will to survive in the others strengthens.
800946: Shelter is minimal. Huddling cannot keep out the cold. When a rescue party arrives with equipment the next morning, they find men frostbitten and hypothermic. Not all of them will survive the journey down.
801064: Water has dribbled almost to nothing during an inland survey, en route to the rendezvous. But hope springs eternal! A muddy river strikes through the arid basin. The crew are delirious when they realise it is not completely dried-up. Do you stop for water, or press on?
801069: The botanist foams at the mouth with thirst-quenching theories. 'The best idea may be these trees. Cut them just here, and catch the drip of water beneath,' they say, as they take a knife to the bark. Before an hour has passed, there's enough water to soothe a beached humpback.
801066: Fashion a device to extract water from mud
801070: 'The secret is boiling the water', says one resourceful survivalist, 'and needless to say a mixture of charcoal, sand and cloth makes a fine filter.' With water drawn, filtered and boiled, the crew can be sure it is safe to drink. Time even for a mud bath - your safari brigade slopping about like happy hippo.
801071: The water still has a mighty pong, despite all solids having been separated out by the rudimentary device. Several feel terribly ill after drinking. A treatment can be improvised, or the survey can try to hold out until the rendezvous.
801079: The sickness clears over time. 'With dysentery the patient must rest,' the sensible doctor said, 'away from the others.' With the last of the good water, and gentle nursing, the caravan reaches the rendezvous in fair health.
801080: No-one is ready for dysentery. The sick are empty and weak, no fluids to replenish all they have lost. With only vague measures in place to prevent the spread, savannah delirium reigns. The survey never reaches the rendezvous.
801081: Haste saves some, but not all. Dysentery is thoroughly set in by the time the survey makes the rendezvous. Although the camp provides the sick every comfort, for many the rigours of the sickness prove too much.
801072: Hours under hot sun, for fatally little. Countless designs in the soil, and no prototype. When something is finally cobbled together, the fools test their stupid sieve with the last of the clean supply. It will be a miracle now if anyone survives.
801067: Look for the source of the river
801073: Finding a river source is easy, but turning it into a shortcut...? That takes brains. High above the dry basin, water piles blissfully into the gully. The men wouldn't miss a swim beneath a waterfall for the world!
801074: There's water, if you can get to it. Hippos are gathered all along the bank. This is their territory. If you don't refill here, there's no guarantee you'll find water further on.
801087: Hip hip hooray! The hippos run as fast as their stout legs will carry them. The serenity of the river bank is utterly destroyed, but none of your crew care, as they help themselves to bucketfuls of clean and highly quaffable drinking water.
801088: Someone knows their hippopotami. A kinship with the animals allows the gentle river bank to be shared. Fresh water is relayed by the bucket. A few nervous moments as a large female rears out of the water, but she just wants a bird to pick her teeth. Satisfied, the crew resume their trek to the rendezvous.
801089: There's movement in the hippo camp, as the crew approach, followed by violent evacuations of their gigantic nostrils. Mandolin jaws open wide in display, and it is pretty clear to the crew they have no choice but to back off.
801090: A game of unhappy hippos ensues! The water swirls with their pudgy bodies. They snort and scream, and prepare to charge.
801093: Cold, but effective. The brigade focus fire at the closest hippo, and soon it is dead. The other hippos falter, bellowed howls of grief echoing around the basin. As the blood of the majestic animal suffuses with the river, your crew must now find the audacity to drink.
801094: The hippos bowl into your nine-pin soldiers. One is dead on impact. Others die slow, trampled or drowning, matchstick guns floating downriver like poohsticks. There's almost no-one left to make the rendezvous.
801092: Immediately run away and leave the area entirely
801095: Escape is more panic than anything else, but the crew are spooked. Lurching through the water with hippos at their backs is not something they are lining up to try again.
801096: Aquatic combat is a key discipline. What small guilt the crew feel about driving the poor hippos from their patch is overcome by a will to survive. Out here, it is such ruthlessness that separates the living from the dead.
801097: What shot hits, barely passes through blubber. The whole bloat of hippos charge, leaving them an instant to make a decision.
801100: Cold, but effective. The brigade focus fire at the closest hippo, and soon it is dead. The other hippo falter, bellowed howls of grief echoing around the basin. As the blood of the majestic animal suffuses with the river, your crew must now find the audacity to drink.
801101: The hippos bowl into your nine-pin soldiers. One is dead on impact. Others die slow, trampled or drowning, matchstick guns floating downriver like poohsticks. There's almost no-one left to make the rendezvous.
801102: Escape is more panic than anything else, but the crew are spooked. Lurching through the water with hippos at their backs is not something they are lining up to try again.
801085: Wait for nightfall, hoping they leave
801103: Hardly seems worth waiting for. The hippos wallow all evening, leaving only as night falls to graze. The crew have lost half a day's march on the rendezvous, for a bit of muddy water.
801104: A waste of time. The hippos leave at dusk to graze. Unfortunately, their patch is just a stone's throw away. Their aqueous eyes can be seen glistening in the moonlight, and no-one wants to risk it.
801075: Following a river should have been easy. But your party are so focused on distant goals, they fail to look immediately ahead. Suddenly, a man shoots downward as if yanked by giant hands. There are holes everywhere - an underground system of caves, and a tomb for your unlucky crew.
801076: There was never enough water for all of them. A freak mist has the crew licking air with cracked tongues, but nothing can keep the wolf from the door. Several drop dead as old bone, before the safari staggers to the rendezvous camp.
801588: Unusual debris floats among the waves. Mold-ridden planks of wood, strings of cloth, fragments of broken plaster, all tinted by the grey shade of time. Filled with childish excitation, the crew discusses the possibility of going underwater to uncover the debris' origin.
801589: Send your diver into the depths
801592: The diver plunges into the ocean with fish-like ease. He follows the trail of debris through the murky waters and almost smacks into a wall of indescribable height. Unsure whether the obstacle is natural or man-made, the diver wanders along its smooth facade until he finds an uncanny artefact and resurfaces with it. His account of the underwater mystery fascinates the crew.
801593: The diving bell looks decent and feels solid. Two men climb aboard and the bell plunges into the depths while a whole group of sailors pumps air into its ventilation tube. The bell descends until it is stopped by a surface of coral. Underneath the colorful shapes, the sailors notice a silver coin on their left and a gaping, perfectly circular hole on their right.
801595: Hope that it will resist the dive and push the bell into the hole
801597: Their trust in the work of their comrades pays. The bell slithers in a slow fall which allows the bewitched divers to take in the view. This is no sunken ship: the engraved hole was a window among a hundred more lining a hall of ridiculous proportions. A single ray of light, pouring from the hole, accompanies the bell's descent until it lands on what might have been statue alcoves. A shining green pearl lies in the lowest part of the alcove.
801599: Ignore the pearl and risk the dive into darkness
801601: Call it luck or miracle, but the bell holds. One of the men lights the bell's lamp and the other dives, following the glow as it illuminates the silent scene below: ghostly statues of hunting scenes, collapsed frescoes depicting plentiful gardens, and a massive throne of fractured marble on which a sword waits, covered in fluttering kelp. When the artifact is brought back to the surface and cleaned up, it reveals a weapon of exquisite quality, embedded with unknown jewels and metals.
801602: Lady Luck does not smile for the faithless. As the bell descends into the dark, so does the pressure rise and press against the makeshift protection. The sailors pull the signal rope in a panic, but despite their fervent prayers, they are not pulled up in time. All that the crew manages to retrieve from the sea are the broken bell and its broken contents.
801600: Retrieve the pearl from the dead-end and resurface
801603: The pearl is made of pure jade! The crew marvels at it and all want to touch it, feel it, smell it. The pearl spreads a nostalgic fragrance of salt water, fresh moss and damp stones, and the sailors agree this might be the very smell of adventure.
801598: The bell doesn't resist the fall. Instead of gliding along the sides of the hole, the bell tilts, letting the water in. The men call for help and the crew immediately tries to pull them up, fighting against what rocks snare the bell, doing their best to save their mates, and unable to react when the rope snaps into their hands. They are left to mourn their sea-buried companions.
801596: Pick up the coin and resurface
801604: Low risk, low reward. The diving bell emerges without a scratch and the crew enjoys the tiny silver coin, passing it around and commenting on its singular aspect. Their excitement can only survive for so long and the coin is stored in the officers' coffers while the sailors whisper what ifs leading to grander treasures.
801594: The homemade diving bell falls apart. The engineers, specialized in complex ship machinery, have no idea how to make such a simple device. Their machine departs with two men onboard, and they continue to dive while the bell itself stays afloat. When the divers emerge, the engineers take an earful, and the crew are too disheartened to make a new attempt.
801605: The sailors protest but understand the risk. As the ship goes on its way, its wake drowns the singular ruins and their promise of adventure.
802002: Water in the hull! The overloaded ship could only go so far with this many supplies in its belly. A series of strong waves sends the crates flying, and the boat's stomach soon explodes. Cracks pierce the hull where the cargo hit, and trickles of water pop one after the other throughout the storage space.
802003: Use the electric water pump to allow proper repairs
802006: Specific situations call for specific solutions: your preparation was on point. The electric pump roars and swallows water much faster that it can infiltrate the ship, allowing the sailors to repair the damage with ease.
802004: Improvise a water pump to allow immediate repairs
802007: Your crafty crew has a solution for everything. Using communication tubes as the pump's body, and spare metal sheets as paddles, the sailors manage to assemble what could pass for a proper water pump. It takes a good dozen men to make it work, but they buy enough time for proper repairs.
802008: This joke of a pump looks like it came from the Dark Ages. As the sailors battle to have their own idea of a pump prevail over the others, they assemble a monster that does nothing more than blow bubbles. One of the cracks in the hull bursts in a spray of water, silencing the machine as the ship starts to flood.
802016: Throw supplies overboard to try and lift the crack above the waterline
802010: Seal the overflowing section, regardless of what - or who - might still be inside
802011: Make a decision! Who knows what'll happen if you don't!
802012: The ship rises in the water, but at what cost? The sailors watch their supplies drift away from the vessel, their hearts lingering after the lost items, until the officers remind them of the urgency of the repairs.
802013: There's nothing more to be done. The ship slowly sinks, pulled deeper into the water with each new fracture in its hull. Both cargo and crew are drenched by the leaks, and the ship vomits their remains when it crashes onto the shore. The survivors contemplate the wreckage in despair, before trying to make repairs.
802014: Both cargo and crew are doomed to drown in the leakage. The sailors close the hull's doors on their comrades, hushing their screams. However, there's no avoiding reopening the hull when time comes for repairs: the water flows out, carrying bodies transfixed with expressions of suffocation, terror, and betrayal.
802005: Seal the damaged section and repair it at the next harbour
802015: The drowned cargo cannot be salvaged. When the ship finally finds a harbour, its hull sits so far below the waterline your crew fears the boat will sink. Although such fears are unfounded, the leaks ruined a good part of your stored food, and the repairs feel like they should have be done much earlier.
800503: The Singular Case of the Midshipman
800504: The Midshipman is found with his throat slit, knife in hand. It would appear to be suicide, but appearances often prove deceptive. Understandably, the whole crew crowd the scene, debating whether he was the type to take his own life, or if someone might have gained by his passing. Needless to say, they expect some action be taken...
800506: The Expert will have the answers
800509: There are gasps of macabre delight, as the famous detective reveals the only possible solution. 'Elementary you see. Look at this tiny moth wing on the body. Moths are drawn to light, and the sole light this night past issued from... this man's LANTERN!!' The detective lunges across the deck and secures the watchman, who being as impressed with the deduction as everyone else, readily admits to having sought to gain rank by the murder.
800510: Careful analysis of the scene reveals two leads. Some believe an autopsy would leave the facts of the case plain, while others reckon the little time available should be spent analysing any evidence at the scene that might establish whodunnit.
800512: Conduct an autopsy of the body
800514: The autopsy is conducted very capably, and confirms the midshipman took his own life. A severe tumour is also discovered on the midshipman's brain. A letter, found later, serves to explain that the fellow knew he hadn't long to live, and wished to face death in his own way. The crew are galvanised on hearing this story of bravery.
800515: The autopsy is sufficient to confirm it was murder. Strangulation was the cause of death, not a slit throat - which was added post-mortem. All else remains unknown. Nevertheless, with the cause of death established, the list of suspects is narrowed down to just a few who had the means and the motive for the crime.
800519: You out the grim truth. The alibi of one sailor does not match his fellows, and he cracks, confessing to the midshipman's murder. It transpires the midshipman had bragged of bedding the other man's wife. The murderer expresses only remorse for his crime, and as the noose is placed around his neck, the crew regret that justice must be so severe.
800520: The interrogation is painfully haphazard. Though it is clear one of the suspects must be the killer, lines of inquiry fail to produce answers. No option remains but to offload all the suspects at the next port to prevent further incident. It is a source of great shame to the crew that fine innocent sailors are certain to be among them.
800521: A brutal approach, but one delivering quick results. It seems the midshipman was preparing to whistle-blow unauthorised smuggling below deck, and was killed for it. The ringleaders threatened others with a similar fate if they didn't keep quiet. The culprits are unceremoniously shot, and the vulgar matter is over.
800522: Torture seldom results in happiness. Your victim screams a confession, perhaps in the hope it will end the pain. With nothing else to go on, you scapegoat the poor beggar, and he is keelhauled until dead. The crew are in no doubt that this was the wrong man, and hope to escape your inhuman expedition at the first opportunity.
800516: The autopsy is dreadfully clumsy, and leaves the body almost unrecognisable. The unschooled 'medic' evidently have a point to prove, and insist on defiling it further, despite being a bundle of nerves. By the end the morgue looks like a butchery, and the stricken mortician runs wildly about the ship, scalpel in hand. Several are injured trying to restrain him, but the psychological trauma of an unsolved mystery is twice as damaging.
800513: Fashion a tool for gathering forensic evidence
800523: What innovation! A bright young spark applies some of the latest forensic researches. The knife used to cut the midshipman's neck is placed inside an airtight box along with vapours belonging to the doctor. As if by magic, when removed, clear sets of fingerprints appear on the shaft! When the crew prints are taken, the guilty party is collared in the most satisfying modern fashion!
800524: It's complicated identifying footwear and gait. Ambitious of the crew, then, to attempt to solve both problems with the one device. Still the notched stick-wheel does prove footprints at the scene are suspicious, and that suspects are limited to just a few matches. But how to get to the bottom of this?
800529: The trial goes as well as can be expected. The suspects are cross-examined, and proceedings recorded with quill and ink. The shoe-prints belong to a solemn old gent, whose testimony reveals him to be the midshipman's secret lover - the reason he was unforthcoming. He confirms the dead man intended suicide from guilt at their relationship, and was trying to prevent it, but arrived too late. All are grateful that the truth is finally out.
800530: The trial is a farce. Sailors bark questions from the sidelines which the suspects are quite within their rights to leave unanswered. But this obstinacy serves only to rile the shouting mob! They flood through the makeshift courtroom and carry the suspects kicking and screaming to deck, before tossing them over the side.
800527: Put the fear of god into the suspects
800532: It's almost like divine intervention. The priest hears each suspect alone, and once the god-fearing killer breaks down and confesses, he is handed his rope. Still, a lack of forgiveness does not trouble the crew, who are relieved this ungodly chapter is now closed.
800533: These are not god-fearing sailors, and hear the priest's weak plea for the killer to come forward with impassive expressions. Perhaps there is a different approach.
800528: Dump all the suspects at the next port, and be done with it
800534: The Singular Case of the Midshipman
800525: Fragile justice! As your craftsmen stare at an empty drawing board, gormless sailors think they help by tidying up the crime scene. With the investigation fumbled, the killer feels he has to take two more lives before he is finally caught. 'Can't believe how sloppy you are in the art of policing,' he teases, 'I could have killed ten more before you'd found me.' Caught he may be, but the damage is already done.
800511: This lot aren't bloodhounds that's for sure, and turn up nothing even with a strong whiff of murder about it all. With the incompetent investigation ending conspicuously silent, the crew must last the remainder of the expedition in fear they are marked next on the list.
800508: Do nothing, it's suicide - nothing more to be said
800698: Widespread suspicion is the undesirable outcome. Ignorance of the full circumstances surrounding the death has the crew feeling powerless. You must accept that quarrels and accusations will now be routine until the end of this expedition.
800441: You have found a radiant relic! The crew toast the success of your archaeological expedition. May we now better understand what it is to be human!
800448: You have captured a wild animal! The crew toast the success of your zoological expedition. This can only aid studies of the natural world!
800454: You have earned a reward for your altruism! The crew toast a successful rescue, with all returning to the glad comforts of home.
800460: You have discovered pirate bounty! With the dread buccaneers blown out of the water, a search of their sunken wreck unearths a well-deserved reward!
801580: You have found a radiant relic! The crew toast the success of your archaeological expedition. May we now better understand what it is to be human!
800008: "A new course must be plotted," insists the ship's second navigator, after crashing in through the door during the small hours. Asked to explain himself, he fancifully blames, "a sudden shift in the position of the stars", as if the cosmos itself were in turmoil.
800013: [AssetData([ExpeditionEventRequirement]) Text] helps the second navigator correct his miscalculation. In a short time, a relieved second navigator has successfully plotted a new course.
800078: Tell him to check his calculations again
800014: The second navigator can no longer see a problem upon reviewing his calculations. The crew, rudely awoken and ready to switch course, take great pleasure in humiliating him for the blunder.
800081: Make them stop. Everyone makes mistakes.
800017: The navigator is thankful and returns to his work.
800082: Let them continue, for light relief
800019: It's good for the general mood, but the second navigator doesn't take it well. He absconds before dawn, taking some supplies with him.
800015: The second navigator is suddenly ill. He looks skyward and blinks rapidly. Jerks and tremors spread through his whole body, before he tumbles, convulsing, to the deck.
800021: The doctor correctly declares this to be an epileptic seizure. He quickly creates a space around the navigator, and loosens his clothing. He assures nervous bystanders that all will soon be well, and that they should go back to sleep.
800084: What in the world is happening to him!?
800023: By now the whole ship is awake, speculating both about the position of the stars and the plight of the navigator. This is going to be a long night.
800079: The ship's clergyman should see him
800024: The clergyman somewhat calms the navigator, encouraging him to re-check the position of the stars. He is now not so certain of his initial claims. No new course is plotted, and the rest of the night passes without incident.
800025: The clergyman is unable to placate the young navigator, and therefore advises he be confined to his bunk for the night. Unfortunately, his tossing and turning mean his bunkmates hardly sleep a wink.
800080: Confine him to his bunk and maintain the current course
800026: The second navigator sleeps poorly, and his incessant tossing and turning mean his bunkmates hardly sleep a wink.
800027: The second navigator sleeps terribly. His fits and screams cause the entire crew to lose sleep.
800053: A cry of "Fog!" pierces the stillness, when before the going was easy. Before long all billow has dropped from the sails. Kelp fingers reach up from the deep as if to grasp the keel, and the ship drifts to a stop. Sure enough, a dense fog descends, through which the panicked crew cannot see more than five paces.
800054: [AssetData([ExpeditionEventRequirement]) Text] invokes the good lord, and the crew are invigorated. As if sensing their buoyant spirit, the fog vanishes almost as quickly as it appeared.
800089: Tell the crew not to lose faith!
800055: After a brief panic, the fog passes. Some try to make light of the matter, but the more experienced sailors hiss and spit at them, as the ship continues on its way.
800056: A sailor screams with terror! He sees a vast, menacing silhouette in the haze. It is an ill omen, and as the fog thickens, the crew resolve to sit apart. They mutter prayers, or grimly sup grog from their hipflasks. As night falls, the shrieking begins. At dawn, the fog  has passed, and the horror made plain. The few remaining crew count missing comrades  and cargo in mournful silence.
800057: The fog grows ever denser, and the crew begin to sweat as if under the hottest noon sun. Suddenly, a sailor staggers wildly across the deck, knocking away those who would grapple at him. He raves delirious, about pursuing shadows, before finally casting himself overboard. A terror-stricken face is the last of him anyone sees.
800038: All Good Things Come From Above
800039: After some uneventful weeks your ship is sailing along a coast with thick jungle. Your crew is bored, working slowly in the sunshine. All of a sudden some bird droppings land on the first mates uniform. Enraged he spots the culprit: A red bird that is flying back into the jungle.
800091: Let [AssetData([ExpeditionEventRequirement]) Text] go ashore to investigate
800041: [AssetData([ExpeditionEventRequirement]) Text] spots some beautiful parrots which could be easily fetched.
800094: Let's take them home. Catch some!
800042: After a few hours ashore [AssetData([ExpeditionEventRequirement]) Text] managed to capture a remarkable amount of birds.
800095: Leave them be and enjoy their beauty
800043: While [AssetData([ExpeditionEventRequirement]) Text] returns to the ship the crew is enjoying the shore leave on this uneventful day.
800092: Send the first mate ashore, give him a chance for revenge!
800045: Everybody knows that the first mate can be quite dextrous but nobody ever saw him this acrobatic! He manages to catch the culprit and a few more!
800046: The birds are brought to the ship.
800097: That's enough. We should leave them be
800047: While the first mate returns to the ship the crew is enjoying the shore leave on this uneventful day.
800048: The birds are more clever than the first mate anticipated. He returns to the ship steaming. He's going to vent his spleen on the crew.
800049: The first mate is angry to the amusement of the crew.
800050: The first mate is angry but then again nobody really cares.
800051: The first mate is furious! He's going to vent his spleen on the crew.
800060: Your ship arrived at a lush coast brimming with wildlife. This must be the famous hunting grounds. Your outlook already spotted some animals in the thick of the jungle.
800062: After a nerve wrecking day of waiting you spot your men at the shores. They managed to catch something.
800063: After some long hours the hunting party returns. They did not catch it alive but brought a trophy.
800064: The landing party did not return yet and if we send more men, we might not be able to crew the ship.
800100: Wait a little longer. Lets hope they're still alive
800074: Still no sign of life. The crew is getting wary.
800101: We cannot wait any longer. They are lost and so will be the rest of the expedition if we don't continue
800073: Heavy hearted the expedition is returning home.
800072: The expedition is worn out. It is decided it's too dangerous to go ashore.
800705: You are chased by an iron dragon! A formidable boat powered by steam, and heavily armed! It has followed you ever since your expedition left port. 'If it is hostile, why does it not fire at us?' your helmsman cries, as its black-scale bows surge nearer and nearer. Its pennants bear the same fearful mark as the pages of your father's diary...
800708: Your direct hits do little damage. They cannot penetrate the dragon's thick hide. The dragon is alongside you. Its iron mouth opens like a flower, revealing the fire in its lungs. Cowled figures manipulate the levers within. They mean to burn you!
800715: Hot stuff! Your guns warp the dragon jaws shut. It's operators cry out, before their ship destructs in its own flame! That'll teach them to mess with a Goode. Wonder who they were? Someone didn't want you to reach The New World. Finding an ally like Isabel Sarmento as Sir Archibald suggested, is vital if you are to fathom this shadowy new threat.
800716: Your hull is toast by the time your aimless gunners give the beast something to chew on. No time to celebrate their destruction when your own ship is on fire... Wonder who they were? Someone didn't want you to reach The New World. Finding an ally like Isabel Sarmento as Sir Archibald suggested, is vital if you are to fathom this shadowy new threat.
800719: The crew cheer! The dance is a fluent chassé, your ship always a step ahead, until the wind fills the sails, and the enemy ironclad is left standing. Wonder who they were? Someone didn't want you to reach The New World. Finding an ally like Isabel Sarmento as Sir Archibald suggested, is vital if you are to fathom this shadowy new threat.
800720: Your tail catches fire in the dragon's breath! Luckily, a south-westerly gust blows you clear and away. No time for celebration when your deck and crew are afire! Wonder who they were? Someone didn't want you to reach The New World. Finding an ally like Isabel Sarmento, as Sir Archibald suggested, is vital if you are to fathom this shadowy new threat.
800712: The dragon boat is too nimble. Your ponderous cannons only lob their ordnance into its wake. The dragon is alongside you. Its iron mouth opens like a flower, revealing the fire in its lungs. Cowled figures manipulate the levers within. They mean to burn you!
800717: The crew cheer! The dance is a fluent chassé, your ship always a step ahead, until the wind fills the sails, and the enemy ironclad is left standing. Wonder who they were? Someone didn't want you to reach The New World. Finding an ally like Isabel Sarmento as Sir Archibald suggested, is vital if you are to fathom this shadowy new threat.
800718: Bungling navigators. Your ship turns the wrong way, and the sails sag. The iron dragon is gaining... The dragon is alongside you. Its iron mouth opens like a flower, revealing the fire in its lungs. Cowled figures manipulate the levers within. They mean to burn you!
800722: 'The rebels know Isabel's whereabouts...' announces the captain, '...we will not last long here without her.' Porto Fogo's tropical shoreline twinkles, its white walls glow. But as you draw toward the terracotta rooftops, you find not the warm welcome you were expecting. The place is crawling with La Corona. They have driven Isabel's freedom fighters away, who it seems until recently had been holding out. You have to discover the location of the secret camp to which the rebels have now been taken.
800726: Footprints in the sand! Two sets. The middle barefoot, and numerous. On either side, fewer and booted. The La Corona guards led prisoners from here into the foothills. You reach the camp, where the rebel prisoners are well-guarded. On the exposed cliff, your options are limited, but you must find Isabel Sarmento! You can storm it, sneak it, or try bluffing it.
800731: You take them completely by surprise. 'Who are you?' the camp commander shrinks in his padded chair, 'none of these dumb rebels were ever that bold!' The prisoners are freed and lead to safety. Once they have had soup and a good night's sleep, a clue as to their mysterious Isabel's whereabouts may be more forthcoming.
800732: It's bloody. Despite having a start on the guards, gunsmoke soon fills the air. Your men have the edge, and get the prisoners out, but good people on both sides have died today. Once they have had soup and a good night's sleep, a clue as to their mysterious Isabel's whereabouts may be more forthcoming.
800733: Joyous faces return. Your crew are so adept at stealth, that the hoots of ashy-faced owls are all that can be heard. A quick punch to the back of the head, and the cell guard is out. The rebels are finally free! Once they have had soup and a good night's sleep, a clue as to their mysterious Isabel's whereabouts may be more forthcoming.
800734: Not all make it. It had gone well - the careful approach, the guards taken care of, until one of your dimwits screeched open the cell door. Then they had to run for it. Once they have had soup and a good night's sleep, a clue as to their mysterious Isabel's whereabouts may be more forthcoming.
800730: Dress as La Corona officers and bluff your way in
800735: It's great theatre. Playing the gruff La Corona general, your spy blags the freedom of the camp. He returns with as many prisoners he can free, each grateful no longer to be a lab rat. Once they have had soup and a good night's sleep, a clue as to their mysterious Isabel's whereabouts may be more forthcoming.
800736: Shots are fired, the moment your silly gaggle of clowns approach. You only succeed in putting the whole camp on alert.
800727: "Aargh my foot!" a man yelps, as you climb into the foothills. Bear traps. Though his ankle is shredded, you know from such a deterrent you must be headed in the right direction. You finally reach the camp, where the rebel prisoners are well-guarded. On the exposed cliff, your options are limited, but you must find Isabel Sarmento! You can storm it, sneak it, or try bluffing it.
800738: Your careful appeal finds eager ears. 'Brave, dear Isabel,' the woman weeps softly. She is cautious, but willing to divulge the place where the La Corona keep the rebels prisoner.You finally reach the camp, where the rebel prisoners are well-guarded. On the exposed cliff, your options are limited, but you must find Isabel Sarmento! You can storm it, sneak it, or try bluffing it.
800739: "Our Isabel?" the woman yells too loud. Your clumsy envoy finally calms her, and she directs you to the prison camp. As Porto Fogo falls away below, you see the woman being led away by La Corona soldiers. You finally reach the camp, where the rebel prisoners are well-guarded. On the exposed cliff, your options are limited, but you must find Isabel Sarmento! You can storm it, sneak it, or try bluffing it.
800725: Try to bribe an La Corona soldier
800740: The man awaits your offer with a casual air.
800743: "Try what you like," smirks the soldier, pointing up to the cliff where the rebels are being kept, "if anyone's seen near that place, they kill them!" After a deep breath, you begin the journey up. You finally reach the camp, where the rebel prisoners are well-guarded. On the exposed cliff, your options are limited, but you must find Isabel Sarmento! You can storm it, sneak it, or try bluffing it.
800744: 'I don't deal with rebel sympathisers anyway' he lilts. You leave, in case he is suddenly bothered enough to call the cavalry.
800747: 'I'll mark her on the map with an S!' says Ramón, one of the rebels you freed, at the mention of the name Samuel Goode. 'Why not an X?' says the captain with an air of disappointment. 'Sarmento!' says Ramón, his eyes sparkling with life, 'She is the key to everything. Without her, you will be nothing here but an La Corona pawn.' It seems your father must have thought the same.
800748: Take the most direct land route to Isabel
800750: Nought is wrong with your compass. But this is not the picnic you thought it would be. Dense and dark is the rainforest, it feeds on your hope. But what's this? Human tracks! Does all hope return?
800754: You are true navigators. Stick to the map no matter what. Yes the odd hack with a machete is wanted, but that's the terrain! Ramón's 'S' mark lies above a promising cleft in rock. Could this be the domain of the elusive Sarmento?! Oil lamps light the way to a large cavern. A fire prevails in its centre, and at your arrival, figures about it stand and draw their weapons. The foremost of them has a face most charismatic, a picture of defiance.
800755: There is a dispute regarding the map. Some of the group go ahead to check. When they do not return, the rest try to follow. They fall straight into the same trap. 'One false move and we kill you,' growls their leader. It appears these are Isabel's people. If only you could prove you share in their cause.
800756: You hunt well. Believing the tracks too good to be true, your crew stay alert. Sure enough, a second, faint set leads away from the first - which were surely there as a red herring. You find a promising cleft in rock. Could this be the domain of the elusive Sarmento?! Oil lamps light the way to a large cavern. A fire prevails in its centre, and at your arrival, figures about it stand and draw their weapons. The foremost of them has a face most charismatic, a picture of defiance.
800757: Suspiciously easy. 'It feels liked we've missed something. Any old man and his dog could follow these prints,' says your tracker. 'That's the idea,' says a voice. Uh-oh...'One false move and we kill you,' growls their leader. It appears these are Isabel's people. If only you could prove you share in their cause.
800751: 'Why didn't we stick to the map?!' your crew moan at gunpoint. Someone thought taking a shortcut through dense undergrowth was a good idea. Turns out it was perfect for an ambush.'One false move and we kill you,' growls their leader. You realise these are Isabel's people, but it seems they take you to be executed! If only you could prove you share in their cause.
800758: Wait for your moment to disarm them
800761: A classic ruse! Your men know it from the army. "Watch out! Jaguar!" bellows a former soldier. Your captors look to the trees, only to have their weapons ripped free in the same moment. Your men show they mean no harm. Naturally Isabel's men remain cautious, as you are led to a promising cleft in the rock. Oil lamps light the way to a large cavern. A fire prevails in its centre, and at your arrival, figures about it stand and draw their weapons. The foremost of them has a face most charismatic, a picture of defiance.
800762: You choose the wrong moment, and one of you gets a good whack on the head for it. 'Lucky we are expecting you,' says the leader, 'you can come with us, but I warn you, no funny business.' Naturally Isabel's men remain cautious, as you are led to a promising cleft in the rock. Oil lamps light the way to a large cavern. A fire prevails in its centre, and at your arrival, figures about it stand and draw their weapons. The foremost of them has a face most charismatic, a picture of defiance.
800760: Convince them of your good intentions
800763: They visibly soften, when it is mentioned your father is Samuel Goode. "Isabel will see you," says the leader, "just don't ask me what she will do with you." Naturally Isabel's men remain cautious, as you are led to a promising cleft in the rock. Oil lamps light the way to a large cavern. A fire prevails in its centre, and at your arrival, figures about it stand and draw their weapons. The foremost of them has a face most charismatic, a picture of defiance.
800764: This is no time for delicacy. Your diplomats are too roundabout in their explanations. 'Shut up, shut up, shut up!' the leader knocks your silly sod out with the butt of his rifle. 'We know who you are, come with us already.' Naturally Isabel's men remain cautious, as you are led to a promising cleft in the rock. Oil lamps light the way to a large cavern. A fire prevails in its centre, and at your arrival, figures about it stand and draw their weapons. The foremost of them has a face most charismatic, a picture of defiance.
800749: Build a raft and take the quicker river route
800765: It holds well enough, accommodating all. The current is getting stronger, as if up ahead some hazard awaits. 'I don't know if she'll take a bump,' says the captain.
800767: Disembark and follow the map instead
800773: 'Bingo!' bark your proud orienteers, pointing at the tunnels. 'Guerrilla tubes,' says the captain with a sage nod. They match the map, leading to a promising cleft in rock. Could this be the domain of the elusive Sarmento?! Oil lamps light the way to a large cavern. A fire prevails in its centre, and at your arrival, figures about it stand and draw their weapons. The foremost of them has a face most charismatic, a picture of defiance.
800774: 'Why didn't we stick to the map?' lament the crew. But the lure of guerrilla tunnels they found beside the river was too much. After crawling forever, they come to an opening. Above, a battery of guns are trained on their heads.'One false move and we kill you,' growls their leader. It appears these are Isabel's people. If only you could prove you share in their cause.
800768: Reinforce the raft and keep paddling
800775: Huzzah for bootlaces! The tightly-wound logs bounce over the edge..."Waaaaaah! What a thrill!" exclaims the captain, as you splash into the clear pool. Beside it is a promising cleft in the rock. Could this be the domain of the elusive Sarmento?! Oil lamps light the way to a large cavern. A fire prevails in its centre, and at your arrival, figures about it stand and draw their weapons. The foremost of them has a face most charismatic, a picture of defiance.
800776:
Not sturdy enough! A hard knock in the rapids leaves your men clutching timber. It is only then that they realise they've attracted spectators. There's laughter from the riverbank, before the bystanders pull them from the water at gunpoint.
"One false move, and we kill you," growls their leader. It appears these are Isabel's people. If only you could prove you share in their cause.
800766: A feeble craft! One bump on a sharp bend leaves your men clutching timber. It is only then they realise they are being watched. There is laughter from the riverbank, before the bystanders pull them from the water at gunpoint. 'One false move and we kill you,' growls their leader. It appears these are Isabel's people. If only you could prove you share in their cause.
802853: Cornered by a fearsome Pyrphorian vessel! Your expedition has reached South America at last, and the crew are looking forward to some well-earned rest. Night has fallen, and your ship is already in the tranquil bay when the look out screams "behind us!". There, looming in the darkness, gleams a dragon of iron, its nostrils livid with fire. "It's the vessel that killed Mr. Goode! But this one must be twice as large! We are at their mercy!" However, the bay is hidden from the bright gaze of the moon, and it is possible the dragon has not yet spotted you. If you choose to show yourself, you cannot expect to be a match for the dragon - only to somehow hinder it long enough to flee.
802855: Your aim is true, but the dragon is gathering its hot breath. To engage the hulking vessel is a humbling experience — the size, the power, the feet-thick armoured hull that your ordnance seems to only bounce limply off. The crew seem defeated, until they realise their precise fire at the dragon's stern, while showing no external sign of damage, appears to have caused a problem in the engine room. As a response, masked figures rush to prime the beastly mouth — a great cannon of fire! You must act quickly.
802856: Maintain your fire on the weakened engine
802857: Your crew cheer the cannoneers, and one good hit to the same spot does the trick! There are loud rasping noises before the ironclad's engines fall silent, and the great monstrosity drifts to a gentle halt. As your crew escape, they are forced to pass close by the enemy, and see the gnarled and hateful iron of the bows and boards, the army of mocking masks, and the firepit of a mouth that could easily have been their end. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. You set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, confident it will keep you well-hidden.
802858: Your aim isn't quite as good this time. Your shots roll over the solid iron deck like balls of ivory on a bagatelle board, barely making a dent. The iron dragon's mouth yawns wide above your little boat, and from it, the first plume of fire melts the men at the taffrail. The two hulls are close enough for boarding, but there are just too many of the rogues. Your only options are to cause confusion by throwing some of your stink-pot grenados, or to target the flaming cannon itself.
802859: Aim to disable the dreaded cannon
802860: The shot finds its mark. A canister of gas fueling their weapon whistles free of its housing, and blows fire spasmodically about the deck. Some of the mystery of the enemy disappears in that instant, as the cowled crows fight to regain control. As your crew escape, they are forced to pass close by the enemy, and see the gnarled and hateful iron of the bows and boards, the army of mocking masks, and the firepit of a mouth that could easily have been their end. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. Your crew set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, where they begin repairs to the ship.
802861: The shot is good, but it takes too long to line up. Your ship is too close to the dragon's mouth when it's hit, and the eruption of flaming debris is most violent! Having travelled for many days along the New World coast, it is now time to decide how you will travel on from here. Ahead, a broad brown rivermouth invites you upstream, its perils waiting unseen beyond its bends. "Perhaps a route over land will be more forgiving?", says the navigator hopefully. Beyond the next bend are a set of devious rapids frothing down towards you, and with the Pyrphorian dragon fast approaching, time is in short supply. There is a very narrow breach at one side, through which a vessel capably navigated may just about fit. Alternatively, blasting the high cliffs could block the Pyrphorian's way.

Though a steamer might be better suited to the task, the iron dragon makes no attempt to pursue. Your captain is quick to praise the great skill of your navigator, rather than face the troubling possibility that the Pyrphorians know of a greater danger to come. The river has taken you as far as it can, and you must decide whether to continue across a marsh of uncertain depth, or as Ramón suggests, to head through a nearby network of caves.

A young sailor reveals a mossy bunker in the forest carpet, "Long since deserted," he laughs, "your information must be out of date, Ramón." "Many years out of date," calls a voice from the trees. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"

802998: "We are here on behalf of Her Majesty the Queen!"
803001: "You think I care about your stupid empire?!" curses Isabel, beckoning to two guards to tightly restrain you. "No sooner had we gained independence from La Corona, than we receive an offer too-good-to-be-true from an envoy of your Queen. An 'amazing prospect, Prosperity', he said - and at first it was." Isabel grunts and slams her boot knife into a barrel, from which wine spurts out. "Now that island, our last hope of freedom, is overrun with these masks, these... twisted people, and their fire!" She rushes at you, and forces your lips open for a better answer...
803002: "My father was Samuel Goode. I am here to stop the Pyrphorians!"
803004: Isabel slowly releases her grip. She stabs her boot knife back into the wine barrel, plugging the hole. "Then you are against the Pyrphorians. Isabel motions her guards to release you, "...I should at least hear what you're planning to do about all this."
